this movie is the best movie i have ever seen, the actors are incredible the photography is unbelievable and the music insuperable, but i cannot understand why Kevin Costner, after doing such a good movie begun doing horrible ones, like robin hood or waterworld, those are terrible movies, but let just don't talk about those lets talk about this, what i can't believe is that this film is not in the top 250, i almost killed my self when i found it, but thats only my opinion if anybody believes that this movie is bad then i can't do anything about it, in my opinion this movie is insuperable in its genre, the western.

This movie is an epic adventure from the beginning to the end. It hits every note perfectly; story, characters, score and the beautiful landscape. It is action, adventure, and a love story all rolled in one.

reviews.review_title: Kevin is not only a brilliant actor but one of the greatest directors
reviews.content: People who say this movie is long and boring have obviously never sat through, oh, "Lawrence of Arabia," "Patton," "Doctor Zhivago," "The Godfather," "Ran," "Seven Samurai," or probably even "Brave heart." Thank God that not every filmmaker believes that a car must explode every 10 seconds in order for his movie to be a success. Kevin Costner is one of those directors who prefers the long format. David Lean, Francis Coppola and Mel Gibson, to name a very few, also worked in that format, and produced lasting works of art that also packed theaters. There are plenty of options for people who don't like movies that take the time to build character, drama and suspense, movies like "Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle," "Freddy Vs. Jason," and "Weekend at Bernie's." I don't think any of those movies has ever been called "boring," but they sure are crap cinema.Onward. "Dances With Wolves" thrilled audiences way back in 1990 and made so darn much money precisely because people had forgotten the pleasures of the long narrative, the Western genre, and movies that weren't special effects schlock-fests. It remains an inspiring and moving experience, especially on DVD, which preserves the movie's theatrical sound and picture quality.Costner's direction is first-rate. He's able to blend intimate drama with big, sprawling action that covers a huge canvas. I'm amazed at how smoothly the film segues from movement to movement -- action, alienation, suspense, social commentary, romance. Heck, Spielberg could take a lesson or two from this movie.He also gets great performances out of his cast. I don't think of these people as actors, but as the characters they play. That's a compliment not just to the actors themselves, but their director. And, yes, Costner is terrific as John Dunbar.Sure, it's easy to call "Dances" politically correct w/ reference to the Indians. But it also treats them as people and, better yet, as fictional characters whose lives are made part of a fascinating narrative. I just consider all the complaints about the politics of this movie as total hogwash.Finally, the movie is beautifully shot, has an unforgettable score, and is very well-written. I've never thought of "Dances" as a Western, but a modern action picture/character study that avoids all the boring clichés of the Western genre. Here is a movie that stands for something, means something, and deserves at least as much respect as some of the overrated deck we've gotten saddled with lately.

reviews.review_title: Meaningful appreciation of a vanishing culture.
reviews.content:
The first time I watched this movie, I almost fell asleep half way through seeing it. I was only 13 years old, so the movie's contents were above my adolescent expectation. Furthermore all conversations in Sioux and Pawnee languages were subbed in mandarin; itself a foreign tongue for me.
Today, ten years later, I just have watched it again in its original English format and I'm deeply at awe at the beauty of this film. Physically speaking, the cinematography, setting, lighting and costumes were very well executed/done. But the real strength comes from Blakes' great storytelling and Costner's engaging directing. This film deserved all the credits it is dued. I felt fortunate to also see the movie the second time in its intended 4-hour version, which I believe brings us a fuller picture of a man's journey of self-discovery. What he found is the heart of the land for which he fought for (during the Civil War) and thought he knew. A transformational quest of consummation between the heart, cultures and ways of life. There are moments when I feel that the performances were not genuine enough, but if you think about it, the actors and movie staff had done a great job in capturing the essence of a vanishing culture. Costner's character for instance, is too naive and sweet for a white soldier of his time, but the movie must be made accessible to a wider audience in the US, hence the story is mostly told from his point of view. Having said that, the real heroes in this movie are the Native Americans, who tried to survive the wind of change brought by colonialization.The character of Dunbar has become a tool of narration that essentially tells us a beautiful story. A story about a vanishing culture, a people whose spirit and way of life are the very essence of America. The true America. When this movie was released in Asia, most of the local audiences labeled the movie as being a watchable bad-movie. The truth is the movie's contents resonanced with the local histories. We are doing exactly what the white colonial movement of that time, were doing against the native people. So those who didn't accept the message and learn from it, were disturbed. I have learnt something  and absolutely love this movie.

Ridiculously long and at times achingly slow (some scenes, like the one where Mary McDonnell's white captive first translates for Kevin Costner's title character, seem to last longer than an Indian/White treaty council) with needless narration and at times annoyingly PC views of the extremely warlike Sioux as paragons of wisdom and warmth, this is an easy film to take pot shots at. It also has some splendid action pieces like the buffalo hunt and the battle with the Pawnee (who for some weird reason look like Iroquois) and odd moments that get your attention like the mentally deranged major, played to creepy perfection by the great Canadian actor Maury Chaikin, the domestic life of Kicking Bird and his chatty wife, and the interplay between Lt. Dunbar and his pet wolf, Two Socks. Pile up enough of these scenes and moments and throw in John Berry's beautiful music and Dean Semler's even more beautiful cinematography and, bingo, you got yourself a pretty damn good movie. Should it have won best picture over "Goodfellas" and should Costner have won best director over Scorsese, to mention nothing of nabbing a best actor nomination for a rather flat, emotionless performance? Obviously not. But as an epic western from a first time director it's impressive. Give it a B. PS...Of all the many awards this picture got the most well deserved was Graham Greene's nomination for best supporting actor, playing the introspective Kicking Bird. This guy should have had a bigger career.

This is one of my all time favorites. The only drawback is the length (Three hours!), but you'll hardly notice. The best parts include Kevin Costner's performance and direction, the beautiful cinematography, Costner's wolf scenes, and the buffalo hunt scene. You'll love it, I guarantee it.*** 1/2 out of ****

Although some of my Native American friends are quite angry at this film, I would point out that it was not made as a definitive history, but as a story to entertain. As such, it did not need to be factually correct, but I think it shows the native peoples in a very favourable light and is sympathetic to their plight over a hundred years ago. I would also point out that not all buffalo hunters were white - many tribes slaughtered thousands of buffalo so that they could sell the skins to other natives as well as to whites.One last thought - The Indian Wars happened over a century ago so nothing we can say or o today will undo any of the wrongs committed by either side, so isn't it time we all moved on and lived as the world is today? To quote a Native saying, "We Are All Related." Sheila

The worst-paced and most stiffly directed movie to ever win Best Picture and Best Director.  Every soldier is played as a parody of a human being.  Possibly , this is the single most OVERRATED movie of all time.  Really Bad.  Only Grahame Greene and a few of the other native American actors are terrific.

reviews.review_title: I would LIKE to give this a higher mark.
reviews.content: Just saw this film for the first time, 20 years after it was made! But the film had NO balance, so I can't mark it up. All the Native Americans are sensitive in their way, heroic, understanding, reasonable, and at least fairly good looking. All the whites, besides Costner and Mary McDonnell, are two-dimensional villains and/or oafs, jerks, morons, and not good looking. This is a stacked-deck look at the two ethnic groups if there ever was one.Not one white soldier is even willing to listen to Costner for a minute? They are all incredibly cruel from the get-go? ALL of them are also stupid? Not one of the Sioux tribe harbors jealousy, mistrust or resentment toward Costner, or is just not that great a guy? Then there is the scene where the white soldiers shoot the wolf. This REALLY strained one's willingness to believe because it is a movie. What wolf is going to hang around while being hammered with the sound of gunshots and seeing guns pointed at him? Even if he loves Costner, the wolf called Two Socks is going to take cover, wouldn't you think? He just stands there, waiting to be killed. This means he is supposed to be a spirit or angel I guess, not really a wolf. But that point is not made clear.Finally, I have to agree with those who say that Costner is not much of an actor or a narrator. Since he's the big star, and in all the scenes, that really detracts. I will say that the buffaloes were impressive and some of the actors playing the Sioux were easy on the eyes.

reviews.review_title: Neither a Masterwork, nor a piece of Garbage...
reviews.content: Its bad points: it drips sentimentality. KC grows tiresome as the ONE WHO SEES. The Native Peoples are portrayed as too ideal, and simplistic.On the other hand: It take its time to REALLY take you into its fairy-tale world...it is a true Epic... Production values are top notch. It got those ADD-addled Americans to sit still for 3 hours and pay attention for a change...Not a bad film, 4 out of 5 stars. I can see how its preachyness could get on ones nerves.Bruce Beresfords THE BLACK ROBE is in many ways a more satisfying picture, but is a much smaller picture, budget and storywise...

First I have to say that I enjoyed this film, but I have a couple of persnickety questions though about native American tribes. 1) Why was the main tribe changed from Comanche (as in the book) to Lakota (Sioux) for the film? 2) Why does Hollywood always seem to cast the Pawnee as the villains? This was the case in this film and in others - Little Big Man immediately springs to mind - again, in the film version, the Pawnee replaced Cheyenne as the murders of Jack Crabb's family. As far as I can make out, the Pawnee gave great service to the US as army scouts. I would have thought they deserve some recognition by Hollywood, rather than always being cast in the role of villain. Seems a little ungrateful? Just a thought

I'm certain that scripts like this one come along maybe once, or twice (if lucky), in a Director's lifetime. It takes such a high level of expertise and talent to convey a story in such a way that it moves an audience emotionally. This film contains all of the elements necessary to do just that; capture someone's attention and in the process entertain both satisfactorily, as well as thoroughly. I can understand the accolades given for the cinematography of this film, the beauty and majesty of the open plain was captured here in its most basic of elements. In fact, I can understand all 7 of the Academy Awards this film has garnered, the story is told with such great skill you don't even mind that more than half the film is in subtitles. In fact, this element just seems to reinforce the impact of this cinematic epic. Kevin Costner has always been an interesting, accomplished actor, however, he has attained pure excellence in his direction of this film.When I think of excellence in dramatic films few come to mind, this just happens to be one of them. Brilliant, beautiful job!! Par excellence!!

reviews.review_title: An epic masterpiece that will stand the test of time.
reviews.content: This western is an example of why we go to the theatre, rent or sit through wast of time commercials on our TV. 1990 was a remarkable year for movies. Such pictures as The Awakenings, GoodFellas and Millers Crossing was released to theatres. Yet surprisingly yes Kevin Costner directs a film around and greater then some of the three. Maybe a tie between GoodFellas. As for a classic up building whimsical cow boy and Indians film. Costner has made hands down the best.An epic masterpiece that will stand the test of time. Just in case you have not seen this show yet I'm not saying any details. If you like the experience of watching a good story unfold before your eyes and ears. This western is going to take your mind and hart into the wild frontier times.One the greatest films ever created. 10/10 for me. A strong recommend, yes even now after 20 some years of being in the rental section.

reviews.review_title: The greatest injustice in Oscar's history!
reviews.content: This drivel beat out Goodfellas???? HELLO?!?!? Anyone notice that Costner can't act? How about the idea that they went through all the trouble to use authentic Lakota Sioux dialect, than slather makeup on Kev and his bride for the wedding scene close-ups. Please! This film was awful, downright awful.

reviews.review_title: spectacular photography but little more with 'underdog hero' Costner
reviews.content: 'Dances with Wolves' became quite a popular film in the early 1990s when the western was making a revival. This film portrays a frontiersman who discovers a life with native American people and a respect for their way of life. It depicts the native Americans as people more than previous westerns, which had a more lowly view of them.The best thing about the film is the production value - the attention to detail, the set design, the costumes, and so on. Some of the landscape shots were breath-taking, and there was also a good sense of action. I believe that this is the reason why the film was so popular. (Not to mention the audience's new love for Kevin Costner and for being more fairer to the native American culture on the silver screen.) However, I do not think this is the best film ever made. In between sweeping scenery and action are fairly long drags of dialog and Kevin Costner being a hero and showing him with his native American wife and hard life and loss. I'd personally rate this as an average film, but it gets points for some spectacular photography.

Very few movies can be called true masterpieces, movies which change the way you think, feel and ultimately stay with you forever. Dances with Wolves is one such film. It is so refreshing to see a 'WESTERN' portraying the Native Americans not as beggars and thieves, but as thoughtful, caring human beings. The relationship struck with John Dunbar and the tribe makes great cinema with a timeless story of courage, discovery and friendship. This film is rich and colourful from its awe inspiring landscapes to its fabulous array of talented actors, most notably Graham Greene whose portrayal of Kicking Bird is absolutely perfect. I urge people who have not seen this film to open your heart to what most must agree to be one of the greatest movies ever made. The music score by John Barry is my favourite movie soundtrack and I suggest that you listen to the soundtrack if you can. Perfect, perfect, perfect, this film is a very precious thing which will transport you to the American frontier, presented in all its wonder and glory. A MUST SEE!!!!

"Dances with Wolves" is beautiful. The detailed conversion on my new Blu player is and was phenomenal. The individual blades of grass stood tall and at moments I felt as if I was right there with Costner as he chased Two-Socks, or crossed the sweeping frontier. Costner's film, if anything, gave a modern technology country a view of a world that nearly feels fictional. No computers, no cell phones, nothing facing you except nature, and the power of Mother Earth. Costner captures this feeling with perfection. Not only does he have the time to cultivate this sensation, but he uses both audio and visual references to assist with his imagery. There was no doubt in my mind that Costner felt dedicated to this project that his creative eye wasn't at the peak of its existence. His passion bled through the film, giving us that moment when "Dances with Wolves" transforms from Hollywood project to Costner's dream come true. For that I applaud Costner for following his heart and creating a visual treat that goes beyond your average film.While Costner's imagery stands powerfully next to any great director's work, it is the overall story that ultimately holds back the rest of the film. Costner is obviously comfortable behind the camera, but it is his work within the film that feels a bit repetitive and cliché. Costner is not Lieutenant Dunbar. While he is the imaginative force behind the story, he cannot seem to tackle the character itself. Costner never quite transforms himself into something we haven't seen. Perhaps watching it during its release would have been a different story, but in 2008, one watches Costner be Costner only in Native American headwear. The scenes in this film where he first encounters the sounds of the frontier, or later when he finds an unseen love, were utterly dishonest. Costner was Costner; there was no other way to see it. The only parts that glimmered with a possible character were the beginning run through the barrage of open bullets, and the violent reintroduction to the white culture near the end were satisfactory, but for just a few short moments. Costner needed to tell us more about Dunbar, give us either flashbacks of his life or his reason for making decisions. The voice-over wasn't convincing enough as a conscious to give us true rhyme or reason. Those puppy dog eyes that Costner blasted any chance he had never gave us the torment that obviously dwelled within this man. There was a reason for his possible suicide attempt and escape into the wild. With no mention of family or history, it is difficult to understand Costner's why.With Costner misleading us through the mapping of this film, it was left up to the other players to demonstrate a goal at the end of this four hour tunnel. This semi-happened with Graham Greene's character and Catherine McCormack's role, two people forced into cliché roles that they have played time and time again. This time they pulled it off well, but I just didn't believe them. Greene plays this character in every film he has ever been in, while McCormack's character was a cross between Helen Keller and Pocahontas. Not to sound offensive to Native American's, I was happy to see a sympathetic view of them via Costner's eyes, but it felt used. Hardship seemed to be an unknown word to this tribe. Costner was able to walk on in, build relationships, not worry about food rations, and easily jump right into the culture without any worry. There was never a moment where I found myself saying, "Ah, is he going to make it?"  the simplicity of it all seemed faked and merely in place for emotions sake.Finally, the question of time has to be approached. Did Costner need four hours to tell this story? Alas, no. Using the beautiful landscape he merely bought time, aka filler, to push his simplistic tale from average story to epic. In two hours, Costner could have pushed the emotional button further and really dedicated himself to his character. At pushing 245 minutes, we felt as if we lost the character of Dunbar after the first hour and a half. With such a broad canvas, not enough was dedicated to the right parts. Costner's relationships with the other characters were pushed so far that a sense of apathy was built. Any cares that we had were brushed away at the two and a half hour mark.Overall, Costner's film probably deserved the Oscars at the time  but it currently doesn't stand alone as a modern masterpiece. Costner misjudged this film pushing the framing too far and loosing the central focus. His character of Dunbar seemed more like an imitation of Droopy Dog in the frontier, instead of a stylized representation of a true soul. Costner does powerfully show us a sympathetic view of the Native American culture during the time of its downfall, but with such an epic nature I expected it to carry more realism. The Sioux has danger, they had fears, and they had their own to worry about, but once Costner appeared we saw none of that. Costner was so excited about learning about them, about communicating with them, that we never quite had the chance to see their world. Costner must be given credit for his eye in this film. While his directing skills were not as I anticipated, his visual eye was superb. Images that may never be captured again were detailed throughout, giving us the view of an epic  although lacking the other parts. "Dances with Wolves" is worth viewing at least once, but another four hours could not be done by this critic even if life depended on it.Grade: ** ½ out of *****

reviews.review_title: Superb cinematography, did what needed doing.
reviews.content: ...And what was that, you ask?Quite simple - remind as many people as possible that millions of Native american men, women and children were slaughtered by murderers that stole their land.First-hand accounts are still widely available, senate approved plans of Genocide are similarly available, yet the American public as a whole prefer their history to be served up a la John Ford or refer to it in a silly, tart phrase such as "Manifest destiny".It is, after all, a lot easier to believe what you want to, rather than what is (and which is usually less attractive)I digress. This film has a lot of very good things going for it, The cinematography, the script (mostly), the way the story flows and explains in a believable way what is happening to Lt John Dunbar, it also shows the increasing trepidation on the part of tribes just beginning to come into proximity with the expanding towns and forts. (The way in which the elder presents Dunbar with a Conquistador helmet as his belief that they will remain unaffected is very poignant)It's not a perfect film, but this was Costner's first attempt at directing, and was a whole load better than the laughable "Robin Hood".Costner's not the first actor to want to make such a statement in film and wake people up, Brando tried for twenty years, but the studios did'nt think it would make money.I hope this film will make some people find out more on the subject. Some of what they will find is harrowing, but the truth, already there, needs to be spread to a populace that basically does'nt care.Still.

I have always read that Native Americans (NA) are typically portrayed as bloodthirsty savages.  To which I say, where?  Through most of my adult life they have been these tree-hugging, talk-to-the-animals spiritualists who can almost do no wrong.  Dances With Wolves shows the warm and cuddly side of NA life, centering around the horse-culture Sioux with the occasional dabble into the raider culture of the Pawnee.The film deifies NA culture, focusing on their spirituality and oneness with nature:  the NA use all parts of the buffalo to honour the animal's spirit. The fact that they are a Cro-Magnon people who *necessarily* need food, clothing, tools and weapons is not addressed.Dances With Wolves presents the other stereotype, but a stereotype still. Check the four-hour version if you can find it, tho.  They put the deleted scenes back into the film (where all deleted scenes belong!) instead of tacked on a separate disc.

I'll save you the time it takes to watch this film. White = bad.  I don't know if Costner simply took at face value what his "Native advisors" were telling him, but he should've done more homework. (Were there any Pawnee advisors on this film, by the way?) Some of the period details are right on, many are not.  Books such as "Death on Horseback" will give a much better idea of the "frontier" at this time. Costner's hamfisted, cliched direction not only obscures many facts about the pacification on the "west" (both pro and con from the "white" point of view) but does so in WAY too many frames.  To think that this bloated, slow, snoozefest beat out "Goodfellas" for best picture!  Good thing, too, that he happened to stumble across a good looking white girl with a nice feminist name!  "Stands with a fist"...(groan.)
Kevin Costner Proves Himself As An Actor And A Director In A Movie That Can Be Summed Up With One Word .... Epic.

reviews.review_title: A classic now borrowed by other film makers
reviews.content: Dances With Wolves is such a powerful story that it was transposed almost directly into Avatar. I have the extended DVD and would recommend anyone who truly loves this film to see it. It explores in greater depth, the lives of the Sioux Indians and is more sympathetic to the destruction of their lifestyle than the standard version. In one extra scene, we see Kicking Bird taking Dances With Wolves on a journey to a sacred place where they believed all life sprang from. Once there, they see the unwarranted and indiscriminate killing of both the environment and wildlife. Two extra scenes also deal with the early differences between John Dunbar and the tribe. One is where the white hunters who butchered the buffalo had been caught and the tribe were celebrating by waiving their scalps around a fire, and the other is where a Pawnee warrior has his head bashed in by a elderly female Sioux. They were apparently cut from the film because they showed a more naked savagery, but I feel they show the truth in the difficulties faced by a people fighting for survival. I really can't praise this film enough for its sheer breadth of vision, its powerful emotions and the way Kevin Costner draws out the majesty of the plains, its changing seasons and the ebbing and flowing of the life that clung so desperately to their land, only to lose it to a people who, as Dunbar narrates, have no souls, no honour and no regard for Sioux rights.

SPOILERS!!!!!!   SPOILERS!!!!!!!!!    SPOILERS!!!!!!!!! This film is a romanticized and sympathetic look (finally) at the Native American side of US expansion in the 1800's. A solitary US Army officer is sent out to manage a vast area of territory and is befriended by the Native Americans, without whom he would not have survived. Eventually, though, the Army comes through and is not pleased to find that he's "turned Injun". The film accurately paints the white man as encroaching upon land that they had signed a treaty that gave that land to the Native Americans. The white man indiscriminately kills the Bison that the Native Americans needed for food and shelter. Altogether, not a pretty picture of the white man and a somewhat romanticized picture of the Native American. The acting is superb and the story, unfortunately, is most likely similar to one played over and over again in the west.

reviews.review_title: Good story line makes this one stand out from the others
reviews.content: The history of the western has gone through several traumatic changes: from the good guys (sherriffs and soldiers) killing the bad guys (usually feather-wearing and painted in ochres) with chaps like Hoppalong Cassidy or John Wayne doing their bit, but usually without much serious subject matter. Sergio Leone with Clint Eastwood (and the great music by Ennio Morricone) tried to make the western into an art form, which had also been tried with Yul Brynner in `The Magnificent Seven'. Kevin Costner has made more mistakes than good films: Dances with Wolves is probably his best. Well filmed, good story-line, mostly good acting, and of course the only really good music from John Barry, who is usually so repetitive he gets sickening (apart from his really majestic apportation in `Zulu' 1964). `Dances with Wolves' stands out from most films related with the Civil War and/or general Westerns in that there is more sincerity, more human compassion and feeling, without forgetting the superb photography. The buffalo hunt was just simply superb, really great filming. I've just seen this film for the second time, and even so it did not seem too long in its cinema three-hour form. I shall watch it again some day......

reviews.review_title: One of the best western movies ever made
reviews.content: While I was watching Kevin Costner's Dances with Wolves (1990) I was reminded of a book excerpt that I read which was from a book called Black Elk Speaks because both stories talk about the Sioux tribe, but the book was based on real life events and this movie is fictional. Costner's film tells the story of Lt. John J. Dunbar(played by Kevin Costner himself) who is a Civil war veteran who served with the Union army who is under exile all by himself in an empty farm while looking for buffalo and at the same time befriending the Sioux tribe. Costner's movie is very well made but I really don't think that this film should have won the 1990 best picture Oscar over Martin Scorsese's masterful mob picture which came out in the same year which was Goodfellas because to me it was more deserving, Costner's film is on a par with some of the best western movies ever made along with The Searchers (1956), Unforgiven (1992), Rio Bravo (1959), The Good, the bad, and the Ugly (1966), Pale Rider (1985), and so many more. Like Driving Miss Daisy in the scenes where Dunbar tries to make friends with the Lakota Sioux tribe it is a story of skepticism and later it becomes a very inspiring story of friendship and love for one another. As well as the scenes where Costner's character is about to be hanged by his former military friends his fellow native American friends come back to save him and those scenes prove to us that people from different races can still be very important people in a particular point of your life.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films in cinema history!
reviews.content: Whether you are a fan of Kevin Costner or not, "Dances with Wolves" is a must see! Despite this film's impressive running time of 3 hours, it actually feels shorter than that once the powerful story plot draws you into the world of the Civil War era. Costner, Greene, and McDonnell should have all received Oscars for their performances, as this film was that good! I was amazed at how well the writers were able to portray the Native American life, too, as it is hard to come by a film that does this so well.Costner basically plays a Civil War lieutenant that comes across a Native American Sioux tribe while on his journey to the frontier. Over time, he eventually befriends the tribe. Not long after, he falls in love with one of the tribe's family members, named Stands With A Fist, a woman who they took in from another family after she tragically lost her husband. They end up marrying each other.Costner's character, John Dunbar, is then given the Sioux name "Dances With Wolves" after the tribe leader, Kicking Bird, played brilliantly by Graham Greene, notices Dunbar playing around with a wolf that he names "Two Socks." Later on, Dunbar is captured by some soldiers of the Civil War and is pressed for answers as to why he is wearing Native American clothing even though he claims to be enlisted in the Civil War. He later tells them that his name is "Dances With Wolves" and that he is a member of the Sioux tribe. Knowing this information, the soldiers attempt to kill Dunbar, but their plans are foiled when the Sioux tribe intervenes and takes back Dunbar. Back at the tribe's camp, Dunbar then announces to the entire tribe that they should move their camp so that the soldiers won't know where to find them. They quickly object Dunbar's proposal. In response to this, Dunbar then announces that he plans to leave the tribe behind, and his wife, Stands With A Fist, also agrees to go with him. As they are leaving, the film ends with the tribe giving Dunbar a Native American salute as a way of thanking him for all that he has done for them.In summary, "Dances With Wolves" is one of those films that makes you feel like you are really there. It is simply an extraordinary masterpiece. The bottom line? See this film. You won't regret it!

It's with good reason that the AFI regards this film in it's top 100 of all-time ... it's an outstanding film. The authentic scenery in the cinematography, the fascinating characters wonderfully nuanced by great acting, the compelling story, and last but not least the beautiful musical score all combine to make this one of the best films ever.Some of the actors in this film should've won Oscars but didn't. Many people slam KCostner's acting, but i like his style. He never over acts, stays within himself and was absolutely believable as Lt.John Dunbar.Bravo Kevin Costner, well done.

After being wounded and nearly loses his foot in battle during the American civil war. Lieutenant John Dunbar (Kevin Costner) makes a request to an insane major (Maury Chaykin) to be posted on the frontier before it dissapears. The Major agrees and John is sent to a far outpost to join other soldiers but quickly finds that they are no longer there. On his own he must make for survival as well as use diplomacy to ease tension with a local Sioux tribe. John learns that these people are not the savages his colleagues portray them to be and learns their way as well as befriending a wolf. John is now torn between taking on the Sioux lifestyle and betraying his fellow men or becoming what the army see as the enemy or can he make ties between the Indians and the army?This is 1 of my all time favourite movies. It has such moving sentimentality and is an absolute gem by Kevin Costner. Beautifully filmed (by an Aussie oscar winner) and written. It's quite dissappointing that Costner couldn't continue his success in movie making but this 1 is among the greats. The film researches the complexities along with the simple lifestyle of the Sioux tribe that no longer exists. This also has a huge emotional impact on the audience. "Can you see. I am wind in his hair and I'm your friend" is 1 of the most moving lines in this movie. The native ways of the American Indian was beautiful and at times savage but true to the land where the white man destroyed the buffalo for pelts and the land for greed. It captures the true tragedy that is the loss of these native tribes and their ways of life on what was their own soil. An educational masterpiece that all must see and love as I & many others do. Well done Kev!!

If it's not as good, or better than, 'Dances with Wolves' - it's not a 10.
30 years later, I will say I generally skip the 1st part - to start the show where he's heading out for the fort. I don't think the movie needed the civil war stuff - but that's just nitpicking.

Union soldier Lt. John Dunbar (Kevin Costner) is horribly wounded. Instead of allowing the surgeon to cut off his foot, he rides into the Confederate lines intending to commit suicide. It proves to be a distraction that wins an Union victory. The admiring visiting general gives him any position and he chooses to go west before it's gone. The isolated outpost is deserted after the disappearance of the soldiers. He is alone with his horse with only a wolf to keep company. The neighboring Lakota tribe makes contact and gives him the name of Dances with Wolves. Kicking Bird (Graham Greene) is the leader, Wind In His Hair (Rodney A. Grant) is the wild young buck, and Stands With A Fist (Mary McDonnell) is a white woman adopted into the tribe ever since she was a child.This is both an epic and a compelling human story. It's a western but even more than the old formula. The comic relief that is usually in the old western like Maury Chaykin and Robert Pastorelli are instead used as characters of quirky madness. Kevin Costner gives the film's quiet leading man. The thing that truly sets this apart from the normal Hollywood western is the authentic attempt at native characters and culture. It's not only their sincere attempt at the language and the use of native actors. It is that they are human beings. The communication problems is done expertly. That doesn't always happen even in modern movies. Graham Greene is excellent as a leading voice of the Lakota Sioux band.

reviews.review_title: The best film of all times
reviews.content: Dances With Wolves is the best because it's about the most important thing in life - to live the longest possible and the closest possible to freedom,unlimited,ideal as a being can. The art is communication and the greater value the art form is relating to, the higher quality it has.Because what is more valuable than the objective representation of lesser limiting.You can use it and get to the knowledge and of course ameliorate your life and lives of other beings.That is precisely what Dunbar did. He went over the limit (the border)closer to freedom (the plains).The experience of higher value, better life was obvious to him. But we can't be free. We can only get so close as our potentials permit. Unfortunately, life is war, which we will lose, but we can decide how long and of what quality it will be.So Dunbar lived it to the fullest possible, but he was not narrow.Every being is fragile and because he knew it, he helped his friends (the warning about the arrival of the army and his escape in other direction from that of the Indians)as they helped him (the rescue from the army).In this way the Indians too could live it the best possible.The gratitude was expressed especially beautiful by the legendary scream from the cliff by Wind In His Hair.This is the reason why Dances With Wolves will be watched by many future generations.Similar can be said for The Shawshank Redemption and Papillon.

reviews.review_title: This is a beautiful movie that tells a worthwhile story that makes the 3 hours run time bearable.
reviews.content: Dances with Wolves (1990) is a movie I recently rewatched on Tubi. The storyline follows a Civil War soldier who get stationed to single handedly maintain a post on the edge of Indian territories in the Midwest. As he comes to understand their ways he quickly sees the mistakes of the white man. When military forces check on him and receive pushback for their actions, he may have to choose one side or the other. This movie stars and is directed by Kevin Costner (The Postman) and also stars Mary McDonnell (Donnie Darko), Graham Greene (The Green Mile) and Larry Joshua (Cradle 2 the Grave). The settings and cinematography are a absolutely stunning. The circumstances are also fascinating as are how the characters face them and interact as they mature and evolve. It's impossible not to appreciate Costner's performance and his approach to the circumstances and how he depicts the events from this era, even if the story is fiction. This is a beautiful movie that tells a worthwhile story that makes the 3 hours run time bearable. I strongly recommend seeing this and would score it a 10/10.

I understand that criticism of Kevin Costner's epic is that it takes a simplistic look at the Old West. I don't think that does "Dances with Wolves" justice. Even though much of the movie did have a similar plot to "Little Big Man", it was still a fine piece of work. Having the Lakota speak their own language gave the movie an extra feeling of realism. One could say that Costner's character started to live authentically only after he befriended the Lakota.We could be cynical and say that the movie features a white savior - and also note that Costner's next directorial effort was "The Postman" - but "Dances with Wolves" is still a movie that people should see. Like "McCabe and Mrs. Miller", it refutes the idealized image of the Old West that audiences saw in John Wayne movies. It shows the true history of the United States. I don't know if I would call it the best movie of 1990 (a year that also gave us "Goodfellas" and "Misery"), but it's still up there. It's good to know that in the 25 years since the movie's release (to the month), people have taken a more serious look at our treatment of the indigenous peoples, to the point where some cities no longer celebrate Columbus Day.I recommend the movie.

reviews.review_title: The most beautiful film ever made
reviews.content: There is no question that is the most beautiful and arguably the best film ever made. Ever. Not in the year it was made, not in the decade or even the century, but ever. Everything in the film is perfect. Every scene captured with immense attention to detail and visually appealing to even the most somber viewer. I had the pleasure of viewing the 4 hour version which felt in no way too long or dragged. Every scene with such emotion and passion, such relatibility, such understanding of Native Indian and white settlement culture, and such realism, showcasing not only gory battles, but genuine relationships forged in real time. It is literally a story like no other.The cinematography is jaw dropping. Best cinematography in a film in my opinion. The frontier. The landscapes. The beauty that no longer exists. As Dunbar himself said he wanted to see the frontier before the white settlement. And he saw it! Saw it through the eyes of Kevin Kostner in his masterpiece achievement.Kevin Kostner really should have won the Oscar for his Acting. I mean the film won 7 Oscars maybe the Academy thought it should not get greedy, but the fact is Kevin Kostner played the role of a lifetime. He transformed into Lieutenant Dunbar. Even though some scenes are clearly 'Hollywood' you forgive it because the film is perfect. It is flawless in everyway. You can watch this film 1000 times over and you couldn't find a single fault in it. It's my favourite movie of all time.

reviews.review_title: Ouch Standing with a Fist for Almost 4 hours?
reviews.content: I used to like Dances With Wolves so much as a child, that I wanted to change my rating scale and give this the first six stars out of five. Yeah, I was a kid.I watched it then, in the early nineties, maybe a half-dozen times. Then stopped and moved on. Even when the (nearly) four hour version came out, I avoided it to savor the experience I had for a special time.Sixteen years later, the Bluray was given to me for my birthday – my only request – and finally, I watched the 3 hour 58 minute version. Reaction?Well, I still love it. It's a beautiful, adventurous, wonderfully written and excellently acted epic. But, I'll hold off on the 6/5 star rating. Which would be hard to explain anyways.Some call this overrated, that it shouldn't have won the Best Picture Oscar and way too preachy. I disagree on all aspects. It's an epic yet small and intimate film – that's not something just about any filmmaker can do. It's very deserving of the Best Picture Oscar – sorry, Goodfellas – and besides, it fits with their love affair with epics. And watching this time, I paid close attention to see if I was too preached at. I didn't feel so. These are facts: Greed came over Americans – shocker – and we devastated these lands and more importantly, these people. (They got their revenge and my money when I gave up probably a year's salary at the Indian Casino over a period of a few years) Not once did I felt talked down to, or at school. If anything, I wanted to get educated on these wonderful people: the Sioux.Anyways, if you haven't seen this by now, John Dunbar (Kevin Costner) fears he'll lose his leg in the Civil War and when his suicide attempt fails, he requests to be stationed in what he thinks is Nowhere, USA. Only, he befriends and is adopted into the Sioux tribe and takes allegiance to them over his own "white people."Wowwhat is almost 4 hours I summed up in a few seconds. Believe me, there's so much more to the plot.The movie is gorgeous – it has both some of the best cinematography I've seen and one of the best scores I've heard. The love John does have for Stands with a Fist (Mary McDonnell) is genuine and fun to watch. And the camaraderie within the group, the peaceful and playfulness of the members and productive and loyal stands makes you feel as you're with them as well over the course of the movie.Highly recommendedalthough, just stick with the 3-hour theatre version. I found the changes (additions) in this one-time viewing, even after 16 years of Dances silence. And the deleted now inserted scenes didn't add much.

reviews.review_title: The Trail of a True Human Being beautifully displayed
reviews.content: With a strong cast, memorable costuming, and beautifully shot sequences, the viewer is veritably taken back in time to the lost world of the frontier. Cross-cultural empathy leads John Dunbar down "the Trail of a True Human Being" as he comes to admire a lifestyle that is about harmony, not profit or politics.

A multi-Oscar winning film starring Kevin Costner as Lt. John Dunbar, who accidentally leads Union troops to a victory during the Civil War. While in the western frontier, he meets a wolf and a Native American tribe. There he befriends the Indians, learns their way of life and falls in love with a woman within the tribe. What results is an interesting story of friendship, culture, adventure and romance. At four hours long, there is plenty of room for this movie's plot to lose steam and drag on for several minutes; however, I've found this film to be somewhat captivating, from what I remember. This film didn't need to rely on hardcore action, over-the-top comedy or crude humor and tear-jerking love relationships to make the plot entertaining; instead, (politics aside) it relied on the beauty of the Native American setting, their culture and how Dunbar assimilates into his new life, his romance on the side with Mary McDonnell's character and the adventures that awaits him in making the story interesting. A pretty good movie, overall.

Date: 2 June, 2012 -First Time Watch- Dances with Wolves is considered a masterpiece, something you'll never grow tired of watching. I grew tired of watching it within the first hour and a half, which is bad since it's over a three hour movie. It seemed like it would never get going and was way too long! The ending was sad and left me feeling like it wasn't worth watching. I also didn't like how most of the Indians were portrayed. They seemed blood thirsty and most of their decisions were unjust. Just an average movie and not worth the three hours you have to watch. Believe me, there are movies that are just as long Dances with Wolves and ten times better.5/10

reviews.review_title: Hollywood cliché and overrated acting, but still entertaining.
reviews.content:
As several viewers already have pointed out, Kevin Costner is not a great actor. He's doing all right, had the perfect looks for his time, and in Dances With Wolves he reached his peak, also as a director and producer. Even more overrated when it comes to acting and credibilty is his female opponent Mary McDonnell. Not only is she basically overacting but her appearance makes it even less credible. Why does her hairstyle have to be absolutely 1990, also even hooker-just got out of bed-and dragged thru the dirt-style? Her character is supposed to have lived with Lakotas for some two decades, and she still hasn't been told to comb and groom her hair like all the other women in the band, not even when she's getting married. It's just silly and does not go well along with the otherwise well studied original clothing and effects among the Lakota characters. This is a big turn down about the film as a total.
The plot is very much a Hollywood cliché, with good fighting evil, and as always the Pawnees are the bad indians. What was genuin and new in 1990, at least in such a big production, was that the audience got quite a good Insight into native culture and even more important, that they spoke their own language. Most of all it's the same old love story, with Euro-American hero saves and falls for captured Euro-American heroine. Nothing New, but told in an entertaining fashion and with brilliant cinematography.

reviews.content:
I have always been so excited about watching this film, and maan the 4 houres were never a waste. I mean there are some goofs here and there,

reviews.review_title: Finding your way into the hearts of Indians without actually trying but just by being there
reviews.content: This is one of the great masterpieces of American film. Everything in it is perfect, the wonderful cinematography, the carefully chosen actors, the splendid music by John Barry, the overwhelming script of the story going constantly to extremes of beauty, harmony and dashing elegance to heart-rending tragedy and sorrow. It is a tragedy, but it is filled with moments of supreme harmony and tenderness, in the development of the friendship between the lone soldier beyond the last frontier and his Sioux neighbours, a friendship and relationship that outlasts the film. The focus point of the film is actually a lone wolf, which must raise universal sympathy although he makes not a sound, but his acting is almost more impressive than anyone else's, being something of a symbol for the entire film. The film takes an entire evening, so you will hesitate to watch it again, but sooner or later you will.

reviews.review_title: Walden of the West - Dances With Wolves
reviews.content: This is Kevin Costner's greatest success as both an actor and director. The film won 7 well-deserved Academy Awards. Best Film, Best Director for Costner, Best Music for Barry (even better than Goldfinger, Best Cinematography (some breathtaking sequences), Best Screenplay by Blake, and Best Supporting Actor and Actress roles, McConnell is outstanding as naturalized citizen of the Sioux Nation. This was the ultimate good-guys/bad guys Western. The Indians are clearly the good guys and the US Cav is clearly the bad guys. Of course, things were not that clearly black and white (or red and white if you prefer). There were good and bad people on in both nations. However, since Hollywood has framed Indians as the bad guys for several decades, it is necessary to put a little weight on the other side of the scale. A great film.

reviews.review_title: I wanted to see this for a long time, BUT! pretty bad
reviews.content: The only reason I would give this movie a 2 is because of the great cinematography, And I love and do cinematography for college myself. But for what was it worth? The story is very subtle slow and frankly boring as hell. I love movies involving history, their my favorites! And I especially love westerns or most stuff involving indians. Lonesome Dove, Bury my Heart at Wounded Knee, Jeremiah Johnson Etc. I wanted to see this for along time coming but wow I was disappointed. I'm not particularly a fan of Costner but I think he does a fine good in some movies (Untouchables). His narration of the story is mono-toned (never let Costner do narration Obviously) so bland and bluh (boring). The story is slow and not interesting through out, it barely develops. reviews.review_title: A Great View of a Time Now Gone
reviews.content: The opening scene in this film is gut wrenching. Men who have suffered on the Civil War battlefield, and having their limbs chopped off to save their lives (maybe). Kevin Costner's Dunbar is one of these and he takes off at the risk of his life before they can do this. In the process, he becomes a hero for risking his life in a charge (pretty much an accident because of random luck). He is given an opportunity to choose his next assignment and ends up on the central plains. He survives, living off what is there, and eventually meets up with Lakota tribesmen. What this movie tells us is the fact that the West is going to be gone; the Native Americans are going to be shoved aside. He is integrated into the tribe and finds there a white woman who was taken in when her parents died. He "becomes" a tribe member. This is a story about human beings and their spirit and gets away from the clichés of the Western movie. Costner is fantastic in his role.

reviews.review_title: A compelling human drama and some passionate filmmaking by Kevin Costner..
reviews.content:
Dances With Wolves (1990) :
Brief Review -A compelling human drama and some passionate filmmaking by Kevin Costner. Dances With Wolves is based in the novel of the same name which tells a story of white man (soldier) who goes to his military post but end up having friendship and bonding with tribal Indian group. The film is all about human bonding which cannot be stopped by any difficulties such as language, religion, cast and class. The soldier feels comfortable while living in a small village with tribals and they are ready to fight mightier enemy for him. This says so much about thier great friendship. I called it a passionate filmmaking because the film needed lot of research and dedication if it had to be made as a quality film. I couldn't see a single thing compromised or reduced for the sake of feature film-making. Rather, the film is an uncompromised classic. The locations, art direction, background score, costumes, language, accent and even the characterisation of all the actors all these things are uncompromised and outstanding. Look at Mary McDonnell's non glamourous avtar, how convincing she looks. Which actress would have accepted such a dull looking role? Kevin Costner does an incredible job as an Actor, producer and director of the film. He deserves all the credit for huge critical and commercial success of this film. I happened to catch the 236 minutes version of the film whereas original runtime is of 181 minutes but still I didn't find it boring. May be i got to watch more scenes and that's why it connected me more to the characters of the film. Dances With Wolves deserved all those 7 Oscars but i feel sad for Kevin that he didn't win Best Actor award. He deserved it for this astonishing performances. This is without any doubt The Best Film and Best Performance of his career. A Classic and a Must Watch !RATING - 8/10*By - #samthebestest

The ones that survived lived through dysentery, amputation, blood poisoning, disease, or death. In reality he probably would have been made a bureaucrat with a cushy job in the Johnson administration. But no, our pretty boy wants to go west because he is too pure to live in nineteenth century white world. He may be pure but he is still a stupid white guy who doesn't yet know yet how wonderful other races are. Follow closely.Instead, cut to the chase. Evil white world follows him out west and you know the rest. On the way Dances meets a beautiful Hollywood bimbo. In a politically correct western no Hollywood pretty boy (who saved the Union) is going to marry no toothless Indian woman even though (wink wink) Indian women are superior to white women. You see the hierarchy in Hollywood is this: Hollywood bimbo is the center of the universe, the buffalo are next. Then come the Indians who are all equally good - no judgement here. Then comes white women then the rabid dog, then the white male. And That's Hollywood. The cinematography was nice. reviews.review_title: this was my favorite movie for a long time
reviews.content: Possible Spoilers!Dances With Wolves was my favorite movie for a long time and still is one of the best movies I've ever seen. I saw it for the first time at the movies,in 1990.At that moment I was 11 years old and it made a huge impression on me,because this was the first "mature" movie I had ever seen in the cinema,maybe together with Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade.I remember that I thought that the scene in which Timmons,the dirty mexican,gets butchered by Pawnee Indians was very gruesome and it still is,as a matter a fact.My favorite scene was and still is the scene with the Buffalo's,a beautifully made scene. And then the surroundings,the beautiful country in which the Indians lived freely until the white men showed up.The movie shows the Indian life from the Sioux point of view,which makes the Pawnee bad guys.But still,the real evil men in the movie are the white men and rightly so.Costner(his best role in his career together with "the Untouchables") plays an American soldier called John Dunbar who wants to live in the Indian land peacefully.He meets with the Sioux Indians and starts to become an Indian,especially after he gets named Dances With Wolves(Sioux see him fool around with a wolf) and marries an Indian/white woman. Costner,who also directs the movie,gives the white soldiers their true face as brutal killers.The scene that gives the best image of that is when the soldiers kill Costner's horse and shoot on the wolf.In the end the white soldiers get killed by the Sioux Indians and that makes the viewer happy.The real end of the movie is rather sad,though.Costner leaves the Sioux with his wife and as we see them leave the camera goes away from the two and a text shows us that almost all the Indian tribes get killed or captured by the white soldiers.The version that I saw at the cinema was 3 hours long,but I've got a version of 4 hours on video that is as good as the 3 hour version. A must see for everybody we wants to see the story from the opposite side of John Wayne,the Indians. 10/10

With no men to command (they have disappeared before he arrives) he first makes contact with, then befriends the plains Indians.Yet so called civilised man is not that far away and that will bring tragic results.Everything that is wrong with Costner movies is right here, and you can't help to leave this movie a little bit moved from this journey into a another world that has been destroyed by our own.

reviews.review_title: Possibly the last good western worth watching.

It was a bucolic chant to the nature, even the human nature, and to the Indians' traditional way of living (not always understood). This film doesn't try to transform points of view (like most 1990s movies tried to do later), but only tries to give each one's position (though I still consider that many white men of the US army aren't correctly depicted). reviews.review_title: The Director's Cut is a great film
reviews.content: I didn't watch the theatrical version upon release, I was too young. I'd heard conflicting reviews that it was a) great and b) self indulgent and sluggish.I rented the Director's Cut on DVD not expecting much. After 20 minutes I nearly switched it off - I thought it WAS very self indulgent, over slow and a huge ego trip for Kevin Costner. But I stayed on and about an hour in it suddenly took off and breathed a life (probably around the time the Costner character empties a lake of corpses). I realised that it took time to get into because the world it conveyed was merely being set up. Once into the thrust of the story I was emotionally involved and very impressed with the direction, locations and music. There are some moments of genuine tragedy and real bonding between the Costner character and the Indians. It isn't a documentary about the period, but it does give you a glimpse into that bleak time in American history.Once the film ended I felt that I'd seen a truly epic piece of work. I couldn't imagine watching the theatrical version - goodness knows how you can take an hour off the movie (thank God for DVD). I watched it on a massive projected screen, and in DTS - so it was a truly cinematic experience.Costner deserved his Oscars, but I think it was a one-hit wonder for him. I usually can't stand him but in this instance I take my hat off to you, sir.

This must be one of the most overrated movies from the 90's. I just can't understand why this movie got so many Oscars, and was so popular on cinema. The movie was made in a prof. way, but the whole thing falls a part when it's so extremely dull. This movie had been dull even if it had lasted only 90 minutes. And the facts that it's least 3 hours does not make it any better. No nerve in this one. ----------(4 out of 10  from me)

reviews.review_title: Probably the best "going native" film to date
reviews.content: A film that manages to combine deep and meaningful character study with exotic locations and the feel of an adventure. Dances with Wolves is one of those rare films where time becomes transcendent and you're no longer able to perceive the usual story arcs or acts. They're there and the film has a rock-solid foundation, but you're still surprised when something new happens, because the film has managed to lull you into its world, its prolonged seasons. This is a movie that is able to portray the passage of time properly. It's a film in which events don't take place over a weekend or even a month. Rather whole years just glide by. Or perhaps just months, it's impossible to say for sure, but it feels like years, a sizable chunk of a whole life.And what a life that is and what a person living it. Lieutenant Dunbar - masterfully played by Kevin Costner - is a war hero given a dead end assignment according to his wishes, so that he can resign there to die a slow death. Thus the film starts as a macabre portrayal of a man giving up, but unable to just lay down. And it never becomes clear whether he manages to shake that initial attitude towards life. The events slowly give him more reasons to live, but Costner always plays him slightly detached, like he's always just one step away from giving up again. It's an amazing story and one that requires space to flourish. Quite many films since this one have managed to recreate the same "going native" storyline, which of course existed before this film though never quite like this, but none of them have seemed to realize that the film needs to dedicate most of its running time to the actual "going". Because that's the story, that's the attraction. The action scenes and battles have their place, but the magic is in the community, in the bonds that slowly grow between the main character and the natives.It's very hard to find any flaws in this film. Its slow pace is not for everyone, especially in the extended cut, but I personally never complained or even noticed the hours. It's a captivating film from start to finish and every minute is well spent, be it a minute of quiet landscapes rolling by or a minute of blazing battle. There are things which warrant this film to be revered as 'beautiful' at times, but there also exists a shameless show of grandstanding by Kevin Costner.What purpose did it serve for him to sacrifice his life at the beginning of the film by riding his horse into enemy fire with his arms out-stretched as if he's Jesus on the Cross, followed by the praise of the army commander.... "We got an officer who's worth something lying here". No doubt Costner did that to win the emotional adulation of his audience. He himself narrates that the result of this "elevated me to the status of a living hero".Still later, when setting up his post all alone, he writes in his journal how he "is not the whole affair".... an attempt at being noble, but that appears to be exactly how Costner wants others to see him -- and I mean Costner the actor, not Dunbar the soldier. And again during his stay with the Sioux, he mentions in his droll narrative how the people see him as a "celebrity". And still much later he states how the soldiers "hate me like no other".... there's that tin-plated nobility again. The hate for him has to be 'special', more than the hate for anyone else.And speaking of nobility, how noble - or even realistic - was it for this seemingly dedicated soldier to abandon his post and become an Indian? That is rather hard to believe, as is Costner forgetting all about his rifles and journal at his post, even though he knows that white men could show up at any time. This development only extended the film for another half-hour, which leads to one of the technical errors: the film's running time is severely too long. These are the things which prove that Costner was preoccupied with blowing his own horn, and that's a shame. His Personal Ulterior Motives belittle an otherwise well-made film.

"Dances with Wolves" is marked as a western, but it is far from a typical entry into the genre. The film's focus isn't on gunslingers, but rather Lieutenant Dunbar, an officer in the Union army during the American Civil War and his relationship with the Sioux tribe. The film has a superb Civil War scene to introduce the disillusioned officer. Following this is a memorable performance from Maury Chaykin, who sends the lieutenant on his mission to the frontier.Slowly Lieutenant Dunbar learns about the Sioux tribe and integrates himself into it. This leads to several episodes that include such things as breaking the language barrier and making war on the Pawnee. I liked the fact that the Sioux spoke in Lakota, albeit a simplified version. These episodes are portrayed with high caliber cinematography and the aid of an excellent score by John Barry. The film can be slow-paced at times, but is interesting overall. Kevin Costner is decent as Lieutenant Dunbar and the supporting cast gives excellent performances.The theatrical cut is a good one, but I enjoyed the additions in the extended cut. The additions are appropriate and aid in characterization. "Dance with Wolves" is a key film dealing with Native American culture.

Most films benefit from a bit of objective cutting in the editing room, but there are some that suffer from shorter running times. They are few and far between. The director's edition of Dances With Wolves, clocking in at almost 4 hours and just released as a Special Edition DVD by MGM, is a shining example of such a film.I'm convinced that Kevin Costner's sole reason for ever working in Hollywood was to make Dances With Wolves. Everything he did before or has done since is irrelevant. It's one of those transcendent experiences that is greater than the sum of it's parts. All of the necessary ingredients were in the right place at the right time for this movie, and magic happened. Like the extended edition of Peter Jackson's The Fellowship of the Ring, this version of Wolves is what should have been in the first place, test audiences and people with short attention spans be damned. Everything here is pitch perfect, with the additional character development and plotting bringing a sense of grace and fullness to the story that was previously missing. A film with conviction and heart containing enough wonderful performances to decorate a Christmas tree. A must have.

POSSIBLE SPOILERS???I'm not a fan of any of the Kevin Costner movies out there, except for this one. No, I'm not here to bash him. I am just saying that trying to top the scope and beauty of DANCES WITH WOLVES with over-budgeted stuff like WATERWORLD is impossible. This is the one great work that he can be proud of for eternity.Based on a book by Michael Blake, DANCES WITH WOLVES is a story of a Union Soldier during the Civil War who takes an assignment in the west, far out into the prairie and "Indian" country. He finds the fort deserted and has no idea what's happened to the other soldiers who lived there. They might have been kidnapped or murdered or both by the fearsome "Injuns" who reside in the country, or they might simply have left their belongings and trudged out into the prairie during a freezing blizzard and froze to death. Lt. Dunbar (Costner) feels lonely and isolated, except for his horse and a friendly wolf who comes to visit now and then. But the beauty of the prairie is enough for him to feel content even without human company. For a while anyway. He meets several members of the Sioux village several miles away and slowly comes to trust, admire and befriend them. He realizes that white people have labeled "Indians" as savages, heathens and bloodthirsty murderers, and that the people are exactly the opposite of that. In time, Dunbar is re-named "Dances With Wolves" by the Sioux people, and he falls in love with an adopted Sioux of white ancestry called "Stands With A Fist" (Mary McDonnell), whose parents were killed by members of the Pawnee, when she was no older than five or six. Very much like the child SWAF was, Dances With Wolves is adopted as a member of the family of Sioux and his life takes on meaning for the first time he can remember.The People are worried and hope that Dances With Wolves will answer their many questions. The whites began to emerge in the 17th century, after the Spanish Conquistadors had been in and out of the land. The whites, unlike the other groups, seem intent on staying. The People are being driven further and further west, and their buffalo, the staple of their lives, are being slaughtered in such huge numbers that they are on the verge of extinction. In the early part of the 1800s, buffalo hunts were commonplace and successful. In the 1860s, buffalo were already threatened with extinction. Times were changing so fast that the People had no idea what would become of them. This film illustrates the mindset of the Sioux, and other Native American tribes, like no other film in existence. There are many memorable cinematographic scenes: The great buffalo hunt, the battle with the Pawnee warriors, the battle with the Union Soldiers, etc. But the best part of this picture is the human element, the struggle to communicate, the realization that a bunch of people that are thought of as "ignorant" or "animal" are actually very warm, compassionate, human, the understanding that even though someone is "white", it doesn't make him hateful or "dirty" or soul-less. Prejudices on both sides are resolved.
A great story, as fresh and insightful as it was fourteen years ago. Wow has it been that long???

Lt. John Dunbar is dubbed a hero after he accidentally leads Union troops to a victory during the Civil War.He requests a position on the western frontier, but finds it deserted. He soon finds out he is not alone, but meets a wolf he dubs "Two-socks" and a curious Indian tribe.Dunbar quickly makes friends with the tribe, and discovers a white woman who was raised by the Indians.He gradually earns the respect of these native people, and sheds his white-man's ways....It has taken me almost twenty years to pluck up the courage to watch this movie. it had many mixed reviews, and a three hour long western just didn't appeal to me, despite enjoying Wyatt Earp.How stupid have i been, ignoring this classic film for so many years. Costners acting may not be the best in the world, but the man knows how to direct a beautiful setting and connotations, and how to tell a story.For the majority of the first and second act, we are almost in castaway territory with Costner, one man trying to rebuild something, maybe himself, but it's so intimate and well shot, you cannot help but be compelled by every scene that is on screen.His relationship with the Siousx tribe is beautiful and very unpredictable, you would expect them to hate him, but he is such a placid character after cheating death, you cannot help but like the man.everything about this film oozes class, from the child like encounters with two socks, to the exhilarating buffalo stampede.A fine piece of cinema,,

I avoided seeing this movie for quite a long time as I generally don't like straight dramas, but was surprised when I finally did see it at how much I enjoyed it. The movie is about a civil war soldier, John Dunbar (Kevin Costner), sent to an outpost in the western frontier. There he encounters an Indian tribe camped a short distance from his outpost. He gradually becomes acquainted with the members of the tribe and, in time, becomes friends with the tribe. What makes this movie so good is being able to see and feel sympathetic to how the indians' land was more or less taken from them by the white man. It was done very cleverly by showing how John Dunbar went from the attitude most people have ( the indians were savages ) to understanding their culture and coming to appreciate it and understanding they were only protecting their way of life and territory. Most of the really good movies, like this one, will have you come away with an altered point of view or, at least, make you look at something in a way you haven't before.

This post refers to the extended DVD special edition of DANCES WITH WOLVES. Rarely does a film improve with the addition of 50+ minutes of film, certainly not a multiple Oscar winner.  DANCES is that rare beast.  A fine film at its original theatrical running time; it is a true masterwork in its extended DVD presentation.  I'd viewed the film but once in its original theatrical run in 1990.  I was impressed by Mr. Costner's directorial debut, though I felt much of the same material about the Caucasian race's shameful treatment of Native Americans had been stated as eloquently in LITTLE BIG MAN.  Seeing the 4-hour cut of DANCES renders my initial reaction invalid. I recently viewed LITTLE BIG MAN for the first time in 15 years, and then bought my copy of the extended DANCES.  Comparing the two works is like saying THE LONGEST DAY covers the same turf as SAVING PRIVATE RYAN.  They may cover the same history but they are different poems in different languages.  Get the new DANCES extended edition and treasure it as one of THE great American films.

I loved 'Dances with Wolves' when I was younger, but when I went back to watch it again recently, I turned it off half way through. First of all the movie is racist toward whites. Kevin Costner seems like the only white man who has sympathy for American Indians. Costner depicts whites as sloppy, drunk, and incompetent, while depicting the Native Americans as pure, noble, and peaceful. The settlers who came from Europe did horrible things to the American Indians, but that does not mean the American Indians were all pure at heart and the white man was all evil. The war and genocide that occurred between the two groups is what almost always happens when two people of different race, religion, and ethnic groups conflict with each other. Costner was paying respect to the Native Americans and that was a good thing that he did. The American Indians deserve it up to a point. But don't go around thinking they were not deeply flawed and did not have darker side like other human beings.

"Of all the trails in life that one can take," says the Sioux medicine man Kicking Bird "the one that matters most is the one of the true, good-hearted human being." Civil War soldier John Dunbar is on this trail. Injured in battle and facing a leg amputation and questionable prospects for survival, Dunbar commits a nearly suicidal act of bravery that inspires his fellow soldiers to charge and overrun enemy lines. Rewarded with the best health care, a promotion to the rank of lieutenant, and his choice of posts, Dunbar travels to the edge of the western frontier. Here he comes in contact with the Sioux nation and a thrilling and vibrant landscape brimming with fascinating wildlife. Dunbar discovers who he really is and even falls in love, but his fellow soldiers are not in the mood to celebrate his success.Dances with Wolves won seven Oscars including for best picture, and if nominated for best bromance it would have won that too. No "I love you man" moment can top that of the brash warrior Wind in his Hair shouting from the cliffside "do you see that I am your friend?! Can you see I will always be your friend?!" Tell me you did not have tears in your eyes.Elaborate and epic, Dances with Wolves made a deep impression on me when I first saw it as a senior in college. At the time it was refreshing and eye-opening to see the film's alternative takes on the plights of Native Americans, women and soldiers during the western frontier era. While these sympathetic takes have not quite withstood the test of time, at least it was progress. Kevin Costner (Dunbar) and Mary McDonnell are quite good, but the performances of Graham Greene (Kicking Bird) and Rodney Grant (Wind in his Hair) really stand out. The four-hour soap opera format is much more bearable with the alluring images of the majestic Grand Tetons, big sky country, and the eerie Badlands, combined with a catchy and emotional score. "Good men" said Hawthorne "ever interpret themselves too meanly." Just do not interpret your bro too meanly.

reviews.review_title: Its Indian name is Does Not Show Age
reviews.content: This arguably did not need a remake(and if you don't see how Avatar can be called another version of this, you must not have seen them both, or remember them), being a mere 20 years old, but one can hope that Cameron's film will reach the new generation, many members of which would not even consider putting this on. It is epic and on a grand scale, helped by the immensely high production values and the amazing score. The visuals are stunning, with magnificent cinematography and editing, aside from those few and far between shots that are too close. This is largely credible, if admittedly black and white, and very clearly siding with the Natives, to the point where they almost couldn't allow any Americans to have attractive features. The battle sequences are masterfully done. This delves into the society and culture nicely. The narration is used well. Every acting performance is impressive, and Costner isn't the only one to shine. It is a credit to this that 25% of the dialog is not in English. There is great humor, and this is fun and exciting at times, not only serious. The regular DVD contains four trailers, one of them for this. I recommend this to anyone mature enough to handle the subject matter, that can be intense. A smart Western that still holds up. 8/10

reviews.review_title: A three-plus hour postcard for revisionist history
reviews.content: This is a perfect example of the power movies have to convey ideas, experiences and history, and of how that power can be used to rewrite history.  Not since Birth of a Nation has a film worn its racism so blatantly.  Aside from the plodding pacing, simplistic dialogue and wooden performance of Costner, the film is rife with historical innaccuracies and half-truths.  Who would know from watching this "historical" film that the Lakota Sioux were ruthless, vicious warriors who were not above scalping, mutilating and raping their victims?  Who would know that the Pawnee actually had a reason to attack the Lakota, because they  had been forced off their own land?  It is exactly this sort of half-baked revisionist history that does an injustice to the very people the film tries to ennoble. Costner and Blake must not think much of their audience to portray every soldier as a buffoon and/or coward, and to make the "bad" Indians noticeably darker-skinned than the "good Indians?  This film should have come with a disclaimer stating that it is a work of fiction, because from reading and hearing people's responses to it, I am not sure the average viewer is smart enough to distinguish a well done movie from a piece of feel-good PC ego-stroking.
