Kevin Costner appears in his trademark character in this movie, and I was very surprised to know that he was not awarded an oscar for acting. Anyway , the praise he got was beyond oscar circle.

After leading a team to victory in the American Civil War era, Lietenant John Dunbar requests to be posted on the Frontier. Finding it deserted he discovers that he isn't alone. The land is mostly inhabited by Indians and wolves amoung other animals. After a while, John makes friends with the tribe and becomes one of them. But with his comrades marching onto their land, Dunbar must figure out how to protect the indians who have become his tribe.An Excellent film of beauty and adventure that ignites the human spirit. A bit long yes, but you don't seem to care while watching it. Costner's film is amazing and should be viewed by everyone. Too bad that Costner's other films weren't as good as this one.****/****

Sorry, but the overwhelming dullness, the absolute monotone of Costner's every line, ruins this film and in my mind makes it totally unwatchable. I'm aware it's apparently setting the record straight about Native Americans, at long last, but this man's acting ability defies explanation.

reviews.review_title: An impressive directorial debut from Costner
reviews.content:
Kevin Costner's 1990 Dances with Wolves was notable for being the first Western since Cimarron in 1930 to win the Academy Award for Best Picture. But it isn't a typical Western, if there can be said to be such a thing. A sprawling epic (nearly four hours long, if you watch the Special Edition), it charts the growing relationship between US Army Lieutenant John Dunbar and the Lakota tribe he finds himself living next to, and the emphasis is very much on Dunbar starting to understand the Sioux rather than the clichéd "Cowboys and Indians" approach people often vaguely recall (usually incorrectly) from Westerns of the past.
Dances with Wolves is based on the novel of the same name by Costner's friend Michael Blake, which he in turn based on a spec-script he previously wrote. The story is character driven: Dunbar chooses a posting to the Western Frontier so that he can see it before he disappears, and is left isolated at an otherwise unmanned fort by the deaths of the only two people who know where he is. Lengthy scenes show him making the fort habitable before he even makes contact with the Lakota, and when he finally does so their initial encounters are characterised by mutual suspicion. Gradually, he starts to befriend them, eventually joining them on buffalo hunts and starting to learn their language, with some help from Stands with a Fist, a white woman who was adopted by the child when she was a little girl and can still just about remember how to speak English.
All of this takes about three quarters of the film. Surprisingly however, it doesn't drag. Costner is one of the most boring actors ever to achieve Hollywood success, as his tedious monotone in the occasional voice-over painfully demonstrates, but he proves well cast as the thoughtful Dunbar. The Lakota are uniformly well written, with the most obvious examples being Kicking Bird, Wind In His Hair and Chief Ten Bears. Stands with a Fist also works well, starting out as a grieving widow who is terrified that Dunbar will try and take her back to the white people and ending up as Dunbar's doting wife. Graham Greene, Rodney A. Grant and Floyd Red Crow Westerman are utterly naturalistic as their characters, as is Mary McDonnell who is quietly impressive as Stands with a Fist. The characterisation only falls down at two points: Maury Chaykin gives a brief but memorable performance as the insane Major Fambrough, but the character is an absurdity. Later, the US army soldiers who capture Dunbar are portrayed as one-dimensional sadistic hicks; this is clearly intended to make it all the more satisfying when they get killed during the tribe's rescue of Dunbar but feels lazy. However, neither of these shortcomings is enough to derail the film.
It helps that Costner the director is more impressive than Costner the actor. He assembles all of the right ingredients, from the costumes and props to John Barry's sweeping soundtrack, and he handles the character moments and the action sequences equally adeptly. The decision to film many of the scenes in Lakota with subtitles is laudable, even if the accuracy has been questioned. Dean Semler's cinematography makes full use of the South Dakota location filming, with long and wide-angle shots that show off the frontier landscape wonderfully. He also provides some dynamic camerawork for the many action sequences: the battle with the Pawnee is particularly impressive. The buffalo hunt, with its filming of a herd of wild buffalo (and the odd tame one courtesy of Neil Young) is a breathtaking technical achievement.
Dances with Wolves deserves the epithet epic; it's also a beautiful, elegant and very well made film. By the end of the lengthy running time, the audience has to got to know the characters well enough that the poignant ending, which sees Dunbar and Stands with a Fist leaving the tribe to protect it from the US Army, feels genuinely sad, and the historical note about the Sioux submitting to white American rule thirteen years later feels like every inch the historical injustice it was. Dances with Wolves has been credited with prompting a resurgence of interest in the Western genre in the 1990s, and it isn't hard to see why.
I like the bit when the block was shot with an arrow by the Native American whilst he was eating bacon. The man was eating bacon not the Native American to be clear

reviews.review_title: Among the best movies ever made
reviews.content: Great Epic movie. Among my favorite movies and I have seen thousands. Brilliantly directed by Kevin Costner. This movie has it all a good story, great acting, a wonderful score by John Barry, beautiful cinematography, a moral point and purpose, and enough emotions to keep interested through a long movie.The movie is about the American frontier and how the courage to learn breaks down the barriers of fear as you in your enemy discovers someone much like yourself. Its about love, courage and friendship.I highly recommend this movie to anyone, especially people who enjoy movies like "3:10 to Yuma", "Lord of the Rings", "The Last Samurai", "7 Years in Tibet" and "Troy".

In an occasional series I look back at films I have loved (to death) and muse on why with the vain hope that some of you will dust them off again and plunge right in all over again. They need to be re-watched. They're worth it.This time; Dances with Wolves, brought to us by a very wise and brilliant young actor (at that time) called Kevin Costner (you've probably heard of him!)NB: This was what turned Kevin Costner into gold dust for a few years (remember Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves). Costner was King Midas basically until his sparkly, shiny star reached its apogee with his untimely filmic demise in the utterly ridiculous and overblown (and over-budget) Waterworld. (Holds head in hands; Kevin what were you thinking!)I fell in love with Dances With Wolves in 1990 and then recently again when I tried to force my 13 and 15 year old to watch it. Their response was the inauspicious; "It's a bit boring dad," as they vacated the sofa 32 minutes in. But I contend here Calum and Adam that you're just not quite ready for it yet and don't be surprised if it cycles round again sneakily one Friday Family Film Night soon. Dances With Wolves is genius, a slim novel of 1988 vintage written by Michael Blake with his eyes on a possible screenplay prize, it was bought hook, line and sinker by Costner who yummed it up so much he starred, directed and drummed up the finance for it over the next few years. It became Costner's labour of love and at the same time he re-invented the Western form for Hollywood so they could fall in love with it again in a post-modern way with a whole lot less stubble and a whole lot more human heart.Dances With Wolves has Oscar written all over it and I fell head over in heels in love with it when I was a (still extremely naive and immature) twenty-two year old. Where to start then on this gorgeous-fest of love, hope, humanity and sheer cinematographical brilliance?Is it with Timmons the hapless mule-train driver who first takes the naive and idealistic John Dunbar (the solider fresh from the horrors of the Civil War) that Costner plays out to the Frontier, a sea of prairie where so-called civilisation hasn't reached yet? (Poor Timmons dies brutally - and brilliantly - the victim of some Pawnee Indians tracking back to their home-lands after a patrol. His scalping is so visceral we can almost hear (at an appropriate distance) the skin unzipping from the skull!)Or perhaps we should start with Kicking Bird (played by Graham Greene) the thoughtful and wise young brave who first visits the decimated Fort Sedgwick after John Dunbar first arrives.Or perhaps it is simply the vast, swaying grasslands of the mid-west, an ocean of Buffalo for mile upon mile? A landscape the sky was invented for, a landscape to put us in our mortal place.Or perhaps it's the sweeping John Barry soundtrack or incredible long, lugubrious shoots of the Dakota Badlands and the in-your-face wilderness of a country as yet untamed.At root the reason why so many of us love this film is the production values for the whole project, from cinematography through to the language coaching the Native American actors underwent so they spoke Lakota convincingly. Everything on this movie is sumptuous (except perhaps the budget, note to self Mr Costner) and it is strong and powerful theme of the story, revisited endlessly in mini-echoes throughout its three hour duration, that brings home such a resounding narrative success. Dances With Wolves works because the story is simple and straight as a Pawnee arrow and it strikes right to our hearts. It is about what we truly are, as individuals and as a species. It is about heart and head, family, connections and the wisdom of living together with tolerance and in harmony with our world. It is about the wind in our hair and the sun on our backs, it is about simply being as opposed to being something.The story is a back-to-nature tale of John Dunbar's gradual re-education about the so-called Savages the great White Man is expunging from America's heartland. It is an Alice Through The Looking Glass narrative where Dunbar very soon realizes, whilst amongst the metaphorical wolves of the title, it is his own kind, White Man, who are the savages. The story of this film was totally ripped off in Avatar, same idea, just with eleven foot smurf aliens and some eye-popping CGI. What Dances With Wolves has in spades which its newer and bluer rip off didn't (and I totally loved Avatar too) is that it helped reinforce a revisionist tack on the Great American West, actually much more like genocide than a heap of swaggering John Wayne gunslingers ever let on. Of course the Native American life-style is romanticized in this film, the wars between tribes, the pointless politics and the diseases and famines of a neolithic society are all glossed over, but we can forgive all that. It's ultimately an extended apology for all the Cowboy and Indians nonsense that went gone before. The Wild in West was the White Man's rapacious and violent land-grab and in Dances With Wolves we get to see that barbarism from the other end of the telescope. Not pretty or pleasant, but a truer account than most Westerns.Go on, buy it again and re-watch it. It deepens our humanity and succeeds in upsetting me deeply every single time I watch it.***** (Five Stars)

reviews.review_title: From an era in which winning Oscars meant absolutely nothing...
reviews.content: The bad: this movie is a band aid for all those who feel guilty that folks slaughtered these Indians by the MILLIONS, in the not so far past of history. THAT and that alone was the reason that this movie won so many Oscars. It made folks feel good about a brutal attack on indigenous Indians. And Kevin Cosner made it all happen...The other reason this movie won so many Oscars was because Kevin Cosner was an absolute box office magnet in the nineties. He is totally forgotten now, but back in the nineties, no matter which movie he was in, it was a guaranteed money maker at the box office.BEWARE:During the nineties all the WRONG movies won Oscars. It was really obnoxious to see that the Oscar jury was taken "seriously" back then, because they were nothing more than a stand in for the marketing department of the big Hollywood blockbusters.Not any good then, hey? Not correct. The photography and the feel good factor of this movie are still quite enjoyable to watch IF you choose the "short" version. It is an enjoyable, well made movie. Hollywood does know how to please the audiences. Yes, sir.But PLEASE dont take this story too seriously, because this movie is NOTHING ELSE but a moral guilt pleaser for the massacre of millions of Indians.Just so you know a little bit about history. And now you may start downgrading my review, because this review will (without a doubt) not be very popular...

reviews.review_title: A film that impresses in the locations and the well staged fighting sequences.
reviews.content: Epic in a humble scale, influential in it's storytelling and masterful in human scope. Dances With Wolves is a masterpiece of the 90's who mixes bold entertainment with intelligent wit, heart and characters.

reviews.review_title: A MASTERPIECE-AND MORE THAN THAT:A DEPOSIT OF SOUL
reviews.content: It's not easy at all to speak about this sublime film.The inner battle of a lonely soldier who after his own wish serves at the frontier wasn't an easy story to tell.Yet Michael Blake's script (and especially Costner's monologues- in my opinion the best in the history of cinema) made it possible.(It's hard to believe that the same person had previously written the novel on which the film was based.)Blake's deep-going screenplay is enhanced by Costner's splendid performance (he deserved the Oscar for an actor in a leading role as well) and his extraordinary direction.The other actors(especially McDonnell),the cinematography,the sound,John Barry's score were all of them perfect.On the whole, the film is a masterpiece, no, it's something more than that. Dances with Wolves is made up of human soul; what we see on the screen is nothing less than a deposit of soul.

This movie was amazing. This is probably the only movie I've ever watched that portrays Native Americans in such an intricate and beautiful way. This movie is so important and for it being made in the 90s really broke boundaries in how we perceive Native Americans. The way Dunbar interacts and becomes one with the Sioux is amazing and I love how at the end of the movie he has become family with the Sioux. The craftsmanship of this movie is spectacular also. The Natives have beautiful outfits and look real and not like a Hollywood stereotype. This movie fleshes out these characters and paints the Natives in an incredible light. Dances with Wolves is also so special in that Kevin Costner not only acts but directs. He deserves all the praise he got for this movie and I hope people continue to carry on this story for years to come.

Grandiose film of epic proportions about an American Civil War soldier who wanted to see the Frontier. Lieutenant Dunbar (Kevin Costner) ended up befriending the Sioux Indians and eventually became one of them.Costner is in fine form, both in front of and behind the camera, as is his supporting cast, including a superb Graham Greene. John Barry's score is uplifting and Dean Semler's cinematography is both awe inspiring and breath taking.The story of the Sioux Indians plight is one that needed telling, and it is told superbly in a movie that never fails to hold for three hours with its fine balance of drama, humour and love.Sunday, April 7, 1991 - Knox District Centre

I got a kick reading the negative reviews for this film because they're all based upon: 1) technical aspects;  2) the fact that the white guy ends up with the white girl;  3) dislike of Kevin Costner.  I don't like Costner but I think he made a great film.  Anyone can make a film about politics but few can capture what it's like to befriend people when you don't share their language or culture and have no help from interpretors.  I've had that experience and think this film captured it beautifully.  People are individuals first.  That's a simple message but it's powerful because it's easy to forget.  Great job.  A must see.

An awesome epic that the Academy Awards righteously awarded 7 Oscars to. Like other monumental motion pictures (Casablanca, Titanic) it sets the story against a huge backdrop (in this case, the Civil War).  After I saw this movie I wanted to buy a wolf for a pet.  Later reality kicked in and I figured that would be a little dangerous and illegal.  So I went and danced with my cat.  I honestly do not understand why so many people put this movie down.  Costner's performance was good not hideously bland and boring. Graham Greene would have won an oscar if Joe Pesci did not give a career performance in Goodfellas.  The soundtrack is so good Mozart couldn't have done it better.  My favorite scene is when Costner sees the Indian camp for the first time, simply stunning and timeless.  I still believe Costner's direction rates among the best of all time, right up there with Coppola's "Godfather" and Kazan's "On the Waterfront."  The cinematography (beauty of the movie) looks better than heaven probably does.  Costner's horse was fabulous and can outrun Black Beauty any day.  For all those history freaks that declare this movie inaccurate, hello - did you see "based on a true story" anywhere in this motion picture.  That comment is so bogus it's like putting down Star Wars because it's not a true story.  If you enjoy history so much go read a history book.  Some people say this movie is filled with Costner's conceit and greed.  That's bogus too.  You reward Clint Eastwood's Unforgiven and Mel Gibson's Braveheart when they both did the same thing (by the way I think both those movies are awesome as well).  Just because a man in Hollywood does a huge amount of work on a particular picture (Stallone did the same thing with Rocky, as well as Thornton for Sling Blade) that d oesn't mean there character has to be so humble.  I am happy Costner made himself a great character because he deserved it.  I would have done the same thing if I did all that work and so would all of the critics out there who cut this movie up.  Three thumbs up for a masterpiece.  I recommend this movie to anyone who is alive.

reviews.review_title: Marvelous picture of love and respect for traditions and culture.
reviews.content: Marvelous picture of love and respect for traditions and culture. It is a new way of presenting the violent encounter of two cultures. Kevin Costner plays a magnificent roll. It shows his talent not only as an actor but as a director.

"Dances with Wolves" is without question one of the greatest films ever made, it is a masterpiece in every sense of the word. The acting is terrific (especially Costner), the story is brilliant, the effects are great (the buffalo sequence), and the films meaning is incredibly powerful. Many people look at this film and say that it's boring or it's too long, these people don't understand the meaning of this movie or anything about great film making for that matter. I was shocked when I saw this film was not in the IMDb top 250. It should be in the top 20. The film was a power at the Oscars winning 7 awards from 11 nominations and deserved everyone. Costner probably should have won the best actor award as well but oh well. If you like historical films, epics, or just great movies I strongly recommend.

reviews.review_title: Movie is definitely NOT like watching paint dry
reviews.content: This movie is not like watching paint dry at all, as some reviewers have said. It is like watching paint that has ALREADY dried. I believe it is the slowest, most boring, overly long movie I have ever seen. Certainly the worst movie with the most undeserved Academy Awards. Even the worst old Horror/Sci Fi movies I have seen have some semblance of a redeeming feature or two but this thing has none. The scenes where an Indian and Costner are talking have to be twice as long so the language can be translated by the white girl who has lived with the Indians. Thank goodness Costner learned the language almost over night so I wouldn't have to watch many scenes like that, but after that I had to see Costners words put in subtitles like the rest which I hate. And that overly long scene where the hesitant wolf finally takes food from Costner is film making greatness right? Costner should have gotten an Oscar for that scene if nothing else. NOT. And what in the world was with Mary McDonnell's hair. For it to stick out like that I think it would have to be teased and/or hairsprayed, which would make it not authentic - they didn't know about teasing or hairspray in the 1800's. Anyway I have wasted enough time on this review which I could write 10 pages about it's awfulness but I will quit now. Never will I watch this monstrosity again even for money. Shame they don't have negative rating numbers so I could give this movie a minus infinity.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films in the 90's
reviews.content: Dances with wolves is a very epic film.I must much hear that this film is too long or even I little bit boring, but a good written book you have to read at least in more than 4 hours this film take.This film gives you great impressions of native Americans life, of course fabulous screen shots and strong performances by Kevin Costner and Graham Greene.For fans I recommend to read the novel which helped me to understand this film better.It's a touching movie and one of the best of the last decade.
Ridiculous story full of one dimensional characters, but the cinematography was great!Graham Greene was very good, but I can't say the same for most of the other performers.

"Rewarded for his heroism in the Civil War, Lt. John Dunbar (Kevin Costner, who also directed and co-produced with Joe Wilson), wants to see the American Frontier before it is gone. He is assigned to an abandoned fort where a (Native American Indian) Sioux tribe is his only neighbor. Overcoming the language barrier and their mutual fear and distrust, Dunbar and the proud Indians gradually become friends," according to the film's official synopsis."Eventually, (Costner) falls in love with the beautiful 'Stands With A Fist' (Mary McDonnell), a white woman raised by the tribe. He learns the culture of the Sioux, lives with them, and even experiences the breathtaking excitement of a buffalo hunt, but his knowledge of the fate which will ultimately befall the tribe torments him. Finally, he is faced with a crucial decision that will cause him to examine his heart and soul before making a heroic choice that determines his destiny." Some of the criticism regarding "Dances with Wolves" misses the point; it's intentionally about role reversal.Mr. Costner was a neighbor of mine during the 1980s. He lived on Palm Drive, past the old LCUSD building. I'd never seen a Costner movie, but knew he made them. After "Dances with Wolves" came out, you could measure his success by the amount of long, dark cars coming to pick up Costner for award ceremonies. There were quite a lot of limos, and the film's honorees included the aforementioned, plus writer Michael Blake, photographer Dean Semler, composer John Barry, and editor Neil Travis.Costner's film is very beautiful, and he looks very good in it; much like real life, but with more feathery hair. He's a nice man (very zen) just like the character he plays herein. I was surprised to see one of his daughters in the opening, playing "Christine" (Ms. McDonnell as a child); why didn't anyone think to match the character's hair? A great dad, Costner took his children on walks, and jogged when in town. Backing out of our car port, we always checked to make sure Kevin Costner wasn't behind the vehicle.******** Dances with Wolves (10/19/90) Kevin Costner ~ Kevin Costner, Mary McDonnell, Graham Greene, Rodney A. Grant

Most films this long would be better if they were shorter, but this isn't one of them. Somehow the slow pace of the film - especially near the beginning - is essential to establishing the isolation of the outpost. Other than the generally simplistic Indian good, White Man bad attitude of the movie it was a great flick. Well worth the Oscar nod, I'd call it one of the top 5 big epics, and for me I'd say it was second only to Lawrence of Arabia, and not by much.

One of the best movies ever made imho. Although fiction, the movie is a good example of how mutual respect goes a long way. It's also a good example of why violence is sadly a necessary evil. Brute force and strength is the only languge any bully understands.

(89%) One of the stronger westerns to be made after the genre declined in popularity during the 1970's and 1980's; although it could be argued that this deserves to be among the very best. This really does mark the highpoint in Kevin Costner's filmography, made at a time when he could do little wrong. His direction here is typical of all the best, well-shot films of this type, with great location work and a fine eye for detail. It's best strength though lies in the mix of emotions that bombard the audience. Pain, beauty, sadness, joy, and by the end a strong sense of anger toward the savage white land-grabbers; the like of which is very powerful and implemented superbly well. Despite the plot using the overused white person adopted by natives theme, everyone still should watch this film at least once.

reviews.review_title: My brief review of the film
reviews.content: A spectacular epic western, well done in a number of aspects, but yet the film is uneven in its execution, resulting in a film that is far less than perfect. It is often involving and some of the scenery is captured by the cinematographer very well, but yet at times it drags and tends to bore. The acting is generally good, overall it is a very well-done film and was well awarded seven Oscars, but at twice the necessary length it is a shame that it cannot go down as a masterpiece. If it had been a half or even three quarters of its length, Costner would have directed a masterpiece  instead this is just a very good film, but nothing special.

reviews.review_title: Friendships can develop in the unlikeliest of places.
reviews.content: When a film maker pours his heart and soul into a film,it shows in the final product.This is the best film that Kevin Costner has ever made from the standpoint of directing as well as acting and for that very reason.It is obvious that this was a project he believed in very strongly and whenever that is the case,you take no shortcuts toward making it a great film.It is a film about friendship and about how sometimes friendships develop from the unlikeliest of places.As human beings,we develop perceptions of certain types of people based on what others tell us about them.Very often those perceptions turn out to be wrong if we choose to get to know them ourselves.Dances With Wolves will take you on a ride during which you will visit a wide range of emotions,that is,if you have any humanity in you whatsoever.It should not be missed.Well done,Mr. Costner.

This was an outstanding film. It is a true tribute to the Native Americans that we as a nation so wronged long ago. The cinematography here was breathtaking, rivaled only by Titanic in its sheer majesty. A masterpiece in every way, well deserving of its many awards, and probably should have gotten a few more as well. Greene was fantastic, as was Wind in his Hair. An awe inspiring experience.

There are few things wrong with this film.  The writing is naturally paced, the acting is solid (with one exception), the cinematography is some of the most beautiful ever put on film, and the sound immerses the viewer in the environment.  Kevin Costner's direction is nearly flawless as he gives the viewer a glimpse into the Native American culture and its decline.One of the only things I do not like about this film is Kevin Costner's inadequate, monotone performance.  But that is hardly anything to balk at, when the surrounding material is so well executed.  While the 3-hour theatrical version is great, I highly recommend the 4-hour cut.  9/10

The movie took a different approach when looking at the native american cultures. Instead of characterizing the Sioux as the enemies, they highlighted the misunderstandings that stop the white settlers from peacefully coexisting with them. It focused more on the hardships of the Sioux and why white people viewed their culture as a threat but showed that it was not impossible to make peace. Dances with Wolves overall highlights the mistakes that white people make and the assumptions that they have about native cultures. The cinematography was high quality for a 90s movie but the thing that really makes this movie so great is the story and the message it sends.

reviews.review_title: One of the Greatest Movies of All Time!
reviews.content: This movie, by far, is my favorite of all-time. However, to see the edited TV or cable versions does not do this film justice! To get the most appreciation out if this movie, the DVD version is a must! There are extra scenes on the DVD which give you a better understanding of their respective scenes, such as when Stands With A Fist's husband is brought back dead by his fellow Sioux warriors after a battle against the Ute tribe. You then realize why she was slashing her wrists when John Dunbar (Kevin Costner) finds her on the prairie. Anyhow, this movie has something for everyone: Adventure, romance, action, and just overall wonderful human drama. Dances With Wolves basic plot is that Lt. John Dunbar, a recently decorated Civil War Union officer, requests to be assigned to the most remote Army outpost on the American frontier. His main reason is that he wants to see it "before it disappears", as he puts it. To his astonishment, he realizes upon his arrival at the fort, it is deserted. He doesn't know what happened to the soldiers who were supposed to be there but decides to stay anyway. During his time at the fort, he meets and befriends a group of Lakota Sioux Indians, although not with some apprehension on both sides at first. Eventually, he realizes that his pre-conceived notions and prejudices against this race of people are totally unfounded. He, for the most part, falls in love with the tribe after realizing what a peaceful and harmonious they prove to be. Dunbar then fully adopts the customs and culture of the Sioux and rejects his own past. This film has a terrific moral to it as to how we all have certain prejudices against people who are different from us and if we just take the time to know them, we can become better human beings. Also, the musical score in this film is unsurpassed. It was so instrumental in conveying the mood in each and every scene of this film.

A great movie. I saw the uncut version (4 hours), and afterwards, my bottom was completely numb because I had forgotten to move during the whole thing. I am not an american, well I felt like one during this movie and I cannot understand how an american can resist the emotion when faced with that romantic idea (which actually is the fondation of the story) of the country's disappearing frontier.

reviews.review_title: As we would say on the rez, chesli
reviews.content: I'm sorry, but your apologia has not been accepted.  There actually was a Dunbar, and he was really a Christian missionary.And they could've at least gotten a native actress to play Stands with Fist, but nooooo...To make matters worse, this movie started a whole trend of wannabe Indians. Ask any Indian, we find them VERY annoying. All they're interested in is what they want Indians to be.Once we get past the racism, Costner's acting is sub par, as usual. What can we expect from a guy whose debut was playing a frat boy?Oh, on the lighter side, American censors cut out a scene where Costner says "Big buffalo" and one of the Indians says "Actually it was a little buffalo." You can guess what they thought he was talking about. And Costner's probably is fairly small, judging by the fact that he is speaking the female Lakota dialect throughout the movie. LOL

reviews.review_title: one of a kind story effectively told, truly a must-see
reviews.content: Remarkable, moving story stars Costner as a U.S. Army officer who becomes a hero after he unintentionally leads Union troops to victory during a key battle of the Civil War. He's given his choice of assignments, and chooses to be stationed at an abandoned fort on the western frontier. Alone and without standing orders, he forms an unlikely bond with a local Sioux tribe, gradually abandons all he knows, and eventually becomes a member of their tranquil society. Long, but gripping every step of the way with strong characters, some truly breathtaking scenery, and a story that's always involving. Never a dull moment in this powerfully in-depth character study, an extraordinary, riveting story masterfully told by Kevin Costner. ****

reviews.review_title: The music, the scenery, and Kevin Costner's butt!!!
reviews.content: This is a movie I can watch over and over again, even though it has a long running time.  This was truly a gift of love for Kevin Costner.  You can tell that he really cares about the subject by the way he paid attention to the smallest details.  The music is one thing that really impresses me. It is so beautiful and uplifting.  I find myself humming along while I am watching the movie.  The scenery is incredible.  You find yourself wanting to run in those fields, maybe not with the buffalo; that could be dangerous! The actors that were chosen by Costner were perfectly cast.  I could not picture anyone else in the roles.  The Lakota are beautiful people and are portrayed as a noble, caring, brave and close-knit community.  They take pleasure and pride in family. This movie has everything; action, drama, suspense, humour and yes, a gratuitous butt shot.  Kevin Costner is a fine male specimen and a joy to behold.  I highly recommend this movie to anyone who wishes they could have seen the west before it was tamed.

reviews.review_title: The Last of the Great Hollywood Romantic Epics
reviews.content: Very few films get better the more times you see them. Dances With Wolves is that film - for me at least - or one of them. I specificy me because the last time I saw this was when I was a young'un and today I am delighted to discover a film that is just as beautiful and moving as I remember it. I was judging it for its pure surface value then - and now I could judge it on that or anything else - on every level this film manages to succeed. It is one of the last of the Great Hollywood Romantic Epics tailored for for the spiritual grandeur of John Ford. Luckily for us, director Costner happens to be Ford's near-exact size. It's sad Ford died 17 years before the release of this film, because it is one while watching, one wishes Ford had seen it too. You know he would have been pleased. This was also that brief point in Kevin Costner's career where he was suddenly likable, and charismatic, and INTERESTING. Wow! Dances With Wolves is to Kevin Costner as is Wonder Boys is to Michael Douglas. Here he brings it together with a superb directing job that finely rivals Martin Scorsece's work that year on Goodfellas. Many have called Dances' win one of the worst, but I'm fine with it winning. Both this and Goodfellas are near perfect films in completely different ways, and some days I have a hard time deciding which is better. When Hollywood has neglected the subject of the Native Americans' plight (there are a few notable exceptions, such as Ford's "Cheyenne Autumn" and "Little Big Man") this film officially does all that has been missing justice in one grand, beautiful film. It begins with a spell-bindingly ridiculous sequence where Costner somehow fails to commit suicide riding a horse in front of enemy Confederate lines - it climaxes thrillingly, a battle on the creek where we twitch furiously happily every time our Sioux take down another Union'er. It ends with the devastating tragedy of a historical fact. David Lean died in 1991, and I have to wonder whether he ever saw this film too. This film is very much the mix of Lean and Ford, and I can't imagine any two director's who could be more perfectly combined. There are empty spaces in their works that could be filled by the others' - and thanks to Kevin, the space is filled. It wins Oscars for Best Supporting Actor - Rodney A. Grant Best Original Score Best Cinematography Best Costume Design and Nominations for Best Picture (and on some days I give it the win) Best Director Best Adapted Screenplay (see Best Picture) Best Actor - Kevin Costner Best Supporting Actor - Graham Greene Best Art Direction/Set Decoration Best Sound Best Editing

reviews.review_title: Kevin Costner did a great job.
reviews.content: Kevin Costner's Dances With Wolves is a great movie. I had doubts that he could make this film and star in it also, and then it comes out and I'm astonished. The movie is beautiful to look at and the score, by John Barry, is amazing. Costner must have seen this whole picture in his head because a shot does not seem wasted through the whole entire film. A brilliant film.

reviews.review_title: A Story of White and Red on the Frontier
reviews.content: After the American Civil War, Dunbar (Kevin Costner) requests to go to the frontier for assignment. His request is granted (after a really unusual scene where a man announces he has just soiled himself). He then meets the natives, who are understandably worried about the white man's moving in on them. But Costner just wants to be friends -- how can he make this work? Kevin Costner appears in and (in this case) directs epic films. At three hours and fifty-six minutes, this is the most epic of them all. But it's a good kind of epic, holding your attention with a rich story and strong characters (thank you, Graham Greene). I may not personally enjoy this as much as "Waterworld" or "The Postman", but it is probably the better film critically.There has been some complaint that this is a "liberal" movie. I can understand the complaint. This film definitely gives a more sympathetic point of view to the natives than the Americans. Reflecting on the situation, we now recognize the natives were wrongfully massacred. However, this is not the traditional view. Also, Dunbar says he wants to see the frontier "before it's gone", implying a liberal anti-sprawl stance. I don't have a problem with his views, though I do think they were not common at the time.The film is full of good surprises: fights, love, historical oddities and Costner's bare bottom. I think you should see it if you haven't. My brother has watched this film a dozen times, so it has to be worth your watching it at least once. I'd write more, but this film is such a classic that it's hard to say something a viewer won't already know.

I got an opportunity to watch this movie 6 months ago but never got time to review this title @ IMDb... This movie is truly spellbinding. Although i never prefer Hollywood films which are so long but with 'Dances with Wolves' you can sit for 3 hrs. without getting annoyed at any point.The film directed by Kevin Costner is artistic yet very simple. I don't know if he has any other title which is so much popular. The story portrays the terminal era of Red Indians with different perspective.. It is normally believed that the tribes including these people were cunning as well as brutal. But in this film the other side of the coin has been highlighted. It has been shown how American armed forces try to conquer their land so that they can exploit it for their own advantage. Their operation almost leads to the extinction of a community in whole.Kevin Costner has crafted this film so beautifully that the ethical beliefs, customs and rituals of the Red Indians are shown in the most mesmerizing fashion. This film clearly delivers us a message that if someone wants to form a bond of care and affection then language is certainly not a barrier.There are numerous reasons due to which one can go for this film. The set decoration, the costume, the direction and of course, the plot. Overall, this film has truly justified with its 1991 Academy Award nominations and wins.Go and watch this movie... you'll never regret it !! 9/10 Highly recommended ....

Kevin Costner's Academy-Award-Winning film 'Dances With Wolves' is an overrated classic. Yes agreed, it's beautifully directed and executed, but not a complete sweeper. The film's length is its biggest problem, leaving the viewer exhausted and tired. Its an above-average-to-average entertainer in my eye. Just about decent! Pluses: Costner's direction is fantastic. 2 words = Par Excellence. Costner's performance is also endearing. Other actors also do a pretty good job.Minuses: Too lengthy and violent. On the whole, 'Dances With Wolves' works in bits and pieces.

reviews.review_title: The Best Movie You'll Ever See As Long As You Live! Period!
reviews.content: I am listening to the soundtrack as I pen these words.For those few folks who have not yet seen this movie....STOP!Go buy the DVD and watch it now.The fondness and attraction I have developed for this Oscar-Winner Squared 10 is beyond what one might expect to receive.In any/all areas of "measuring a films worth" I give it all 10's! It is an adventure,a love story,a cinematic history lesson,a unique and moving journey through time.One of the more striking components is it's absolutely unique treatment of real old west "Indians".A complete departure from the under-done,over-the-top,campy,old west movies which have been slung upon us from birth...Dances With Wolves portrays the most genuinely realistic view of what it must have been like back in that time.Dances completely satisfied this unexplainable yearning in my heart for "us" (the white people)to interact realistically with "them" (the indians).The emotions this true masterpiece has brought out in me places it in a category all by itself.Okay, a word about the soundtrack:Uh, go buy it!If you have ever been moved by a movie score in the least.....go get this one. To say this movie is "well written" does not do the truth justice.You will be drawn in from the first syllable to the last.Your heart will be torn right out of your chest when "Wind-In-His-Hair" shouts..."Can't you see that I am your friend"! Or, again when earlier those wicked U.S.Cavelry guys are shooting at "two socks"!I swear to God,This film will tear you up and wring you out.To any pathetic soul who dared to say it is "too long" I would simply reply....I feel sorry for you,as it is obvious you do not possess a soul.If God put a "soundtrack" together which represented your life......it would sound close to the Dances With Wolves Soundtrack.This glorious film will magically take you into a world from the past which you might not otherwise enter.It is a bonafide once in a lifetime experience.If you think you might enjoy a vicarious trip to the old west...out on the plains:Go see this honest to God work-of-art!

"...I'm Wind in His Hair! Do you see that I am your friend? Can you see that you will always be my friend?..."WATTA EPIC SCENE... from an EPIC FILM!I can't recall if I ever STOPPED CRYING during this ending scene! Seriously, is been 30 years since this film was released, I've watched it over 50 times (at least!) and I NEVER STOPPED CRYING LIKE A BABY watching this INCREDIBLE scene!The "Wind in His Hair" says all if two phrases, ALL ABOUT PURE FRIENDSHIP!
To me, this is the ULTIMATE love, among with the love for your children. No erotic love, no. The pure love for YOUR FRIEND, that makes you sacrifice for him, your brother in arms, your ...brother, period!The film is EPIC, I mean... seriously... GIGANTIC EPIC!
And I'm not even American, nor Native Indian origins... and still, this film TOUCHED ME SO MUCH, that I thought I am Lakota and I was close to start searching for relative origins!!!Okay... I love western films. And I do love the Native Indians, the REAL AMERICANS! I always was supporting them watching films, even if I was pretty sure they will lost and slaughtered from the White men in the end... No matter, I was always with them! And this film... oh boy... is a POEM, A TRIBUTE for those people. If you have A SINGLE DROP OF INDIAN BLOOD in your veins, this is a LEGACY film for your people, you MUST watch it.Great photography, emotional music/soundtrack, superb costumes, REAL LAKOTA (SIOUX) LANGUAGE FOR A CHANGE (not English!), REAL INDIAN FOLKS-ACTORS (not... painted White actors!)... real buffaloes, real... real... REAL!
I mean... we can't travel through time back then and ACTUALLY SEE ALL OF THESE... but we can see (again!) this film and have a look how they actually looked like about 97% ACCURATE! ...And that's a comment from a REAL INDIAN, how much this film is accurate!...Obviously, for me (and many others), my favorite character is "WIND IN HIS HAIR", a PURE portrait of a Lakota Sioux Brave man! You can't but fall in love with this character. You can't but drop oceans of tears at the end of the film...THIS IS AN EPIC FILM! THIS IS A FILM FROM THE TOP-10 YOU NEED TO WATCH BEFORE DIE!The End.

reviews.review_title: A beautiful movie, but overlong and ultimately boring.
reviews.content: There can be no denying 'Dances with Wolves' is an incredible production and it certainly deserves all the accolades and high praise, but ultimately I found the film (eventually) a bit boring.Yes, it is an interesting story of a man's journey to self-discovery, but to sit through a 3-hour western drama with very little action does become tedious. If the film was just over 2 hours long, or 2 and a half, I might have found it less boring. Some scenes were unnecessarily long and could have been cut. The film is also very slow moving.Ok, so that's my main criticism. Kevin Costner is wonderful as John Dunbar. We don't really know too much about the character, but since he is about to discover who he truly is and wants to be, it doesn't really matter. There are some very funny moments, too. The cinematography is beautiful and I loved the setting. 'Dances with Wolves' is a story of courage, will, determination, moral values, and unlikely friendships.Off course a love interest was inevitable and predictable, and when the love story finally took over, I really became bored. We all view films differently, and that's a good thing. For me, 'Dances with Wolves' is too long a movie, and there were moments when I got a sense of deja vu. 'Gone with the Wind', for instance, is longer still (about 4 hours), yet I never felt bored. The 'Lord of the Rings' films are about 3 hours long each, and they, too, kept me engaged for the entire duration of the film. 'Dances with Wolves' just drags too much, and there are many rather quiet moments in the film. It is a beautiful movie with lots to admire, but just too slow for my liking.

reviews.review_title: Costner couldn't be better, one of my top favorite movies ever!
reviews.content: I rarely give a rating of "10" to a movie, mostly because in any great "top notch" movie there's always something..you know.. even a little something, that is either missing or not done right, but this movie truly has it all.. the directing, the acting, the theme music, the clothes, the locations.. ALL.To be honest, I'm not a huge fan of Costner, I mean..other than that movie, there are certain movie roles for Costner that fit incredibly, and surprising the other roles don't convince you at all, this guy is a genuine talented actor if he is in the right part and "Dances with wolves" definitely is.

reviews.review_title: Epic if there ever was one
reviews.content: Why didn't Epic Movie spoof this is all I want to know? Kevin Costner who stars and directs in the sweeping film 'Dances with Wolves' has delivered an epic of all proportions. It is a human drama, it is a classic Western, a civil war film and a film about understanding of Native Americans. Costner plays Lieutenant John Dunbar or as he will come to be known by the Native Americans - 'Dances with Wolves.' The story goes that Lt. John Dunbar, exiled to a remote western Civil War outpost, befriends wolves and Indians, making him an intolerable aberration in the military. The film is one of the first of it's kind to treat Native American's with respect, this is an intelligent film about breaking down the barriers of communications between a tribe of Native Americans and Dunbar. The story is brilliant and the acting is wonderful. The music score by John Barry is brilliant and his best alongside his score for 'Out of Africa' and I won't mention the Bond theme because no one really knows who really did it. The cinematography is brilliant and in my favorite scene from the film that is in perfect showcase. Late at night Dunbar is woken by the sound of buffalo. He can't see anything through the fog as he runs into the open field and as he stands there he is surrounded by a herd of buffalo who emerge from the mist and on the characters face emerges a look of wonder and amazement. How wonderful it is that the audience shared the same reaction throughout the whole movie.

I'm sure every story has been told before, but I can't recall any that have displayed such originality as this. Michael Blake set the bar high. This is a movie I watch with my wife at least once a year. Yes, we can quote almost every line.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as Costner's reputation might lead you to expect
reviews.content: Nineteen ninety was a different time for Kevin Costner. This film, which he directed and starred in, won seven Oscars (unjustly overshadowing "GoodFellas" in my opinion) and cemented his status as one of Hollywood's heavy hitters. Fast forward nearly twenty years later and he's equally famous (or infamous) for a couple of massive flops ("Waterworld" and "The Postman"). However, this early directorial effort shows some of the promise of what might have been.The story concerns a Union lieutenant who requests a post on the frontier so that he can experience it before it fades into history with the westward approach of 'civilized' man. In his solitude he connects with nature and then strikes up a friendship with Native Americans in the territory. It's a fairly engaging story but I feel that there were a few concessions made to give it a broader appeal. I could have easily done without the romantic angle and I feel that the film would have had more resonance if it had been cut off a little earlier.Costner's not too bad of an actor but I would have preferred someone else in the role. It's not that he's particularly unconvincing but rather that he lacks personality. The supporting cast is hit and miss, with Graham Greene standing out as the best of the lot. He managed to nab an Oscar nomination along with Costner and Mary McDonnell, neither of whom I would have singled out.Costner's direction is fairly accomplished and there is some nice cinematography at times but I wouldn't have chosen him over Scorsese for Best Director. The score by John Barry sometimes seems overbearing as well. I would have rather had sparser instrumentation to go along with the sparseness of the frontier. However, the score won an Academy Award so I may be in the minority regarding its merits.Considered as a whole, "Dances With Wolves" isn't a bad film but, as we've seen many times, the Academy got carried away and made some now-questionable Oscar choices. As for myself, I believe that with a few tweaks this could have been a great film rather than just an okay film.

reviews.review_title: 3hrs running American history lesson: a true masterpiece.
reviews.content: At last, an historical western epic where most of spectators (except the Lakota ones) feel like intruders. Along with the genre usual tools (roaring music, breath-taking landscapes, etc.), Kostner provide us with the most authentic native tribe portrayal ever captured on film. Here, every single element of the indians daily life is depicted in detail, but far from the documentary style: in fact, everything is showed as part of the story-telling. Then, the linguistic choice. It is here that the movie raises from excellent to memorable: we hear the true language of the natives, their voices sound distant and fascinating, exactly as they must have sounded to Lieut. Jhon J. Dunbar at his first meeting with the Sioux (Michael Blake's novel was about Comanche, though, but while the Comanche language happens to be disappeared with its speakers, Lakota is still spoken in North Dakota Sioux Reservoir. No one ever attempted such a task, not even the righteously famous "new Hollywood" western films, like (Blue Soldier) between many others. The original novel is carefully respected under every other aspect, and the result is a powerful, moving picture of what America once was, and of the people at which expense America has been built. In his directorial debut, Kostner displays what eventually has remained his distinguished mark: a style both magnificent and visionary (the buffalo hunting scene is masterful), with a notable sense of what cinema has to be: something larger than life, but made of life itself.This movie stands, in movie arts, as the greatest tribute Hollywood has ever made to Native Americans, and as a great lesson of national awareness for all who desired to know the dirty, mixed, deep roots of the United States of America.

After 13 years I've seen the movie again on TV. Great Tv night!! This picture has not lost any of its splendour over the years!! It definitely IS the groundbreaking masterpiece in depicting the American natives' lives from a different viewpoint and still deserves all the Oscars it got at the time. My only objection is that Kevin Costner puts himself in the frame just a bit too often and for too long. As for the rest, the performances are impressive, the story heartwarming and heartbreaking, totally believable, the production design just awesome and the direction, though sagging at times,as good as it can get. Kevin Costner should stick to direction, here he shows a wonderful talent. Did he exhaust himself in the realization of this project, which had been his great dream for a long time, or whatever happened to his directing skills after this movie??

Unfortunately, for some reason Kevin Costner didn't have the reputation of a talented actor. It would seem, that he has everything: he is a courageous, handsome, textured. He could play both brave daredevil and degraded debauchee-ribald. And he played, but evidently didn't convince exacting critics. Well, let so be it. All the same we love him. He nevertheless won critics' hearts by his director's talent. His epic western film «Dances with Wolves» - the confirmation of that.This is an extraordinary story about extraordinary man. Each of us makes strides along the road of life with one or another destination, leaving the tracks by acts of various kinds. Somebody sows the good seed, somebody destroys everything, somebody creates for the welfare of science and culture and somebody aimlessly goes down with the stream in expectation of opportune destiny. The character of « Dances with wolves», First Lieutenant John Dunbar doomed to be a hero. His heroism is not the ostentatious prowess and thirst of recognize, it's his self, his way of life. His conscience, his spirit and his desperate heart lead his acts. His vital desire don't come to conquest of all possible and impossible heights, he violently persists in discover the frontier within himself.Growing roots in an uninhabited fort, stoically and thoroughly overcoming the harsh natural conditions, John Dunbar conscientiously and patiently waits for other soldiers. At first sight, he's absolutely lonely. But he realized very quickly all advantages of his loneliness: finally he was left alone with himself. Getting acquainted with Sioux, with their way of life, rituals and law, he doesn't look for personal gain. His aspiration to become closer with new neighbors, to be imbued with their traditions and, in the end, to become a part of their tribe, was dictated not by desire to relieve the lonely pastime or establish the good neighborly relations with strangers. All his acts – are heartfelt needs heart and soul. The destiny an incredible way throws John in the dizzying centrifuge of even more incredible circumstances, which frenzied rotation only strengthens his will and morale, opening him his true capabilities and personal orientations. Going over to the Sioux side and fighting against the U.S. Army, Dances with Wolves has no doubts in his right choice and actions. He doesn't compromise with his conscience, he acts jointly with it. He had found himself, the meaning of his way, and he didn't betray these acquirement.John Dunbar stepped into a heroic way from his birth and relentlessly moved on it even on unconscious level, without changing neither his route nor to himself. Ha was a hero even before accomplishment of his heroic feat. He went all his life to these and subsequent feats. John Dunbar didn't become Dances with Wolves, he became himself. And those circumstances, which thick he gets into, only push him to the frontier within himself, his genuine predestination.The staggering movie! And staggering Kevin Costner!

reviews.review_title: I have mixed feelings about this film.
reviews.content: First let me talk about what I consider to be the strengths of this movie. John Barry's score is excellent and well deserves the oscar it won.  Dean Semler's cinematography is magnificent and, to me, the highlight of the movie.  For many years I considered the cinematography of "Lawrence of Arabia" to be the best I had ever seen.  Now I'm not so sure.  To me, the filming of the buffalo hunt/chase is one of the great achievements in movie history.  And the filming of the vistas and the land under different lighting conditions is outstanding.I did not see the performances of any of Mary McDonnell's competitors, but was very disappointed that she did not win for Best Supporting Actress.  And the nominations for Art - Set Decoration and Costume Design were very well deserved.Another top achievement was getting to know the Indians very intimately and coming to realize that individually, the Indians of the 1860s are very much like white people today.  And it showed, to an extent, how Indian culture of the 1860s differed so vastly from white culture of the same time.  It would have been a good idea, I think, to have developed this aspect some more.That is one of the weaknesses, in my opinion, of this movie.  Another is the tendency to portray the Sioux as 100% good and the whites and the Pawnee as close to 100% bad.  I have a handful of reputable books that all point out that there were a significant number of whites who were sympathetic to the Indians during this time.  Unfortunately for the Indians, there weren't enough of them and most were back east.Regarding the Pawnee, it is true that they were enemies of the Sioux.  But so were the Crow, Shoshone, and some lesser tribes.  From what I have read in my books, the various tribes of the Great Plains competed against each other for enough land to support them.  They needed water, grass for their horse herds, wild game for food, and buffalo for just about everything. They warred against each other.  But that doesn't make one tribe "good" and another tribe "bad".Finally, there is too much of Kevin Costner in this movie.  I don't know if he realizes or agrees, but it seems that he was trying to make himself, not the people of the Sioux village, the centerpiece of the movie.  If someone else had done the narration, that would have been a big help.  Or if someone else had played the part of Lt. Dunbar, that also would have been a good idea.

SPOILER AHEAD The great, great Gary Larson even made a cartoon about it. A huge room is decorated for a convention, a banner reads "Welcome people who didn't like Dance with wolves - World con" and there a just 4 people in it.Back then when the movie was shown on the big screen everybody was in awe, a cultural phenomenon. I liked it, but it had lengths and it was almost too beautiful to watch. Man, the big country is awesome...I kept thinking to myself "please let it end, they will die in the end anyway, so make it quick!" And I did not like the black and white view of the two Indian (native American) tribes. Come on, show some shades of gray! It's the idealization of the natives that bothers me, at least sometimes. It's so cliché.But anyway, it's a nice story and it could have happened like shown in "Dance".So I'll rate it: 8/10Macaulay J. Connor

Kevin costner is a actor who seems so underated, in this he directs as well as acts and it is the best work he has ever done. Every frame of this movie has had so much care and attention to detail put into it. You find yourself caring about every single character, the score for the film is perect. It's a epic movie with a epic run time but one that flys by and one you don't want to end. If you want a escape from all the cgi and one dimensional charcaters then this movie is a tough one to beat.

Kevin Costner both directed and stars in this compelling adaptation of Michael Blake's novel about Lt. Dunbar(Costner) a decorated officer during the American Civil War who nonetheless is disillusioned with his society, and requests transfer to a remote frontier outpost, where he befriends a lone wolf he names 'Two Socks', and also the local native tribe, whom he makes peace with, falling in love with a white woman the tribe had raised named 'Stands With A Fist'(played by Mary McDonnell) and becoming accepted into the tribe as 'Dances With Wolves'. Unfortunately, his past catches up with him, leading to his capture and court martial for desertion, though despite tragedies, will not give up his new way of life... Winner of the best picture and director Academy Awards, this film is a fascinating portrait of a most extraordinary man, with exquisite direction. Only goes wrong with the fate of 'Two Socks', which felt wrong and senseless; otherwise a must-see picture.

I finally had the chance to watch this 7 Oscars winning movie. Winning Best Movie against titles like Goodfellas and Awakening, two amazing and impressive movies. After watching Dances with Wolves, my question was: why? Why the seven Oscars? Why all the fame?The first hour I was tempted to turn off this movie. I could not believe what I was watching. Great actors acted very mediocre. The story was mainly about mad people acting weird, the storyline was very weak. Then the story changed and it was mainly about Costner and his solitude. The movie was now very similar to one of the pseudo-documentaries set in the nature. One of those scripted documentaries where an animal is followed. The animal has a name and an artificial voice-over tells us what the animal is feeling and what the animal's motivation is. These pseudo-documentaries are usually poorly made and very much made up. This part of Dances with Wolves is even worse.The final part is acceptable. When Costner joins an Indian tribe, finally the movie starts to be a bit worth watching. But still not great.The movie was, in my opinion, definitely not worth any Oscars. Not even nominations. I gave this movie a 4. The average of a 1 for the first part and a 7 for the second part.

This is one of the best movies of the 1990´s, and it definitely shows that Kevin Costner doesn´t deserve the bad reputation he has got. He is a great actor and most of all a great director. "Dances With Wolves" is a grand and touching story of a wounded soldier in the american civil war, who chooses to take service in a small outpost in South Dakota. When he arrives, he finds the fort to be empty and abandoned. The only contact with other beings he get is with a wolf called Two Socks and with the local sioux-indians. After a while he gets interested in the indians and their way of life, and eventually becomes a member of the tribe. But the american soldiers are coming...

Since when a movie has been quoted "bad" because of it's lenght? I know Die Hard 4.0 was too long, I know Alexander was too long but I really can't understand the complains about the lenght of this masterpiece. In my opinion the length of a movie becomes a trouble when the viewer starts watching the clock. I remember sitting in my chair gasping over the tremendous amount of feelings this movie makes me feel.Dances with the wolves (1990) is a story about John Dumbar, a "hero" of the U.S army which decides to go to an abandoned little fort in Indian land. Without spoiling the storyline the movie tells the story of an era where the colour of your face and the culture of your people rejects you from the right to be treated like a human being.I really cannot praise this movie enough and I really advise EVERYONE to see the director's cut, which is over 3h long but really, after seeing it, where would you cut?

reviews.review_title: It's very good movie for a director who made his first movie
reviews.content: John Dunbar is one of the deserved heroes of the American Civil War. In 1865 he is assigned to a forgotten and abandoned outpost of the west. This task is very exciting for him. His job is to wait for the soldiers to be brought here. While enjoying the days he spent here, Dunbar begins to get closer to the Lakota Siu he has just met. Day by day, he gets to know these Indians, who only think of peace, and becomes friends with them. After a while, he will begin to accept that he is one of them.Kevin Costner achieved a rare success in his directorial debut and won 12 Oscar nominations, including the most important ones.

reviews.review_title: My Favorite Movie Of All Time
reviews.content: This movie has everything. Drama, action, humor, and the most important message a movie can give to its viewers (and still be entertaining). A message that when practiced would effect and solve all other issues in life. Of course, having my favorite actor Kevin Costner in it helps too.

reviews.review_title: From Darkness in the Dark to Brightness in the Light
reviews.content: So many have romanticized this era, despite the pall of death obviously borne by the red men. This realistic presentation by default wears a mask of sadness, occasionally and realistically grins (or at least grimaces) when appropriate, and the 'hero' is never certain to win the prettiest girl -- but we're all glad for his choice and her acceptance -- they very much deserve each other.The military is realistically mediocre at best, save for the officers who are worse than chance would have it, proving our suspicions that the good ones always leave to be rid of those diluting the quality pool.While I genuinely loved it, I have only watched it 3 times in 5 years, allowing time to mellow the actions, thereby better objectifying my impressions. I'm convinced you'll be won over as well, adding your higher votes for a fine performance.

I recently watched this movie again after an interlude of several years. I enjoyed it up to the point where the cavalry arrives. The good native american/evil white invader that finishes up the movie is just too much for me. In fact the movie portrays almost all whites as either losers or murderers. I think it could've done a great service to the memory of the late plains indian culture without that, or at least not so much of that.
