Does anyone else find it odd that Costner's character falls in love with a Native American...except she ISN'T??? Between this and the equally delusional "JFK" Costner has done more to propagate history misinformation than even Mel Gibson. I recommend steering clear of this misinformed piece of fiction.

Dance with Wolves is a very gripping, magnificent film. I put this film off for years because I thought it would be horrible despite winning Best Picture. Well this movie is a true epic of the 1990's. My only complaint that this movie is a little too long. I am not a big fan of three hour movies even if it's Avatar or Lord of the Rings. Like those two, I dealt with it and watched the whole film.This is about a Civil War soldier named John Dunbar who is exiled out in the middle of nowhere. While he is there, he and the local Sioux tribe becomes friendly with each other.Kevin Costner is pretty good here. His haircut in some scenes reminded me of Mel Gibson from Braveheart. Graham Greene is magnificent as Kicking Back or whatever his name is.The score for the film is truly memorable. I can't remember a good score from the 1990's as good as this one. The cinematography is unbelievable too.There are a few scenes that choked me up. They were written very well. This is a very good movie certainly better than Goodfellas. I rate this film 9/10.

Nice attempt by Costner to produce an intimate Western epic with a heartily embracing attitude towards the Native Americans. And in cinematic terms, it works quite well, with beautiful photography and some rousing moments enlivening the three to four hours running time.But basically, it's the conventional long-standing naive view on the oh-so-noble savages, while the use of subtitled native language and extensive insight into the Indians' everyday life is laudable but does not necessarily provide a stronger grip on reality. The pic's still an all-American boy's adventure, owing a lot to Jack London's books and in that respect watchable (if not nearly as harsh and absorbing), but finally too long-winded and overreaching.6 out of 10 gripping buffalo hunts

Saw this movie when it was originally theatrically released. Knew then what a great film it was. Have just now watched it again in bluray. It is cinematically brilliant and gorgeous to watch. If you haven't seen this exceptional film recently, please do so - it is simply what a film masterpiece should be!

What a movie. I have no word to describe how much I've enjoyed this movie. It is one of the best creations I have ever experienced. And Kevin Costner,he acted fantastically. He made this movie with unparalleled skill of direction. The Sioux people, their lifestyle,dialect,and culture has been depicted and detailed in a very artistic way. The background music was excellent. A 10 out of 10. I think the relation between Lt.John J Dunbar and Sioux people was the most interesting and significant part of the story. It happened in a very naturalistic and realistic way that it will easily win anybody's heart. I loved the first kissing scene of Dunbar and Stands With a Fist. It was very emotional. Surely a revolutionary motion picture.

reviews.review_title: A movie about emotion and justice overcoming reason.
reviews.content: For many decades, the American film industry portrayed the Indians as bandits, in a portrait later reinforced in Italian westerns. In this movie we finally see Indians portrayed as they probably were: a people with a culture that white Americans were not able to understand. Cavalry officer John Dunbar, on the other hand, understood the Indians, forced by his isolation, but ended up being acculturated by them to the point of marrying an Indian woman. From there, this character follows his heart and his sense of justice more than his rational discernment. The story is deeply romantic and has a touch of sadness because we, the public, know the fate of these Indians, and the film shows us how the Americans knew to be unfair and cruel. Kevin Costner has earned in this film one of the most remarkable works of his career. He was brilliant in the role of the young American officer, to whom the fear, the need and the curiosity lead to initiate dialogue and coexistence with the Indians. Mary McDonnell gave birth to the young Indian who marries Dunbar and filled her character with gentleness, understanding and joy. The way the Indians are represented seems historically accurate, as does the representation of Americans. The wide prairie scenery is a beautiful addition, astounding and astounding the audience. Some sequences, such as marriage or hunting, are worthy of anthology.

reviews.review_title: One of the most spectacular pictures EVER!!!
reviews.content: I'm a 14-year-old boy who enjoy the classics. My friends said they are so old and so boring. I used to think the same, though. And not until I watched Dances with Wolves did I realized why all classics are said to be the foundation of the film industry. I started to enjoy watching classics since that day. But none of other classics, in my opinion only, can surpass Dance with Wolves.Now, I'm gonna talk something about the movie. The story was so good that it could be the best story ever told. It's a pity that 19 years later, Avatar use the same story. But trust me, Avatar, by no means, can surpass this magnificent classic. Not only because it's the 1st movie that brings us the story, but also well written and carefully made.The acting was good too. But I don't think it's the best that Kevin Costner could give us. He could have done better. But what am I thinking? He did such a great job in direction and producing, I cannot blame him for not winning the Academy awards, can I? The rest of the cast did fine job too.The sound was great, it's so suitable with the view of the wilderness of the place. I could barely realize when I started to got suck to the movie by the sound, and the view.In short, Kevin Costner was the right man for the job. He made a masterpiece. It's a pity that Dances with Wolves didn't get high point on top IMDb.

reviews.review_title: Outstanding Film! Bravura Performance by Kevin Costner
reviews.content: To this day it astounds me this great film won Kevin Costner academy awards for best picture and best director, yet not best actor. He gave a truly great performance in showing how the U.S. Army treated not only the Lakota, but those soldiers they considered sympathetic to them. It was a story that was long overdue...entire generations were lied to about the injustices and downright hatred the Lakotas and other American Indian tribes suffered. The film accurately portrayed how the Lakotas embraced their land, taking only what was needed, never anything more. Graham Greene and the other actors who played the Lakotas and Crow were outstanding. They were believable...real humans who were driven off their lands due to "manifest destiny". In my humble opinion this film should be shown to kids in school...so they know what really happened while the West was "won".

reviews.review_title: Dances with Wolves - What a triumph!
reviews.content:
Dances with Wolves is simply a masterpiece! I believe it stands as one of the greatest movies ever made. I believe this for many reasons!
Artistically, it is absolutely astounding. The best I can explain is that the film transports you! It carries you to the place whether it be a Civil War battlefield or hospital, or a dusty fort at the end of the westward sprawl of America ca. 1860s, the rolling hills of the prairie, or the majesty of a huge herd of buffalo, this movie is transcendent visually. The musical score by John Barry whisks you away to place, and a moment, with perfect effectiveness. Just play "The Buffalo Hunt" on the radio, the next time you are driving in an open expanse. You'll understand. Historically, this capture the dichotomy of the American expansion westward, and the challenges it presented to the Sioux and other nations displaced by this expansion, in beautiful and sorrowful detail. It shows is the majesty of what the American Indian world was like. This makes this Dances with Wolves such an important story for future. Kevin Costner shares the objective story of the American Indian. Too many movies cast the American Indian as mindless and bloodthirsty savages. This film captures the American Indian as the unwitting protagonists in a story of the duel between the past and the present, a position they would have rather avoided entirely. Even the Pawnee, in their displays of hostility in this movie, act in response to a sense of frustration and self preservation. This movie captured the pride of a people, as well as their anxiety, in the face of changes that they ultimately could not challenge or control. This story of the American Indian remains beautifully intact with this film.

A classic film, beautiful scenery and wonderfully acted."Dances with Wolves" is beautiful. The detailed conversion on my new Blu player is and was phenomenal. The individual blades of grass stood tall and at moments I felt as if I was right there with Costner as he chased Two-Socks, or crossed the sweeping frontier. Costner's film, if anything, gave a modern technology country a view of a world that nearly feels fictional. No computers, no cell phones, nothing facing you except nature, and the power of Mother Earth. Costner captures this feeling with perfection. Not only does he have the time to cultivate this sensation, but he uses both audio and visual references to assist with his imagery. There was no doubt in my mind that Costner felt dedicated to this project that his creative eye wasn't at the peak of its existence. His passion bled through the film, giving us that moment when "Dances with Wolves" transforms from Hollywood project to Costner's dream come true. For that I applaud Costner for following his heart and creating a visual treat that goes beyond your average film.

reviews.review_title: Some people should learn how to enjoy themselves
reviews.content: I went to see the original movie when it came out in the theaters. I thought it well presented. It drove me to purchase the novel. Now one thing I should point out is the novel and hence the movie is purely fiction.Having said that and reading some of the negative reviews and scorn surrounding the depiction of white people in the movie, I would like to say, are all white people evil? No. Were all Indians evil? No. However, being part Indian I think I have a valid point to make and that same point was made in the movie, "The white man comes and he takes. Without asking." What is not said is because the American mindset is we kill and get what we want because we are better. Manifest Destiny is no more than excused genocide. The US slaughters because it can. If anyone doubts the nastiness of the US all one has to do is to read the letters of General Sheridan, Sherman and others of their ilk. BTW I would also point out the quote, "The only good Indian is a dead one!" didn't originate with Indians. If I have one issue with this movie is it the depiction of white soldiers being the predominant race in the Union Army when they were slaughtering the Sioux. I have no sympathy for the black race calling for reparations as they helped wipe out what was left of the indigenous population. As a matter of fact, the dominant race in the US Army during the Indian wars of the plains was black with white officers.So a movie was finally made that shows the people of the plains as being human. As for the Pawnee, as history shows, all enemies are always reviled. This is true of our time, to whit the Iraqis, so let those of us without sin cast the first stone. I'm sure if a story was presented from the Pawnee point of view they'd be depicted as saints.Notice that all stories show their subjects in the finest of lights, this is true from Beowulf to the present day. Even Romeo and Juliet two suicides are portrayed in the best of light. So LIGHTEN THE f**k up.Go to the movies and enjoy yourselves for 90 minutes to 9 hours. Oh and by the way GET a LIFE!My recommendation? Get the movie's extended version if you liked the novel. This version more closely follows the novel than the one released in the cinema. Then watch it with a grain of salt. However, I do advise reading actual material from the period, especially what Col. G. A. Custer had to say regarding the issue of the black hills and the Sioux. Also the novel was originally about the Comanche. It was thought at the time of filming that depicting the Comanche as benign would offend some people hence the change to Sioux.

An excellent film that chronicles one man's search for himself, adventuring into the American frontier immediately following the Civil War. Reminiscent of the old Eastwood-Leone films, but done much more professionally. Costner never so much resembled an animated corpse as he does in this flick, yet it works marvelously. He is a poster boy for stereotypical Indian stoicism, and the Sioux embrace him with open arms. I think the politics of Cowboy Bad, Indian Good isn't too heavy handed either. The message is certainly there, but is told in a fair manner, as it points out that not all of the American Indians were saints. Ill leave that all alone. Its rather long, and I don't think Ive seen the end more than once. But I never tire of attempting to rewatch it. The cinematography is as good as it gets, and Costner's Direction is more than worthy of the praise it received.

reviews.review_title: A Modern Classic of a Classic Time.
reviews.content: Dances With Wolves (1990) -I have spent many years avoiding watching this film and groaning at the thought of sitting through it again, but with no real reason for doing so. When I first watched it, probably at the cinema, I really liked it and I liked it again once it was bought on VHS, so I couldn't think where the disdain for it had come from when I watched it this time and found it to be a highly enjoyable film.I can only assume that it came about, because Kevin Kostner suddenly started appearing in everything and he wasn't regarded very highly for his performances in other things, especially 'Waterworld' (1995) and that the idea of watching such a long, long film, with him in it, was off putting.Actually, apart from his boring and monotonous drawl as he narrated his journal, although I suppose that might have been appropriate for his character, Kevin did a very good job in this film. He was actually quite handsome and had a lovely bottom on display, but he also delivered a great performance too.The film overall could definitely have been a good smidge shorter and I do feel that if it had been, I would have been and would be going forwards, more inclined to watch it more often, but films of over two hours in length really are a commitment, especially when the subject matter wasn't exactly my go to genre. I liked the message that it sent that showed people getting along and the historical aspect, that provided an idea of the feelings at the time. It wasn't essentially my own history, being from and living in Britain, but it was still of interest.I also liked the fact that most of the story was fairly calm and carefully blended with the fewer rough moments. It was a film more about tolerance and acceptance than their opposite, prejudice, as well as an exploration of the lead characters self, away from what appeared to be a bad element, in the form of the American soldiers. The one thing that always amazes me though is how bad the Americans make themselves look in some of these films. It's almost as if they were saying that for every good man in the US, there were 60 or 70 bad ones to undo all the hard work that he had achieved.With that aside, I will no longer groan when I see this in the TV guide, but I will still have to consider if I have the time to watch it again when there are other films still out there to be watched. It was definitely one to be recommended for the beautiful way in which most of it was filmed and for its peaceful and easy qualities for the most part.759.81/1000.

reviews.review_title: A tale that should have been told long before
reviews.content: Dances With Wolves is a sweeping, touching, apology for the genocide of almost all the Native American people by the United States Government. Kevin Costner shows patience and an eye for the beauty of serenity in his direction, acting, and writing.  His film is three hours and is slow, but instead of dragging, he gives us a gentle appreciation for the Native American culture and its love of nature.  It is three hours of beautiful poetry, and tells a tale that should have been told long before.

reviews.review_title: Not as good as I used to think, but still a great film
reviews.content: My view of this film has changed, but it's still great in many ways. I still never tire of watching the buffalo hunt, and the period is brought to life marvellously. The extensive use of the Lakota language, even if flawed, is immensely admirable and educational, as is the portrayal of Native peoples in a positive light.But the portrayal of the Sioux is perhaps too positive, and that of the Pawnee too negative. As with Last of the Mohicans, the good guy Natives are Elves, while the bad guy Natives are Orcs. The Sioux and the Mohicans are graceful and respectable, while the Pawnee and Huron are bloodthirsty and barbaric. The Sioux and Mohicans are also long-haired and handsome, while the Pawnee and Huron are bald, unsavoury, and smeared in frightening war paint. The two films demonize the Pawnee and Huron in order to garner more sympathy for the Sioux and Mohicans. Kind of insulting if you ask me, to all four tribes. And while the film is commendable for portraying Native peoples (the Lakota anyway) in a positive light for a change, it seems to give the false impression that the Lakota were all saints. Some real-life Lakota carried out brutal attacks, against the supposedly exceptionally savage Pawnee no less, burning their lodges and killing women and children. Look up the Battle at Blue Coat's Village, and also Massacre Canyon.People go on about the Americans being portrayed as all vulgar and repulsive, but I'm not sure this is fair. A very small amount of Americans appear substantially in the film, and it is easy to imagine that the behaviour and attitudes depicted actually would've happened. It's hard to tell if Kevin Costner intended to give a blanket portrayal of them, because the Lieutenant who questions him is a good character. There's even a deleted scene where Dunbar stops Wind in His Hair from scalping his dead body.Sticking with appearance, although the period is brought to life really well, the Sioux always look like they've just stepped out of the shower, while the Americans are always dirty (Timmins especially) and the Pawnee are always sweaty. These contrasts kind of take me out of the period a bit.Stands With a Fist is another contentious character. It's quite a coincidence, isn't it, that there just happens to be a white woman living with Dunbar's Sioux neighbours. And of course he just so happens to fall in love with HER. But it is a plausible situation. And if he prefers the white woman over all the Sioux women, that's his choice. It's also an interesting dynamic. But I still would've preferred if Dunbar had fallen in love with a Lakota woman. There wasn't any real intimate interaction between Dunbar and a Lakota person. He always seemed kind of distant from them.Probably the most common critique of this film is that it's a condescending White Saviour film. This is just not true at all. I mean Dunbar gives the tribe a heads up on the presence of buffalo, and he evens the odds against the attacking Pawnee by giving the Sioux the guns from the fort. How is he a messianic figure? He's just helping them out and earning their respect. If anything the Sioux save Dunbar, I mean they literally do at the end of the film.Overall I still like the film, but not as much as I used to. I still think it deserves an 8/10, but that's down from the 10 I used to give it.

reviews.review_title: Nicely constructed and unfolded piece about a man's isolation in a location he's in so as to fight, but ends up encountering so much more.
reviews.content: The Dances With Wolves from which the title derives is the name given to Kevin Costner's Union Army Lieutenant, named John Dunbar, by the Native Americans he'll come to reside with. It's a touching moment, one of rather a few in a 1991 piece directed by Costner himself, and gets across a sense of equality between two sides whom come together through an entire clan representing one and and a lone individual representing another. The film sprawls over a number of various genres, ranging from war to romance to western, but is never sprawling in the negative sense; all this eye for scope and extravagance nicely reigned in by a man doing just as well in front of the camera as behind it. Set during The American Civil War and running on hostilities between the north and south as well as the Native Americans and the issues they have with rival clans of their own kind, the film is wonderfully low-key in its dramatisation of all this conflict and hatred boiling up between individuals; Costner's presence as this Lieutenant acting as this rock on which to map onto and observe. After all, the film unfolds in the beautiful locale of 19th Century North America - the film obliging in focusing on all the beauty of this place at times such as these amidst all the hatred and warfare, in the views; naturality of the place and eventually the love with a young Native American woman.In Dunbar, we have a lead the film is unashamedly proud in detailing as softly centered and understanding as possible. Positively pacifist in mostly everything he does, Dunbar represents the very antithesis to a Spagetti Western lead; adopting traits that are more suited to more classical western leads of great honour, courage and moral value whom are only ever as violent as they need to be when drawn into duels with the wicked. Dunbar's first action is to essentially win a battle between Union and Confederate soldiers without shooting or harming anyone. He does this by way of engaging in a suicidal act that'll come to double up as one of sheer bravery, but without ever actually killing or harming anybody; a riding up to the enemy on a horse, sacrificial Christ like pose in-tow, as enough confusion and doubt is implanted within the minds of the enemy that a frontier charge occurs.This heroic act, in the eyes of his superiors, is enough to warrant a repositioning to another front; something Dunbar requests when his dream, it appears, is to get as much out of this conflict as possible by journeying far and wide so as to lap up the surroundings amidst the ugliness of war. His posting does not go so well in the initial stages, the camp is devoid of other people and that sense of being all alone and rather vulnerable is put across by way of some uncanny stumblings across of dead animals in nearby ponds of water and an interruption to his stay in the cabin on behalf of his horse giving him a jump. It's here the film gives itself time to construct a sensitive and methodical portrait of Dunbar, a man that writes a journal in a warm and reassuring manner getting across a sense of caring to go with prior positive traits. The film goes on to use the inclusion of an animal, in this case a wolf whom Dunbar names Two Socks, to reaffirm positive; uplifting and caring traits so as to assure us our siding with him. To enhance positive characteristics, the film has Dunbar refrain from deeming the wolf a pest and therefore killing him, instead opting to write about him, in a glorious tactic designed to evoke a sense of creation in reaction to the wolf rather than destruction.But in doing so is not enough to criticise the film, rather acts as a necessary place so as to point out the time the film takes to establish character prior to the meat of the piece, that being the coming together of Dunbar with some local Native Americans; the kind that are far peaceful than certain other tribes in the area. Dunbar is bathing when the Natives first arrive, a moment in which he is at his most vulnerable and in the rawest of forms; an event that sees him cleansed of his uniform and all things that I.D. him as what he is just as those he'll come to bond with arrive for the first time. When time comes to interact with the clan on a greater scale, it'll be by way of Stands With A Fist (McDonnell), a young Native girl who's attempted suicide but is found by Dunbar, and then we remember well into his bond with them that mostly all of the people of his own kind he's interacted with so far have been anything but relatable: eccentric higher-ups and grotty waggon drivers, the latter of whom Dubar describes as "probably one of the foulest men I've met in my life". Dunbar connects with her because of a shared sense of alienation to the group, Stands With A Fist initially being an outsider adopted in much to the relevance of Dunbar's eventual arc towards these people.The film runs on the idea of finding solace and peace in times of war with those that you ought to be fighting, its foot entrenched in documenting the ordeals of a more classical western lead in Dunbar is deliberately clashed only with the idea to come to terms with the Native Americans, or Apaches, and come to understand them rather than utilise them as some persistently ominous, deadly off screen threat. Rather, Dances With Wolves reserves this role for that of the Ameircan soldiers as the film progresses; completing Dunbar's realisation of both the beauty of the locale and the people that inhabit it. The film is an affecting effort, broad in a sense of scope and style.

The Civil War as seen through the eyes of Union Army Lieutenant Dunbar(Kevin Costner). It is 1863 and due to injury, Dunbar is given a horse and decides to ride out to an abandoned fort which he rebuilds by himself, as he seeks solitude after the horrors of battle.Dunbar eventually befriends a Sioux tribe and even learns their customs, and helps them in a battle with a rival tribe. He falls in love with the chief's adopted daughter. Dunbar finds a wolf and it follows him. The chief names Dunbar dances with wolves. The wolf and Costner travel together and the scenery is spectacular. The three hour length of the film is not a problem, as nothing is filler. Bravo to Kevin Costner's for a wonderful vision.

...Why almost?Well, at the beginning I must admit, that this is the one of the best westerns and certainly, one the best movies, that shows the suffering of the proud native Americans. It got everything...beautiful original music, some humor scenes, nice love story, great acting of Indian people.What's missing then?Hmmm , since I watched the directors version, which is around 4 hours long, I was from time to time bored. Or maybe was the problem, that I wasn't very convinced by Costner's play.I guess that I would rate this movie better (especially because of the ending scene, which one of the best I have ever seen) if I saw the short version and that's why a very solid grade of8 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Believe it or not, romance has a role in film.
reviews.content: Dancing with Wolves is a monumental romantic film about a time that was far, far more bloody and disgusting than anything seen in the movie. Having said that, I believe that there is a place in cinema for these beautiful, expansive films that yes, colour the reality of history but anybody with a brain knows the movie is doing this. However, it is okay because there is room for a little romance in the movies. Not necessarily stupidity but something between the harshness of a documentary and the silliness of something out of the Disney studio.The negative comments that centre on the influence of what these commentators call Leftywood is fabulously funny because they show themselves to be totally ignorant of history of their own country. Just because these conservatives do not wish to believe that the depredations of their country were so horrendous, does not detract an iota from the fact that it happened.Dances is a fabulous film and I will admire it for decades.

reviews.review_title: Epic Length, Epic Lands, Epic Costner
reviews.content: (Flash Review)A civil war hero, played by who else but Costner, from the civil war era, gets reassigned and chooses to head west to see the vast Frontier. He ends up at an outpost in nowheresville, South Dakota where he slowly encounters a tribe of Sioux Indians. Much of the story revolves around them accepting him, earning each other's trust over time and wouldn't be complete without a semi-unique romance story line. What turmoil will ensue when the 'white man' makes their way west? The film paints a fairly realistic picture and plants many nuggets of foreseeable emotional sadness, as one would envision the story arc to play out, yet few that I anticipated actually occurred. The three hours gives ample time for thorough character development as it should with its sprawling and calm pacing. The portrayal of the American soldiers felt a bit stereotypically heavy-handed. Great acting yet Costner's narration felt flat. This is the definition of an epic film.

I like a lot of others don't see how this didn't crack the top 250 list it only got a 7.8 rating. I think it needed about an 8.5 or somewhere in that area. I had never seen this movie until about a year ago. I thought it wasn't going to catch my attention(I was wrong) even though it got 7 Academy Awards including Best Picture and Best Director, but it got my attention through the entire 3 hours and i loved this film. If you haven't seen it watch it and you will feel for Kevin Costner's character and you will feel deeply for the Sioux Indians. It can make you laugh at some points, and it can make you cry at some points, but most of all you will enjoy it and for those of you who don't like Kevin Costner all that much you will still love this film.

I watched it when it emerged and it was sensational, and not necessarily in a lasting sense. The direction was professional in its ability to bring in the level of response that the audience should have at its very melodramatic points, yet they were indeed melodramatic.On repeated watchings, this film becomes more dull and uninteresting. Films should last more than a decade. This film will not. It is more about late 80s hair styling in the nineteenth century wild west than it is about substance or intrigue. It's not terrible, but it is not lasting.Such is the legacy of many popular films.

reviews.review_title: One of the Best movies I've ever seen
reviews.content: I thought that this was one of the best movies I had ever seen - definitely NOT overrated.  Moved me to tears.  I didn't know it was a long movie until someone told me much later.  It is full of action and engaging throughout.

If you consider this film awful then you can't say different from The Last Samurai (a film that borrowed the concept from this one), which in fact is in Tom Cruise's part self-indulgent. Although there's been a lot of bad rap about this film gaining awards people forget that this year (2004) a totally undeserving film was showered with Oscars, Lord of the Rings 3. Of course no one complains because it's an adventure fantasy epic containing lots of action (CGI) and pretentious drama. It's easy to hate a film like this one. What's not to hate for today's audience in a film that takes place in the old West with "indians" and a Union captain becoming friends with them. Westerns are not as popular as fantasy epics or even epics at all. By epics I don't mean grandeur quality films like Russian Ark, The Thin Red Line, Andrei Rublev, or The Seven Samurai, but mediocre ones such as Troy. This is a film that John Ford, Howard Hawks, David Lean, and maybe even Kurosawa (who was still alive at the time) would have loved.

reviews.review_title: More than any other, a film that touches me deep in my soul.
reviews.content: Every time I see it, "Dances with Wolves" touches something ancient in me that still grieves for the loss of the way of life and for the place that was once this land. The line at the end in which the Indian says "I will never forget" especially triggers something within that knows that in another time I lived on those plains and loved them deeply, that I, too, made promises to guard the earth and never, never to forget... Feel the tenderness for the earth as the Sioux man caresses the grasses of his beloved prairies...Feel the passion as Dunbar dances around the campfire. Feel the gentleness of his love for the people and the land. I treasure the sensitivity and spirituality in those who created this masterpiece and find it hard to understand how anyone could seriously fault this brilliant movie. Dunbar's/Costner's  transformation into the Sioux way is compelling, stirring, agonizing, funny, beautiful. Thank you, Kevin Costner, if you ever read this, for letting those of us who have these feelings know that we are not alone and that we will never forget. For me, this is more than a film; it's a spiritual journey to the homeland of my soul, perhaps to all human souls, who lived in this way for far longer than we have lived in this modern, built world. This film gives a voice to my heart. And is it the ancient heart of us all?

The movie took a different approach when looking at the native american cultures. Instead of characterizing the Sioux as the enemies, they highlighted the misunderstandings that stop the white settlers from peacefully coexisting with them. It focused more on the hardships of the Sioux and why white people viewed their culture as a threat but showed that it was not impossible to make peace. Dances with Wolves overall highlights the mistakes that white people make and the assumptions that they have about native cultures. The cinematography was high quality for a 90s movie but the thing that really makes this movie so great is the story and the message it sends.

1st watched 5/15/2010 -- 7 out of 10 (Dir-Kevin Costner): Captivating and emotional drama about a Lieutenent in the civil war sent to an abandoned post who discovers friendship and family with a Sioux Indian tribe. This first Kevin Costner directorial effort is a mostly well done chronicle with a few very strange characters near the beginning of the movie but once Costner's character is by himself and encounters the tribe the movie gets much better. This is one of the first movies that depicts things from the Indian's perspective when it comes to the whiteman's discovery of the West. The whitemen are portrayed as mostly selfish buffoons while the Indians are portrayed as thoughtful and wise. This one-sided vision is a little overdone, but I guess we need to makeup for all the times when the cliché Indian-whiteman portrayal was done in so many other movies. Costner's character befriends the tribe, falls in love with a white woman adopted by the tribe at an early age, and fights with the tribe defending their colony and then eventually has to decide which life he should hold onto. The love story is well done and Mary McDonnell as the love interest as well as the other Indian portrayals are done very well. This is overall a good movie that was possibly a little over-heralded when it first came out, but it is definitely well worth the viewing despite it's 3 hour length.

This is one of my favorite movies of all time. Not only does it provide a full-absorption perspective of a culture that is virtually non-existent, it also depicts a sadly accurate portrayal of life in the Midwest plains. Kevin Costner did an exquisite job of playing a disenchanted soldier looking for fulfillment and purpose in his life. Graham Greene, Rodney A. Grant, and Mary McDonnell all played their parts of Sioux Indians magnificently, stirring the needed amounts empathy and hope for an epic movie such as this. Despite some very minor historical inaccuracies, I believe this movie delivers a message about American History better than any book can, and one that we should not be so quick to forget. There is majesty in freedom, and that was taken away from many Indians, not just the Sioux. They are the true American natives, and watching this movie with an open mind and heart is the least tribute we can pay to them.

Dances with Wolves is a great film experience. It is a story of humanity, a love of nature and a personal journey. Kevin Costner becomes immersed in the Native American way of life and embraces his new life.The story, lessons and unique soundtrack is a treat to watch. It should definitely feature on everyone's bucket list. I would not say this film deserved the Oscar over the masterpiece Goodfellas but this is a truly great film that deserves praise. 8/10

This was movie thrust upon me by my old history teacher, whom made us watch this about 3 times, every time I was bored to tears!Long, boring and pointless, I found no joy in this movie other than the excruciating dialog ("If he comes back tomorrow, I will name him Two Socks", "I p*ssed my pants and I don't care", "Tonka Tonka") which I still quote to this day. Even Kevin Costner (the man, the myth, the legend) was bored throughout this movie! This film is a Kevin Costner vanity project - no more2/10 stars, despite my absolutely hatred for this movie, it has provided many in-jokes.

reviews.review_title: Wonderfully and in details done masterpiece!
reviews.content: What is great about this film is that the plot itself completely fits in Costner's directing view which has easy pace and deep processed content. Furthermore, the way Costner displays such strong feelings as friendship( for example how wolf sacrifices himself for Lt. Dunbar and even how wolf hesitates to eat Dunbar's ham until it makes sure that he means well) and patriotism( in its true sense: battle for your people not country) and of course love( in a way that is not sneeze to watch, quite opposite). He dares criticize the way how American's treated Indians which sends humane message and shows how Kevin Costner's views are wide and beyond the limits( those opinions initiated the creation of the movie).Costner did the job perfectly and I'd like people not to question academy's decision to award this movie before Goodfellas for example( which is also a fantastic movie). I would recommend this movie to anyone because it will make an impression most likely.

reviews.review_title: 'Dances With Wolves' - the definition of an epic film
reviews.content: Dances With Wolves is my favorite film for many reasons. It isn't very often that a movie tears my heart and leaves an everlasting mark on my soul.It was an emotional drama mixed with elements of action, adventure, romance, and some comedy. Above all, it was a tribute to the spirit, courage and selflessness of a man who wanted to see the frontier before it disappeared.I still find it hard to put the feelings it evoked into words. Any picture from the movie can say it all. The cinematography is gorgeous and the actors are clearly dedicated. Beautiful, poignant, and brilliant.Dances With Wolves should never be forgotten or passed into history, like the horse culture was.

reviews.review_title: The strangeness of this life cannot be measured
reviews.content:
Lt. John J. Dunbar, a decorated Civil War hero, requests to be positioned at an outpost on the edge of the frontier. In his own words, "I've always wanted to see the frontier, before it's gone."Upon arriving at the outpost Dunbar
finds it completely abandoned. He secures all provisions, sets up secure outlooks, and
waits for reinforcements to arrive,, however long that might take. Aside from his trusted horse, Dunbar's only other company comes in the form of a solitary wolf, which John names "Two Socks."Dunbar spends time everyday writing the details of his journey in his journal. Hoping the details of his day to day life will prove helpful at some point in the future.One day, while Dunbar is at the creek doing laundry, a Sioux Indian arrives at the outpost. John scares the Sioux off quickly,, but not
long after the Indian returns with a small group, and Dunbar begins to open up communcations with the tribe. Upon visiting their village, Dunbar finds that the Sioux have a white woman in their tribe, which helps their communication move along much quicker (seeing as how the woman can understand both English and Sioux languages). Over the course of the next year or so, Dunbar spends more time with the tribe than he does at the outpost, and eventually becomes a part of the tribe when he marries the white woman (Stands with a Fist).As the harsh winter begins to set in, the Sioux look to move to their winter camp, and John realizes that his journal is still at the outpost. Knowing that his detailed journey is too important to leave behind, John sets out to retrieve the book as the tribe begins their journey.Upon arriving to the outpost, John is shocked to find that his reinforcements had finally arrived, and in great number. The soldiers capture John and interrogate him. He tells them to look at the journal, that it explains everything that has occured since he arrived. When asked whether they found anything, the soldiers who arrived first both lie and say they found no journal. John is then escorted away from the outpost by a group of soldiers, to be tried for desertion and hanged. Thankfully, his Sioux brethren have been following the soldiers, and ambush them to free John, killing every soldier in the process.After John and his Sioux brethren arrive at the winter camp, John informs the Sioux counsel that he will now be seen as a traitor, and will be a wanted man. That while killing the soldiers that captured him was a good thing, people will come looking for him and will
kill the entire tribe in the process of apprehending a traitor like him. After much discussion, John tells the counsel that he and his wife must leave and go to speak to those who would listen.After John and his wife leave, a military unit led by a Pawnee tracker find the winter camp, but the Sioux have disappeared almost without a trace of ever being there.Wow,, it's really hard to believe this movie came out 32 yrs ago!! It was such a big movie during my childhood (like Indiana Jones, Star Wars, etc). It still stands up as one of the all time greats of my lifetime. All of the Oscar wins were very well deserved! 8.5 rating!!(I saw in another review something about this movie depicting the noble savage and white savior, or something. It sounded like woke nonsense imo. I didn't, and still don't see any of that. Imo, the character of John J. Dunbar/Dances with Wolves was that of a good, very decent man/soldier who while trying to fulfill his role of a soldier happened upon a group of people whom he befriended, a woman he fell in love with, and found a home, family, and purpose that he never imagined before. That's what I saw in this movie.As far as towards the end of the movie when the soldiers have Dunbar, and the Sioux kill the soldiers to save John. I saw that as a terrible "it's either them or us" scenario. The soldiers weren't evil. Some were scoundrels and needed a lot of whoopins,, but not evil. If the Sioux hadn't taken them down, then John was gonna die. Sad, that it came to that,, but it's nothing new in the world.)

If you love Kevin Coster, you'll love this film.  If you hate Kevin Costner, you'll still love this film! This film must be seen on the big screen to really appreciate it, though.  After seeing it in the theater and then purchasing the movie and watching it at home, it was a little disappointing. On a regular TV screen is an injustice to the film.  Actually, I first read the book and even enjoyed that more than the film!!  It portrays Indians in a more realistic manner than the old black and white movies where the Indians were ALWAYS bad.  This movie deserves a lot of credit all the way around.  It deserved all the Academy Awards it received and more!!

This is an awesome epic of a movie.  Stunning scenery, compelling script, very well-done by Mr. Costner.  I didn't feel it was too long at all.  At times painful to watch, but that is the reality of our history.  At the very least it may encourage you to do some research into native American life.  I wasn't there, so I can't say whether Costner's representation is exactly true, which is a point that seems to bother many people.  I found it to be a tribute to the Native Americans and not a glorification of some wonderful white guy who showed up to save them all.  Costner's character in fact brought danger to these people ( which leads to a very emotional, powerful ending ).  It is clearly shown that *they* taught *him*, not vice versa.A masterpiece of a movie, worthy of the awards it won.

reviews.review_title: First Time Viewer- Forever Love It!
reviews.content: I know It came in 1990, but wow this film was such a wonderful burst of fresh air. The story is absolutely perpetually relevant and incredibly endearing. Kevin Costner and cast all gave spot on performances. Even though it comes in at 3 hours you'll wish it was 5 hours long. The story was that engaging. The cinematography was beautiful and epic. The music score powerful and moving. The message?... Hopefully a learned lesson for all of us. I'm glad I caught this Gem as a matured 30 year old and not sooner. I could probably sit and watch this story in 3 hour weekly episodes. Just fantastic. Obviously a classic. Oscar well deserved.

reviews.review_title: Historical movie in more ways than one
reviews.content: This Kevin Costner epic will undoubtedly never blow away with the wind, as a memorable and historical western, which for one - marks a new phase in relations with Native Americans. Most importantly "Dances with Wolves" sets a point in time, where native American culture can no longer be portrayed as savage, with incoming immigrants bringing with them technology, progress and the American dream. Now tainted, it could be said that one myth (of the civilisational conquering of the wild west) was supplanted by romanticised wigwams, but the latter for one thing is a much closer account of historical facts. Despite certain elaborated idealisation of Sioux life, this is a far cry from your mystical tree-hugging pacifists (aptly portrayed as being ruthless in warfare).However pointless this may be given the far-reaching recognisability of the movie, a short recap of the: Lt. John Dunbar (Kevin Costner) is sent out to the west to guard the frontier, while the rest of the country is in civil turmoil. The post is completely deserted apart from a stray wolf, who slowly grows an affinity to the kind-hearted man. Waiting for reinforcements to arrive, the first to contact him are his neighbours, the Sioux, with whom he soon forms a close familial relation, slowly immersing into their culture and way of life. Meanwhile chance encounters with bison hunters, cavalry troopers and loggers, have Dunbar grow increasingly disillusioned with his own kind...Rewatching the movie over twenty years after it received a multitude of Oscars (including Best Picture and Best Director), the widespread appeal of the movie has not faltered, still a touching, awe-inducing epic of stark significance to mainstream perceptions of American history. Certain aspects of the story-telling are simplistic and unrefined, often supplanting more cognitive portrayal of Sioux society with opportunities to bring in a hearty laugh. This doesn't however take away the charm of Costner's legendary feature, as comedy basically offers light-hearted respite from the inevitable downfall of the American Indians and the natural habitat in which they resided.The extended four hour cut undoubtedly has its coherence issues, as some scenes are visibly less well-rounded, often superfluous or just jarring. Nonetheless they do add to the overall scope and emotional pull of the story, hence all in all they largely feel best kept untouched.

Dances with wolves is one of only two films that have changed my perspective on life. The other is The Shawshank Redemption, but Shawshank change me in a completely different way. Dance with Wolves taught me about the past, told me about how the Americans were. The length of the film does make some of the viewing uncomfortable, but once finished, it adds to the relief of the final scene.I think that Costner does a great job with his acting and Directing. The fact that for one hour of the film we do not see any communication apart from Costner's narration and with the wolf. The film exceeds in all ways and with go down as one of my favourite films of all time.

Dances With Wolves is one of the BEST movies i have watched and i really admired it the first time i watched it when it came out. I have always loved movies that involved native Indians and of their reservations. Kevin Costner has always been a big favorite of mine and i love all movies he has been in. The "Dances With Wolves" movie was very well put together and i have watched it so many times. The story of the movie is beautiful and outstanding. Other actors in movie i have also admired were Rodney A. Grant, Mary McDonnell, Graham Greene, and Tantoo Cardinal. This is a movie i would watch everyday and never get tired of it. It is rated to be THE BEST!

reviews.review_title: Good Movie but Not Really Oscar-worthy
reviews.content: **May Contain Spoilers** I like Westerns, and Kevin Costner doesn't really bother me; but this movie just wasn't as good as I had heard/hoped.The things I dislike most? (1) The simplistic approach to good guys/bad guys: Lakota=good; white people (except John and Stands With Fist)=bad. Give me a break! (2) Kevin as John Dunbar wasn't a horrible casting decision, but his narration was terribly wooden and sleep-inducing. (3) Mary McDonnell's portrayal of Stands With Fist. Okay, first of all, her whole existence in the movie just screams, "Contrivence!" Second, MM's performance was awful. Her attempts to remember English were bizarre and not believable. It was the reverse awfulness of someone doing a bad foreign accent. Third, the hair, OMG, the hair! Why was Stands With Fist wearing bad Eighties hair with highlights? I would think that after spending most of her life with the Lakota and adopting everything else of their lifestyle (dress, work around the village, marriage into the tribe, language), someone would plait that woman's hair. The hair just completely took me out of the movie every time MM showed up on screen. Kevin's was pretty bad, too; but it was not nearly as 80s as MMs. (4) Kevin's complete "grasp" of the Lakota's language. Was he a savant? I could see if he were still kinda stumbling and fumbling with the language, as many adult learners of other languages do; but Kevin was having long, meaningful discussion with tribe elders in a language he couldn't have begun learning more than a few weeks before. I know I'm supposed to suspend my belief here, but some things are just too incredible to believe.I wouldn't call this a turkey, but it was about two hours too long and full of enough faults to make me believe that it only garnered the Oscar because of the preachy, PC message, not because of any real substance.

reviews.review_title: When view in retrospect to much politics
reviews.content: Its a great movie and it had the potential to be a 10, but the movie tries hard to bash "the white man" and be very forgiving on the indians themselves, and propagates the white man as an invasive species in a really exaggerated form, although history has shown that indians themselves were invasive settlers on the American continent a couple of hundreds years ago. Otherwise its a great movie, the scenes are more amazing than in movies of todays and the lack of computer generated graphics is a bliss. Costner does a very good job in this movie as does his counterpart Mary McDonell. Quite fun to see Wes Studi as the bad guy Indian in this movie as well.

reviews.review_title: How Is This Kevin Costner's Directorial Debut!?!
reviews.content: 1990 was a year that produced many top-tier films. Goodfellas is one of my favorite movies and in any other year, I would have been angry about it not winning the top prize. In 1990, it had to contend with the behemoth known as Dance with Wolves, a film that is also one of my favorite films of all time. Kevin Costner's epic was released at a time where westerns were presumed dead. Costner had plenty of trouble trying to secure financing for his project. Yet he worked his magic and made a film that is reminiscent of a John Ford western. What really stands out is how respectful Costner is to the Sioux tribe and Native Americans in general. We need to face the facts that Americans has seen the Indians as savages and predators and were not worthy of their lands which is why they kept being pushed west for the plight of the white man. As evidenced from the westerns of the 40's, racism was always a factor when it came to Native Americans. Costner treated these tribes like people and even incorporated the native language, despite less than 100% accuracy, into the film. There is romance here, but any romantic cliches were avoided in order to create a more accurate depiction. Politics aside, Dean Semler shot the film with such stunning cinematography work. The Dakotas really do have magnificent scenery and Semler took advantage of that. John Barry created one of the best scores in modern film history. John Dunbar's theme is remarkable in how easy it was to invoke emotion from me while holding true to the story.There is no doubt Costner was at the top of his game in the late 80's, early 90's era. In addition to his memorable performances in films like Field of Dreams, he made his directorial debut here which ended up with a whopping total of 12 Academy Award nominations. For a first-timer that directed a three-hour long Western, there should have been no way the film got the recognition it did. Costner directed the film as if he was Steven Spielberg. He showed such poise behind the camera working with Semler and the rest of the crew. Semler's shots were confident and steady. As mentioned, it took some time to fly off the ground. In the mid-80's, screenwriter Michael Blake wrote his movie as a speculative script that went unsold. Costner convinced him to turn the script into a novel so it would be easier to sell. Costner purchased the rights. With the Western genre being a near extinct genre and Blake's script being massive as it was, studios turned their nose at the script. Costner and his producing partner Jim Wilson were finally able to strike a deal with Orion. I can describe Blake's screenplay and Costner's directing style as patient. As a member of the audience, patience is required to feel the full effect that Costner and Blake were aiming for. After the Academy Awards were over, there was another cut of the film made. One that added an hour to the film...and it received rave reviews. It must have been nearly impossible to edit the movie!The story itself is very simple, but it is told with clarity and precision. The film is narrated and told from the view of John Dunbar (Kevin Costner), a lieutenant in the Union Army. He runs away from a field hospital where his foot was going to be amputated and instead leads a suicidal charge against the Confederates. He survives and is given any post he wanted. He chooses an isolated post in the frontier, the only white man around for miles. He makes first contact with the Sioux and begins to study and learn from them. The tribe wants to learn from Dunbar because they are keenly aware that the white man is pushing them away. Over time, Dunbar learns who these people are and is welcomed as a member of the tribe. His given name is "Dance with Wolves." He falls in love with Stand with a Fist (Mary McDonnell). She is a white woman who was adopted by the tribe after her parents were killed...something that screenwriter Blake based off in real life. Dunbar was able to look past any prejudices to learn about and become a member of the Sioux. He understands why they fight and live they way they do. Ultimately, that will most likely put him at odds with the Americans moving west along the frontier.Costner delivers an incredible performance. He uses comedy to counterbalance the drama at times. For example, take how he and the Sioux first try to communicate with each other. He is prancing around like a buffalo trying to get them to understand the word "buffalo." Of course, the Sioux thought he lost his marbles until they understood what he was trying to say. I laughed during the scene, but it was an important scene that set the stage for what's next. I liked that Costner tried to be authentic when casting the Native Americans. We got to know key member of the tribes, especially Kicking Bird (played by Graham Greene) and Wind in His Hair (played by Rodney A. Grant). It didn't feel like they were acting. I felt like I was there as a member of the tribe.I loved Dance with Wolves. It is my favorite film of 1990...and it seems like many people agree. It can be excessive in its length...but every scene matters in the entire context of the story. Costner was very respectful telling the story the way it needed to be told. Native Americans were not the bad guys. They were just people trying to live and eat and protecting their way of life. Costner took that main point and then followed the John Ford format with a beautiful score and sweeping cinematography to create something special...something that revitalized the near-dead genre.My Grade: A+

reviews.review_title: Actually, a Great Kevin Costner Film
reviews.content: The late Pauline Kael once commented that this is Costner's "Plays with Camera" movie.  I strongly disagree.  This movie has a beautiful sweeping feel to it similar to Out of Africa.  Everyone comments on the cinematography -- and that's because it's lovely, appropriate, and the movie's centerpiece.  Too bad Costner let this movie go to his head and subsequently made one bad judgment after another.  One could easily reach the conclusion that Costner could never have made this movie and it must be a big inside joke. Anyway, this movie kicks Braveheart all over the map.

reviews.review_title: A glimpse of the wild west frontier ...
reviews.content:
While the plot of the movie itself is unimpressive and obvious, the movie scores well in all the other aspects.
1. The actors have given justice to their characters, especially the tribal leaders. The emotions are depicted appealingly
2. The viewer gets a brief idea about the lifestyle of the Indian tribes, the climate of the wild west, the situation of frontiers during the civil war, the wanton and marauding behaviour of the white hunters, the enmity and skirmishes between the tribes, the survival challenges posed by the Americans to the ethnic Indians and so on
3. The cinematography highlights the above aspects quite wellThere are several shortcomings:
1. The background score is not only monotonous and an overkill but almost no attempt is made to include any 'Indian/Native' flavour!
2. The theatrical run was almost three hours but I landed with an extended version of 4 hours! While I managed to watch the entire movie, I couldn't figure out what did they gain by adding another 60 minutes? They could have focused on the developments in the Union, the Indian Wars and so on but the movie simply revolves around the life in the tribal campOverall, the movie is good watch if you have the patience to watch a 4-hour long movie.

reviews.review_title: A simple yet beautiful tale of friendship and loyalty
reviews.content: 'Dances with Wolves' is a good example of how far a simple story can go. This slow-burning, low-key Western is a heartwarming tale of friendship and loyalty. It's a film with a purpose and a big heart. The focus on plot and character development is always refreshing to see and the stunning scenery and cinematography make it a pleasure to watch.While the film has a lot going for it, there are a few noticeable weak spots. I can't help but feel Kevin Costner is more comfortable behind the camera directing than on screen. While his performance in this film is okay, a better actor would have done Dunbar's character more justice. There's also the excessive running time, which is felt at times due to the slow nature of the film. That said, these are only minor points in what is a special and memorable film.

Continuing my viewing of the AFI's 100 best, I recently rented the four hour version of Dances With Wolves. I had never watched such a lengthy film before and after I had been told by a few friends that this movie was at times tedious and slow, I feared the worst. However, this film is a work of greatness and kept my attention so well, I didn't notice the time at all.This movie is an eye opener to the struggles that the Sioux natives and I'm sure many other factions of natives had to go through during the second half of the 19th century. With the huge migration of people heading west it was only a matter of time until they were wiped out by the white man and his machines of war.This is a special movie for many reasons in my mind. First, it does a splendid job in describing the relationship between the Sioux and Lt. Dunbar from the beginning to the end. It is this relationship that the movie is based upon, and what makes the movie work so well. While watching the movie, I felt that I was Lt. Dunbar, not a third party watching the happenings. Secondly, the cast of Costner, Greene and McDonnell plays well together and perhaps should have been recognized by the academy. I can't really understand all that I've heard about how Costner's performance was lacking, because after all it is the center of the movie. Thirdly, the direction and cinematography of this film rank up there with such epics as Schindler's List and Lawrence of Arabia. It is basically flawless and plays the second most important role in the film.The story is told to every last detail and blended together perfectly. The ending also fits well and doesn't disappoint. I find it amazing that this great film was also Costner's directoral debut. This adds even more to the total greatness of the film which in my opinion is the best that has come out of the 90's.9/10 stars.

reviews.review_title: In my top Ten Greatest Films
reviews.content: An epic journey through one mans discovery of his soul and who is was meant to be, set against the Great Plains. Breath takingly beautiful cinematography. A movie score that captures the majesty of the land and the people that inhabit it. The Indian nations of this land haver never been depicted with such reverence as they are in this film. This is how a movie should be made

"Dances with Wolves" is a sweeping epic, beautifully photographed, edited, acted. This is definitely Kevin Costner's best movie. Though this movie did not deserve best picture the year it was released it is still a great movie. This movie is best viewed on DVD. I highly recommend this film.

reviews.review_title: On my top 5 of all time for sure..
reviews.content: I just saw the long version.. Again.. For the 10th time.. And It cracks me up... I laugh.. I cry.. I get mad... I smile.. That film is just what defines perfection.. Kevin Costner does it just as well as an actor... As he does as a director!.. Got to love Kevin for all his work and effort in the movie history.. Its around 4 hours long the special 3disc edition.. But actually.. I wish the film was even longer.. Such a wonderful ferry tail could go on forever for my taste.. I think or KNOW the movie was meant for a lot of things.. To show us how the Indians lived for example.. To show us that the simplest things in life, can be just as great as the big ones.. I don't think I have one bad thing to say about the film. reviews.review_title: Rather than play it safe for his directorial debut, Kevin Costner tackled an epic tale in a moribund genre.
reviews.content: In his directorial debut, Kevin Costner brings a rare degree of grace and feeling to this elegiac tale of a hero's adventure. The story is about a disenchanted US cavalry officer and Civil War hero who finds fulfilment living with Sioux Indians.Dances With Wolves is an epic award-winning Western with a sentimental script and a tendency to labour obvious points. Still, it remains a powerful labour of love (on Costner's part), a passionate story of the oppression of native American decency. Serious-minded acting and stunning cinematography cannot disguise its excessive length. In 2007, the Library of Congress selected Dances with Wolves for preservation in the United States National Film Registry.

Sometimes I think that maybe he made a deal with the devil to be able to produce a film with this kind of beauty. I only say that because Kevin Costner has not been very lucky since 1990 when he directed this masterpiece. But that hardly matters. This one film is worth a career. It is a lyrical, savage, and profound work of love and every frame shows it. This film also changed a lot of perceptions about Native Americans at the time. Not many films make it that far into the culture. A look a time when the European culture was beginning to supplant the civilization that preceded it, it has echoes of John Ford in its portrayal of the expansiveness and impermanence of the west, but it has a generosity of spirit toward its protagonists that Ford did not share. It is unfortunate that the film paints such an unqualified picture of the white man as Satan, but in the end, that is how he was perceived by the races he wiped out. It is a moving film set against a huge panorama. It's hard not to say that it is even "important" because that term is usually the kiss of death. But this film sustains your interest from the first frame to the last and leaves you begging for more even as it rips your heart out. See it.

Unrealistic Hollywood formula movie. The main reason I mention 'Black Robe' is that it was released a few months later, hardly seen by few, and the difference is (literally) like night and day. The costumes in Dances With Wolves look like they just came freshly pressed out of the dry cleaners, everyone's hair is washed and perfect. In 'Black Robe' their is dirt, oil, grime, and a gripping realistic story to match - much more believable. Great portrayal of the differences between Native American and European religion.For another extremely realistic movie concerning Native Americans, see 'Windwalker' - where the actors speak in the actual native tongues. This one is top-notch, with a a great surprise plot-twist that lifts this movie above and beyond.And of course, a superbly filmed, acted and directed movie about the clash between Native Americans and Europeans, between thier cultures and religions, is 'The Mission', which takes place in South America, with Robert De Niro, a young Jeremy Irons and Liam Neeson.

I first saw Dances shortly after the academy bestowed it with honors and I enjoyed it very much. I've long been aware of the shameful history of the raping of the indigenous peoples. Read many books on the subject. So, this movie touched me where I lived, and it was easy for me to relate to the Costner character and the sentiment expressed. I thought it was an excellent movie.Problem is, I tried to watch it again a few years back and I couldn't. Had to turn it off. When Costner spreads his arms out wide and prances back and forth, eyes closed, before an array of rifles firing at him and not able to hit him the thought came to me that 'this is bullshit'. Why didn't I notice how bogus this was the first time I saw it? (Actually, I did but kept watching as I'd paid good money). I guess it's supposed to signal to the viewer that this is a very special man - protected by some mystical force.Then, a while later in the film, Costner is living alone on the frontier and along comes a wild wolf that, again I guess drawn by some mysticism inherent in Costner's character, doesn't remain true to its wildness but becomes a playmate (pet) to Costner. And again came the thought 'bullshit'.Now, I know that the movie is gonna get better (I have seen it before and there's 'indians' coming) but I'm out of the film now because, apart from these incongruous scenes, Costner is boring me to tears. The fact is, he always bores me to tears. He's a very boring actor. A boring personality with a bland look. Why isn't this movie in the top 250? I think I know why.No point in going on about it. After reading four solid pages of 'greatest movie of all time' comments this one's bound to go to the back with lots of 'no' votes and I'm sorry to offend, but: good movie once - stupid movie twice. Kevin Costner is an overblown bore of an actor and his continually declining popularity is due to people realizing it as they revisit his filmography.

Also, another part that screws with me, is that the credits are 10 minutes long! The movie is Best Picture Winner, and it does not help the fact that it was nominated for 12 Oscars! 
 Now the movie is made for people who like watching animals get killed. You get emotionally attached to the wolf, horse, a dog, and half of the buffalo that get slaughtered. Screw you, Kevin. The first animal that you see dead is a dog you see arrows in it, the second animal you see get killed is all the buffalo. Then you see Robin Hood's horse get shot and burned. Also, she goes to her wedding with the worst hair humanly possible, she looks like she was trying to be Mel Gibson in Braveheart.

reviews.review_title: A Great Look Into Lakota Language, Culture, and History
reviews.content:
This film solidifies its place in history with its accurate portrayal of the Lakota.To begin with, their reaction to Lieutenant Dunbar shows how the Lakota originally reacted to the presence of white men. White men spent many years passing through Lakota lands before white people began settling there, and relations were relatively peaceful up until that point.As another example, in one scene where Kicking Bird appears shirtless, one can see the scars on his chest from the Sundance Ceremony.The visuals of the film are simply stunning, particularly the way that the majesty of the buffalo is captured.However, what makes this film truly incredible is it's use of the Lakota language, as well as the story of that use. Doris Leader Charge (Pretty Shield in the film), a Lakota language teacher at Sinte Gleska College, transformed the film with her presence and contribution. Thanks to her, this is likely the most accurate and extensive collection of a nation's language in any film. Just over a decade later, Lakota Language Consortium began a revitalization of the language.Finally, a favorite quote from the movie, and in many ways a perfect one for it:
"Nothing I have been told about these people is correct."

reviews.review_title: Incredible view of the end of the Native American heritage as it was
reviews.content: I've been very fortunate to live in the NE, MidWest and NW, and witnessed the treatment of Native Americans in each state as I grew from from childhood up. I've seen the sad reality in two of those states, which leads me to believe this is more common then not; yet I've seen the pride in their culture shine through even though we've done so much to take it away. Until I watched this film I'm ashamed I forgot what I've seen as I grew up. Thank you to the creators of this film for reminding me of what our country was (and is) but so sad this incredible culture will never be what it was once we took over the way we did. Laura

I have only seen this film once before, it was on a commercial station and (with commercials) it was so long they had to split it over two nights. The BBC finally got the rights and we get it over one afternoon (thank you BBC!). The trouble is, because it's shown in the afternoon, we get a slightly tamed down version, not that I'm complaining. But more of my nonsense later, here's a very brief summary first (summary haters please wait back at fort Hays while I write the next paragraph).Having fought and been decorated in the American Civil War, Lt. John Dunbar is offered any posting he would like. He decides to go and see the frontier, in his words, "Before it's gone." He gets a posting to Fort Hays where the commander, clearly insane, posts him on to a far-flung outpost, which he finds deserted. Finding himself alone, he is befriended by a lone wolf he calls "Two-Socks". Eventually he attracts the attention of a tribe of Sioux Indians. After a rather faltering start the two sides slowly learn to trust one another. Dunbar makes friends, including, Kicking Bird and Wind In His Hair who show him the ways of the Plains people. There is also a white woman among the tribe, Stands With a Fist; she was taken in when she lost her family at a very young age. She acts as interpreter and, eventually, she becomes very close to the young Lieutenant. There is a cloud on the horizon, however, Dunbar knows that the white men are coming and this cannot be good for the tribe.This is an epic film with some tremendous vistas; I would love to have seen it on the big screen. I love the way that Costner made all of the white people in the picture particularly loathsome (with two notable exceptions). Decent performances all round, so honourable mentions go to; Kevin Costner as Lieutenant Dunbar, Mary McDonnell as Stands With A Fist, Graham Greene as Kicking Bird, Rodney A. Grant as Wind In His Hair and Floyd 'Red Crow' Westerman as Ten Bears.I think you have to be prepared beforehand to watch this film Three hours is a long time so plenty of refreshments and control of the remote is always good (for bathroom breaks). There is a pretty slow pace to the way the story unveils, but it's worth sticking with. The final chapter does go on a little and I feel could have been cut slightly. Apart from that, it's an epic film that is well worth a viewing Recommended.My score: 8.3/10

I can not fault this film. The cinematography stunning, and the score one of the best I've ever heard. A timeless classic, deserving of all its accolades. I sobbed like a baby at the death of Two Socks and again when Wind in his Hair farewelled DWW at the end. Cannot praise this film enough. 10.

Dances With Wolves is a tremendous Movie! It's stunning visuals by Cinematographer Dean Semler, and stirring music by John Barry capture each mood of the film as we follow John  Dunbar's ( Kevin Costner ) travels from an Army Field Hospital in the Civil War, to his friendship with the Sioux Indians on the plains. Kevin Costner's direction of the Movie is superb too, with his obvious feel for not only the characters and story-line but for the landscape also. Costner shows great imagination, particularly when the story leaves the horrors of the War in the East and moves onto the endless sea of waving grassland in the West, catching the loneliness of the windswept frontier and the sadness also of the Plains Indian, ever hoping the White Man would not come their way. The film spends much of it's time exploring the Indian perspective, in particular their language, as Dunbar slowly learns their ways and culture while falling in love with Stands With A Fist, played by Mary   McDonnell. There are some sad scenes in the Movie, Dunbar losing Cisco his horse after being fired on by his own Calvary and seeing also his friend the lone wolf get shot by the same Calvarymen, but the most poignant part of the film came, ( as expected ) in the end when the Indians were fleeing the Soldiers and Dunbar, with Stands With A Fist now his bride, left to go their own way. Dances With Wolves is an outstanding Western, beautifully photographed and along with many other accolades the film has attracted, supports a balanced view of the struggle for culture and civilization.

The last hour ruined the movie. He gets his horse and wolf shot then tells the people who rescued him he's leaving. Stupid last hour that ruined the whole movie.Lt. John Dunbar is dubbed a hero after he accidentally leads Union troops to a victory during the Civil War. He requests a position on the western frontier, but finds it deserted. He soon finds out he is not alone, but meets a wolf he dubs "Two-socks" and a curious Indian tribe. Dunbar quickly makes friends with the tribe, and discovers a white woman who was raised by the Indians. He gradually earns the respect of these native people, and sheds his white-man.

Dances with Wolves follows a soldier who is posted in a largely isolated outpost and ultimately befriends the natives living in the area. The actors are all pretty good in their roles. Kevin Costner does really well, although for the first 10 or so minutes he just wanders around with his mouth open as if confused. He sort of portrayed my feelings for the first bit. I had no idea what was going on until a little ways into the movie. Graham Greene and Rodney A. Grant were both quite good in their roles as well, as as much as Costner but pretty close. Mary McDonnell was kind of over-the-top in this role, and while her performance wasn't bad, it wasn't great either. She seemed to be trying to pull off some kind of overdone insanity performance, but it didn't work in the context of the movie or just as a performance overall. The characters are pretty interesting, and it's really cool to see their relationships develop over a long period of time. By the last 1/3 of the movie the audience feels really attached to the characters, and it becomes just that much more investing. And considering the last hour is the best, it gives it a much more effective ending. The movie is, however, 3 hours long, the first 2 of which are the development stages. While it isn't necessarily boring, it's very long and definitely on the slow side. It was needed for the last hour to have the effect that it did, but it probably could have been just a little more engaging, or shorter even. The romantic aspect wasn't something I was very fond of. It came off as very rushed and a little forced, like it was happening simply because that was the expectation for movies. It seems that filmmakers sometimes think that if it's worth seeing, it has a love interest. That seems to be the case a lot of the time, but that doesn't mean that it always works. And in this case it doesn't really. Overall Dances with Wolves is an engaging character study that suffers from being on the slow side for the majority of it's runtime and a forced romance. In the end I'd still recommend this movie.
