reviews.review_title: Agreed....one of the best 15 movies of all time.
reviews.content: As an Australian with a sorry history of treating our indigenous Australians as badly as you Americans have treated yours, this was an inspiring, beautifully filmed (by an Australian - Dean Semmler) movie showing respect to your native Americans. It was a thoughtful, funny, exciting, literate, suspenseful and a gloriously beautiful movie which truthfully showed an embarrassing part of white colonialist history (the same of which occurred in many countries throughout the world). It had a lot of the spectacle and intelligence of "Lawrence Of Arabia", another of the best 15 movies of all time. Please don't be offended by the criticism of whites...we deserve it. Just be inspired by the cinematic scope, beauty and intelligence of one of the great movies of all time.

The film is visually stunning, with beautiful landscapes and detailed depictions of Native American culture. The performances are also excellent, particularly Costner's portrayal of Dunbar and Graham Greene's portrayal of Kicking Bird, the Sioux leader who befriends Dunbar. Kevin Costner's direction is excellent, too.The score by John Barry is also outstanding, creating a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack that enhances the emotional impact of the film.Overall, "Dances with Wolves" is a powerful and emotional film that explores themes of cultural identity, friendship, and the devastating impact of colonization on Native American communities.

Have you ever read an article written by a movie star where he or she talks about another movie star and you can vividly hear both their voices just as you would hear them in their movies? That happened to me while I was reading an account about the life of Clark Gable as written by his good friend David Niven. That is when you know an actor or actress has made an impression upon you. You read about them giving an account of their life involved with the lives of others and you can hear their voice as though they were having a conversation with you. Somehow their activity as a performer has become hard-wired into your memory.Thus it is with this groundbreaking film. The inspiring and uplifting themes of John Barry's musical score easily registers in my mind with pleasure. The unusually literate performances of the cast give you insights into the Lakota and Sioux cultures that create a whole new dimension of humanization for this genre of Cowboys and Indians. While Kevin Costner as Lt. John Dunbar/Dances With Wolves and Mary McDonnell as Stands With A Fist/Christine Gunther stand out in Oscar nominated roles, there are Native American actors who also represent multi-dimensional characters of beauty, wisdom, dignity, intelligence and strength. Particularly memorable are Graham Greene as Kicking Bird, Rodney A. Grant as Wind In His Hair and Floyd Red Crow Westerman as Chief Ten Bears, along with Doris Leader Charge as Pretty Shield, Chief Ten Bears wife, and Otakuye Conroy as Kicking Bird's daughter. Wes Studi, who will later be seen playing with distinction as Magua in Michael Mann's LAST OF THE MOHICANS (1992), is also memorably on board here as the Toughest Pawnee.This Western epic is definitely a drama that could never be presented on the stage. Few films have ever reveled in The Great Outdoors as this one does. The clash between cultures is thoughtfully and probingly evoked, and to see subtitles as Graham Greene and the other leading Indian principals help Costner's John Dunbar assimilate Native American culture gives this presentation of the Western Plains an air of authenticity. The liberal use of indigenous language in this film speaks well of the story to see things from the so-called 'victim's' point of view. Here and there between thrilling Buffalo Hunts we indeed learn a few things in an expansive sweep about the manners and mores of The Plains Indian.Make no mistake, however, about who is telling this story. It is not Graham Greene as Kicking Bird or Floyd Red Crow Westerman as Chief Ten Bears. This is the story of Lt. John Dunbar lately become Dances With Wolves. So we still have a ways to go before a Native American narrates an epic tale about the waning days of The Old West. But you have to give Kevin Costner credit for his empathetic retelling of bygone days when men and women and whole tribes of people made at least some attempt to harmonize their ways with the ways of Nature.This film was nominated for 12 Academy awards and won in seven categories, including Best Director for Costner. While it flirts with images of 'The Noble Savage', and definitely posits Dunbar's Dances With Wolves as a White Savior helping the Lakota win an important battle if not the war, in the end it is more about peoples seeing past competing cultural aspirations to find the good in each other. This does not diminish the fact that the Lakota, like many other tribes throughout the 48 contiguous states, will have to confront the threat of genocide as they struggle to keep their way of Life from dying out in many respects. But where this film innovates is in presenting Native Americans in a more fully human light, capable of strategizing and seizing triumph and not just bearing defeat with honor. For what it is, this is a more hopeful and faintly optimistic and, dare I say, more family friendly version of The Old West, than is to be found in Clint Eastwood's more gritty and relentlessly realistic demythologizing UNFORGIVEN (1992). While both are Best Picture winners, I'll have to tip my hat to this one for shedding its cloak of romance in a kinder and gentler way. That's why it strikes me as the CITIZEN KANE (1941) of the West.

This is a beautiful film that acts as a sort of "anti-western" and seeks to truly undo a lot of the negative stereotypes that have been placed on Native Americans over the decades, not only by Hollywood but also public consciousness in general. I particularly liked the narrative voice-over monologues that he gives reading his journal as he learns more about the Sioux people that he has encountered. Graham Greene as Kicking Bird also gives a performance that I believe deserves to be mentioned.I really enjoyed the way that the movie turns western tropes completely around. It asserts the fact that while white people claimed to have been bringing civilization to the natives, they also brought a lot of savagery and bigotry against a culture that they knew little about. Which is ironic considering their own stereotypes of the "savage Indian."If nothing more, "Dances with Wolves" is a terrific film that still holds up and will prove invaluable in the continuing conversations concerning people of other races and cultures interacting and maintaining healthy and positive relationships that can even blossom into friendship and familial bonds; not just in an historical sense like the one provided in this film, but also in today's world.

reviews.review_title: A harmony with the land, interspersed with savage tribal warfare
reviews.content: Dunbar speaks of the "harmony" with nature the Sioux have with the land, which he came to experience himself, sharing their lives. But how many viewers get this from watching the movie? I suspect it worked better on the big screen, feeling the vast expanse of earth and sky and silence. But unless you have ever been out in the empty prairie or a vast silent wilderness (something that simply does not exist in Europe) you may not understand the peace and silence of mind it produces. To attempt to recreate this is why the movie must be slow and long. This vastness and isolation is key to any good Western. In a classic Western the lone individual (or family or group, such as a wagon train) is on his own, isolated from the social norms and rule of law of civilization. He is typically pitted against raw nature and the brute force of lawless individuals, and must rely on his strength of character and wits to survive. It is a form of anomie, spiritual and social. This is what Dunbar encounters, in its purest form, in his posting to an empty frontier fort.In Westerns it is good guys vs. bad guys, which, in the old days, was cowboys vs. Injuns. Hollywood went beyond that stereotype long ago, at least since the 1960s, if not 1950s. But it is still interesting to see, through Dunbar's eyes, the transition from prejudice to understanding of Indians as human beings with families and personalities, to acknowledge the stereotypes were lies, up to a point. Those "stereotypes" would have killed him with an arrow in the back, as they did his muleteer guide and Standing with a Fist's family, had circumstances not intervened. We see the macho young Indians urging that he be killed and we see the motions of war with another Indian tribe. Though living in peace and harmony with the land, showing their bravery through killing, and risking being killed, is a fundamental part of their culture. The Whites are no different. We see White men at war, first in a clutzy Civil War battle, which is probably more typical than the dramatic scenes more often portrayed; in the early stages, the leadership was often not the boldest. Later we see the frontier soldiers, who seem to be the bottom of the barrel rejects. But they all feel they must demonstrate their warlike spirit, much like the Indians, though sometimes foolishly. People are people, regardless of their skin color or country. Have not soldiers elsewhere been equally vicious, and have not other countries, including Europe, committed genocidal murders? Does anyone remember the Belgian Congo?The viewer's first impulse is to view the Indians as the good guys, but they were not saints. But it was their land, and the Whites had no right to take it from them -- that is the bottom line. They know, thanks to Dunbar, that there will be so many White men coming that they will inevitably be overwhelmed, yet they cannot find the wisdom to know how to respond, aside from futile battle. We can see in hindsight that killing and more killing is not the answer, but that is the only way the humans on both sides know how to respond. The viewer feels sadness knowing this, and knowing that the Sioux's harmonious lifestyle will be lost.Some viewers, especially foreigners, will also feel anger and contempt for the White man, and for Americans. But what are you watching? A film made by Americans, primarily for an American audience, missing the caveats a foreigner should keep in mind. Should Americans feel ashamed? Of course, and we do, for the injustices committed against Indians in the past. One of the strengths of America is its willingness to engage in honest self-criticism and to strive for historical objectivity. America changes with time, over and over again. American movies can be a force for change, and a collective acknowledgment of that change. That is what you see in Dancing with Wolves, made two decades ago. You see a similar pro- Indian statement in A Man Called Horse, made two decades earlier, so this is not a radical new attitude, as much as a beautiful restatement. How many nations engage in such brutally honest self-criticism through their cinema? We find this in Europe and the West, and I have seen some from Japan - though not nearly enough, but such a movie of self- criticism that also glorifies individualism and repudiating the values of your society and government is unthinkable (and probably illegal) in China, and much of Asia. And so I do not consider this as an anti- American film, but very much a pro-American one, one I am proud of. A side note: I mostly agree with nebukanezer from Norway's comparison of Dances with Avatar. It does seem that James Cameron used Dances as a draft outline for his screenplay. Cameron should get over his ego and hire a real scriptwriter.Also, as to the Indians living in harmony with nature, anthropologists now know that the Plains Indians would periodically set fire to the prairie to prevent trees and bushes from growing, and to promote vegetation favorable to the buffalo. These fires, of course, killed many other animals and did significant ecological damage.Still, the White man could have learned a lot from the Indians, spiritually. The history of man's inhumanity to man is filled with sadness and regret.

reviews.review_title: Bumpy first half and an odd mood but still a good movie
reviews.content: A number of scenes in the first half of this film left me wondering, "What the hell did I just watch?" I was wondering whether I was supposed to laugh or not. If a scene ended violently I guess it was meant as serious*shoulder shrug*.In fact, there was something odd about the entire tone of the film and it dawned on me after a while: Dances with Wolves feels like a kids movie. Whether that feel was intended or not is unclear, especially considering all the blood and violence, but the movie definitely has the feel of an adventure for kids. There is a subplot with befriending a wolf and another one about a loyal horse. This movie features farts, some slapstick and I swear at one point I heard a bouncing noise like in a Hanna-Barbera cartoonbut then someone had their scalp removed.Throughout the film, the main character is narrating his experiences on the frontier and his style of narration as well as the wording sounds like that of a curious child discovering the world.While there are a few scenes that drag on for too long or seem unnecessary all-together, overall this movie is interesting and well-paced. At almost 4 hours long, it does not feel too long because the story works. Intelligently, bits of story are introduced that do not resolve right away thereby making you want to keep watching to see how those seeds will grow. The movie gets better as it goes on and as you get more attached to its characters.There is another minor complaint: the film attempts to be respectful to Native Americans, but a number of elements in the story damages the integrity of that respect. The natives who are friendly to the immigrants are portrayed as good. The natives who attack the whites are bad savages. The main character tries to train a wolf to eat from his hand and I cannot tell if this is intended or unintended symbolism but it sure is not a pleasant one. There is a white woman living amongst the natives (Mary McDonnell) because she was supposedly adopted, but was this character written into the movie to act as the English translator for the main hero or was this just another way of ensuring that the main hero's romantic interest is a relatable white actress. As always, the two main heroes are a white western couple. This is still a Hollywood movie.Kevin Kostner's main character is perhaps least interesting as he is the most wooden. His face is frozen in the expression of confusion for much of the movie. This performance fits the story as the character is mostly alone and remains cautious and unsure as he is pushing social boundaries on the frontier, but it does not make for interesting acting. The rest of the participants are more emotional and interesting, especially Graham Greene at the top of his game as the holy man.The music in this film is a soundtrack for epic exploration, some of it sounding like a tune that would accompany a scene of a kid discovering some magical house, and again contributing to the children's adventure movie feel described earlier.In short, what an odd filmI like it. It is not a great movie. Some of the acting is stiff and some scenes are questionable but the off-beat mood is curious enough and the story starts to really grow on you, so that it feels like a complete and rewarding experience after the movie is over.

After a couple of generations and Manifest Destiny, it was westward for the whites and lot's more Indians. Not too long before Dances with Wolves, Hollywood in the 1960's was littered with western movies with stars such as John Wayne, Charles Bronson and Clint Eastwood. These tough, big gun actors helped create some of the greatest cowboy flicks we have come to know, the western firmly stamping itself in film history, leaving a legacy far beyond the decade it shot holes in. Kevin Costner has given himself the responsibilities of film making's trifecta with Dances with Wolves, he has directed, produced and starred in one of the most ambitious and impressive debuts since Orson Wells created Citizen Kane.
Dances with Wolves opens with Union Army Lieutenant John Dunbar(Costner)miraculously surviving a suicidal charge at Confederate lines, a doomed act he had bravely opted for in favour of the amputation of his wounded leg. As a reward for his heroics, he is given apropriate medical treatment and offered a station of his choosing. He requests an abondoned fort on the Frontier, his only campanions are his loyal mount Cisco, a diary in which he pens his daily duties and a friendly wolf that he names Two Socks. As Dumbar repairs the run down fort, he attracts the curious attention of a local indian tribe, their leader Kicking Bird, played by Graham Green, is caught snooping around the Lieutenant's prized reinforcement. The two continue to meet, firstly out of curiosity and then through a female member of the tribe, Stands with a Fist who Dunbar has become affectionate toward. These encounters are the heart and soul of Dances with Wolves. Many westerns have explored relationships between American Frontiermen and the Native Indians, but none as inquisitively as this one as Costner gives the audience a rare glimpse at the trying fundamentals of human behaviour that is communication. Kicking Bird and the other members of the tribe embrace Dunbar into the camp, the leaders desire to learn about the white man, a perspective far from what we have come to witness in the American western. At this point in the film, Dunbar is completely apart of his new found tribe, his is now known as Dances with Wolves, and his love for Stands with a Fist has now become a celebrated bond under observation and respect from the group. Dances with Wolves is a film about bonds, weather its with another person, a tribe, an army or the land, Kevin Costner explores the frailties between the bonds that through effort and understanding can endure lifes toughest hardships, but are easily broken through ignorance and hate.
Dances with Wolves isnt just a magnificent western, but one of the greatest films ever made.

reviews.review_title: Revisionist Western that Gets It Mostly Right
reviews.content: Dances with Wolves (B+): An excellent revisionist Western that works so well for most of its running time. After becoming an accidental hero in the Civil War (beginning the revisionist theme of the film), John Dunbar is able to choose his future posting. After a memorable stopoff with his insane superior officer, another hint that this film is set to demystify the era, Dunbar heads across the American West with his provisions to his post in South Dakota. The following sequences of an isolated Dunbar embracing his new solitary life at the outpost are the best sequences of the entire film to me. I loved watching him repair Fort Sedgewick, making friends with local wildlife (where the name Dances with Wolves comes from), and starting relationships with the territory Indians. The highlight of his relationship with the Sioux Indians is the incredible buffalo hunt sequence. As the relationship grows with the Indians, the biggest revisionist aspirations take shape - the Indians were primarily peaceful and friendly. There is some complexity given to them, but it's clear they are the good guys. This is done fairly well, but by the time the end of the film comes into view it becomes too heavy handed. For instance, the Pawnee Indians and US Cavalry are painted as unthinking villains (with practically zero shades) while the Sioux and Dunbar are the only enlightened ones to see the peace. For a movie that gets so many details right, this oversimplification is really jarring and tough to take. This film works so well for about two thirds of its runtime, gets so much of the details correct (a sweeping romantic score, beautiful real life locations, taking seriously the Indian roles, etc), that the comically villainous US Cavalry in the final act of the film and the revisionist axe begin to overshadow it.

reviews.review_title: A moving experience of film as true art.
reviews.content: Without doubt, one of the finest moments ever to be found when true art emerges in the form of cinema is the epic "Dances With Wolves". The Oscar winning cinematography is sublime and breathtaking, the acting superb and genuine in a way that seems to only come about when performers truly believe in the project at hand as perhaps having meaning beyond commerce and thus being worthy of more than mere acting perchance even allowing actual expressions of soul. But here there is yet another great force at work, and that is surely the beauty and majesty that is the North American landscape in its unbridled glory. Having first seen the movie in it's original three hour cinematic release, I was moved in a unique and profound way that has remained with me for almost two decades now. Furthermore, I was priviliged enough to see the four hour "Director's Cut" some years later again in a full cinema setting. Here I felt the story was given even more depth and indeed some of the meaning conveyed originally to important aspects of the storyline turned out to make a very different point altogether. There is, therefore, no doubt in my mind that (far from always being the case) in this instance the longer cut is the one into which to immerse oneself into if given the opportunity.Naturally I have since procured a DVD version and was fortunate enough to find a release that provided both 'cuts' of the film in full wide screen format. This brings me to what I regard as a very interesting point. Over the years I have met a surprising number of people who have conveyed to me that they do not particularly care for this film. This deeply puzzled me for some years. Dare I say, and to my delight, thankfully none had ever declared anything even remotely resembling loathing. Naturally being curious as to how someone could feel unmoved by what I regard as one of the most moving of moving pictures, it emerged that every single one of these poor souls had had their first and any subsequent encounter with this masterpiece on a television. With the screen chopped off at the sides and all the other shortcomings of the now technologically quaint Cathode Ray Tube this outcome was surely inevitable for a film that realises so much of it's magic through the amazing cinematography of what can truly be described as sheer aesthetic majesty. Thankfully, large wide-screen high definition home cinema has arrived with excellent sound so as to allow the superb score some justice as well. In closing, might I strongly suggest should the opportunity to see this masterpiece in a cinema setting once again present itself, especially if you have as yet not had the opportunity, do yourself your loved ones and anyone you care about even remotely the immeasurable favour to experience this epic in the environment it was created for. Moreover, should the unexpigated version ever appear in a cinema near you... run don't walk, buy plenty of popcorn, and let yourself be mesmerised for the full four hours of cinematic heaven that is "Dances With Wolves"!
This movie is a classical and beautiful timepiece about a time in which Millenials know very little to nothing about. A film in which one can watch and never get sick of.

10/10 - great epic film. You won't see any computer-generated comic-book characters in this movie, but you will see real people having real conversations, and you'll see Costner and costar Mary McDonnell engaging in such intimate and convincing love scenes that you'll forget they're acting!If I could rate the musical score for this movie by itself I'd give it a perfect 10, because it's one of the best I've ever heard, able to stand on its own but fitting the movie like a glove. It is sentimental without being schmaltzy, noble without being pretentious. Best of all, it captures the hesitant emotions of the story, the sense of curiosity overcoming fear and becoming trust.Only this movie's extreme length works against its total success, particularly in the special edition that runs nearly four hours. The three-hour theatrical version is still long, but it's difficult to say what should have been left out of it.Some people still resent the fact that Costner won the Best Director Oscar over Scorcese's Goodfellas. There's no question that Scorcese is the better director, but I believe the direction of Dances With Wolves is better than that of Goodfellas. If you disagree with me try this test: imagine that Scorcese did this movie, and Costner directed Goodfellas. It's a question of which directing job is better, not which director is better.

I only took one star away from this film ... primarily because Kostner (or perhaps Blake) used the standard villain in such films ... the Pawnee. Long before the white man appeared in the Plains, various tribes were fighting one another over territory. No one single tribe was less brutal than any other in such disputes. A plus for the extended version of the film was the mention of another adversary, the Utes, and that it was clear (or apparently clear) that the Souix initiated the battle. Certainly, the Pawnee people were no better or worse than any other native group.Other than that, no flaw in the film was so terrible that it detracts from the film's purpose ... to show the Plains native (primarily the Souix) as a relatively cultured and sophisticated group that bore no "specific" ill will toward anyone unless it was perceived that they were infringing on their territorial rights. And, it showed them as people who were good stewards of the land ... unlike white settlers (and for that matter, white people even now).However (evil grin), as much as I liked the film, I felt that the theatrical version had a lot of unnecessary footage in it. And when I saw the extended version, I felt that if some of the scenes were added to the theatrical version, it would have made more sense to the film-goer. To test this theory (grin), I used my video capture device to capture the extended version from Comcast "on-demand" and edited the video based on my own parameters. I ended up with a video that's only 3 minutes longer than the theatrical version ... yet covers all the "making sense" bases and guts out the "fluff" scenes. The theatrical version DVD I got as a gift from my son is now retired (grin) since I like my edit job better.Example of cuts - On the wacky Major at Fort Hayes, I cut out the eccentric salute, the "Sir Knight" comment about soiling his pants, and his suicide. I left plenty of that scene in so that people would know he was a nut case. One controversial edit (grin). I cut out the scene where Spivey and a fellow soldier were taking dumps out in the high grass. True, this scene shows Spivey with Dunbar's journal. But later, when the Sergeant is the last person killed at the river, the next scene shown is the journal floating down the river ... leading people to believe that the Sergeant had it on him all the time ... that he purposefully withheld it from the officers because he was a bigot who wanted Dunbar to be hanged (ie., "Ya turned Injun, didn't ya ... didn't ya!").Example of scenes retained from the extended version - The scene showing Captain Cargill giving his speech to the assembled men ... and telling them to gather their things to abandon Fort Sedgewick. The scene showing the aftermath of the raid on the Utes, showing what Stands With A Fist had to mourn about ... before she was found by Dunbar. The brief conversation between Stone Calf and Kicking Bird after seeing Dunbar "dancing" with the wolf ... where Kicking Bird first suggests they give Dunbar a "real name."Therefore, my 9 of 10 rating is for the extended version since the theatrical version left me puzzled on a few points. I'd give MY version a 10 out of 10 (grin). Of course, I'm biased, hehe.

This movie is hands down one of the best I've ever seen in reference to the American Indian. It does a fantastic job of portraying the Sioux as they really were, without bias or embellishment. The inclusion of the Pawnee in key scenes reinforces the fact that not all American Indians were the same - something that most Americans don't know or simply don't care about. It also makes a strong statement on the ignorance, cruelty, and disregard for the land that the whites showed when they settled the United States, and through the story of Dunbar, illustrates how that could have been avoided with nothing more than respect for another group as people and interest in their culture, instead of blind contempt.

Predictably "Hollywood-esque", but sometimes surprising (no doubt stemming from its literary origins), this Costner-directed story is certainly well made. Strangely, I've never been able to determine the depth of the star's acting talent in any film in which he's appeared. In DW, his oral narration is weak but his passive presence throughout the rest of the film is adequate for the role. Regrettable is the movie's attempt to be both (historically) realistic and morally abstract. The ethical simplicity of the plot and its characters does not lend itself to a stern history lesson, in which we are taught that the White man is (almost inherently) corrupt, the Sioux is a noble savage and environmental guardian, and the Pawnee, a bloodthirsty barbarian. What I mean is that these characterizations are fine outside of the pretension that they are the truth; the stock nature of the story is suitable only for drama (as opposed to realism). I would not be too concerned if it were made in an age where the audience was more sophisticated, because it is clear to me that one should not be deceived by the film's historic appearance into thinking literally about the nature of the plot. Rather, Dunbar (Costner) is a man who confronts the frontier within himself after a flirtation with suicide. The western limits of America in 1863 happen to form the concrete setting--the dramatic effect of pathetic fallacy--for his internal struggle. We must also remember the extraordinary influence on the American character that was the frontier--Indians or no Indians. While watching Dunbar's notebook being borne away by the river after a brutal--and decisive--struggle with Union troops, I found myself admiring the metaphor, but was also a little disappointed by its naiveté; but later, when he again comes into possession of it, the implications are problematic, more serious.Other comments: I found the narration confusing, in that it wasn't clear what chronological perspective was being adopted. What is the deal with the officer with whom Dunbar speaks before departing into the hinterland ("I p***ed my pants, and there's nothing anyone can do about it", etc.)

Dances With Wolves is one of the most overrated films in existence.  It made a bucket-load of money and got a whole bunch of undeserved Oscars -- including Best Director and Best Picture.While this movie really wants to be a sprawling epic, its nothing of the sort.  The film's only message seems to be that Native Americans are not the stereotypical "How, white man" caricatures they are often portrayed as, and that they have suffered injustice after injustice at the hands of American expansionism.  While this is certainly true, it is a point repeated often both before and after Dances With Wolves.  It is also a point that has been made a lot better.  One should also note that Kevin Costner is being horribly self-righteous in telling everybody else how horrible they've been to Native Americans as if he (the millionaire celebrity) has suffered alongside them.The insufferable preachiness of the film is compounded by bad storytelling. The movie bludgeons its simplistic point home with clunky voice-over narration from Costner's character's diary.  There's plenty of films that have expressed subtler themes than this one's without saying a word.Subtlety is one big thing lacking in this movie, in all respects.  rather than letting scenery speak for itself, Costner simply has to tell  us how beautiful the frontier is.  His performance is, as usual, bland and boring.Don't waste your time on this Hollywood trash.  Go see an indie movie.

The movie " Dances with Wolves " is very especial and has very important position in the film history. Secondly , and most important point is that it changed the central values of traditional Westerns, from old- fashioned in white as the lead out of personal heroism , to the continent of North America between whites and Aboriginal cultural conflict and explore mutually and understand the thinking, so that the " Dances with Wolves " has become the most anthropological spirit of Westerns.This movie begin with Lieutenant Dunbar's unsuccessful suicide action in the Civil War. After that he choose go to the frontier as a hero, because he want the peaceful life. Unfortunately, Major Bulu suicided and the transport team is killed, so Lieutenant Dunbar lost the connect with the white world. reviews.review_title: Twelve years old and still a hit!
reviews.content: `Dances with Wolves' begins in 1863 during the Civil War.  John Dunbar(Kevin Costner), a Lt. for the Union Army, earned a high honor from his heroism. The Union Army rewarded him when it assigned him to an empty Fort Sedwick on the frontier.  Gradually, John and the Sioux overcame their fear of one another and learned each other's way of life and language, with the help of Stands With A Fist(Mary McDonnell), a white woman raised by the tribe, whom Dunbar marries. Dunbar befriends a wolf he named Two Socks. Dunbar receives the name Dances with Wolves, because the Sioux witnessed him playing with the wolf in the field.  Dances with Wolves' conscious catches up with him, and he tells the tribe that the white men will be looking for him.  The best thing for the tribe is for him and his wife to leave.The intention for this movie was not just to entertain, but to teach a lesson about American History.  `Dances with Wolves' demonstrates how much love the Sioux Indians had for their land.  The purity of the land tended by the Indians compared to the land taken over by white people shows that the Indians' respect for nature ran more deeply.     Kevin Costner(director) cared deeply about the making of this movie, because he wanted to show every minor detail possible, particularly from the way the horses ran freely along the land to the way the tribe congregated around a fire at night to celebrate their victorious hunt of buffalo.The length of `Dances with Wolves' is 180 minutes long.  I did not think that was too bad, compared to the four hour editor's edition.  South Dakota is marvelous for the setting.  `Dances with Wolves' is packed with drama, romance, action, and comedy.  Even though this film is twelve years old, it is still a must see.

It is not just a film just talk about white personal heroism, it is jump out of the personal heroism. But talk about the culture conflict and understand between the North America and original people. I think "Dance with Wolves" has become the most anthropological spirit of the western movie.The first half of the film is based on the perspective of U.S. Lieutenant Dunbar went into a strange world. The film was showed the white people and original people in the same place to the audience, is not just the white people as an explorers to identify the Sioux life, actually it is an observation based on western value. There is a very long time they spoked Sioux language. The purpose of this I think the director is going to create a view, which Sioux and white people stood outside the value and let the audience to evaluate and think the main conflict between them. And the make audience stand on the value neutral attitude towards the history between the whites and the Sioux.I think from this movie it has related to the class I am taking now, American Ways. The contradiction in the film is the core value. The white people is intruder and they from Europe it has so many different with original people. So the movie showed a culture conflict between them, and through the story let audience understand the difference between them . At the beginning Sioux and Dunbar have been tested of each other. To Dunbar he faced is the "barbarians"，when he found Sioux were not as he heard to burning and looting, he tried to get close to them. Because in Sioux society, brave and skilled warriors have very high social status, and the warrior is also the best hunter. From this we can see different types of people have different cultures, different experience in their life and lead to a huge difference in the values.From this movie I have a deep recognize in American history and their value and culture. The different of national value and the self-centered civilization are all come from their own life experience. Because of way of production and the objective environment, so that all knowledge of the entire world, philosophy are derived from the experience of their lives. So I think it is really difficult to accept strange culture and value because of our own life experience so we could go to understand each other's lifestyle and habits, and think about their own civilized society works.

reviews.review_title: A union army officer is sent out west to a remote past and befriends Indians
reviews.content: After viewing this movie several times I still have the same high opinion of it. The plot and acting at all levels was well above average Costner is not my favorite actor but has a creditable performance in this. What troubled me was that the tribe he affiliated with were the Sioux, deadly enemies of the settlers and the U.S. Army. The enemy of the Sioux were shown to be the evil Pawnee. However, this tribe was not an enemy of settlers and even provided scouts for the army in its war against the Sioux. It seems to me that proper research would have discovered this. This officer could just as easily adhered to the Pawnee rather than to their enemy.

How many "westerns" have you seen where the dominant action scene featured the "good guys" killing a bunch of Indians? Or how many times did a white man play an Indian on TV? I'm not blaming "white America" for this, perhaps the blame lies in Hollywood. I do allow that I probably played cowboys and Indians as a child, and the Indians are always the bad guys who die first. Maybe all of that stuff made me really appreciate "Dances with Wolves". The movie showed two very different races and yet also showed that the two could peacefully co-exist. It wasn't one of those "hey, we don't know what it is or understand it, so let's kill it!" kind of movies. The movie had great scenery, a fantastic score by John Barry, and plenty of action. There was even a love story to keep the lady viewers tuned in. Yes, John Barry did write scores for some of the James Bond movies, but nothing like what he wrote for this. Perhaps the material inspired him. This movie resonates with me, and I can't say that about many movies. If you can only own one western, get this one!

If you are looking for a film with everything, check out this one. To me it is one of the finest ever made. What are you looking for in a film? First of all, great storyline. Secondly, great cinematography. Thirdly, great direction. Fourth, great cast. How about great acting. Then throw in fantastic locations, and finally, what about one of the greatest scores in filmdom. John Barry has always been my favorite composer and his music is unmistakable. I have seen far lesser films in which Barry's scores were the highlight. "Raise the Titanic"? Lastly, this is a film for all audiences...I plan to sit and watch it with my grandchildren in a few years when they are old enough to appreciate it.

The book goes into great detail and makes one fully appreciative of Her story.), or are they merely to be overwhelmed by a magnificent soundtrack (scored by John Barry of the "007" music fame) and breathtaking cinematography? I was. I suppose that to include all that "needed" info, The Human Bladder Co-efficient would have been exceeded. I did not read the book until last year, but have seen the movie several times on video, and originally on the big screen (a very bad 16mm print with poor sound @ a college auditorium). I am by nature a very skeptical, detail oriented person who enjoys History (especially Civil War Military History) but yet my eyes still well up with tears everytime I watch this film. See it on the Big Screen with someone you love.

As to the comments of lee1888, You know nothing of Native American culture or of history itself. The Sioux got a pretty good deal you say? It just so happens to be that the Sioux occupy the two poorest reservations in the U.S. Suicide rates are amongst the highest in the U.S. as well, how does this tell us that they got a "good deal". Every weekend you hear the ambulances taking off to try to save drunk Sioux. With populations so small the death rate is abnormally high. The U.S. allowed over zealous companies hunt the buffalo to near extinction and then gave the Sioux plows and seed to plant fields, who in their right mind tells a hunting society to plant for a living and expect them to accept it automatically. If at most they should have asked them to become cattle ranchers. In Sioux culture you did not toil day after day just to make a lowly income, nature had all you could want and if you needed something you went and got it, of course you had to hunt and make the things you wanted, but generally these were saw as activities rather than work. There was no plowing the earth, they had deer, buffalo, and other game. There was no standing in a factory for 10 hours a day making one thing, you learned how to make almost everything and you could make it the way you wanted. They still had struggles but other than that why would they want to change? They in their mind, had achieved a state of life that was comfortable and prosperous. That is why it has been hard for the Native American to find their place in white society. There is nothing glorious about our society today other than our traditions and family. My father born in 1950 grew up in a three room log cabin with 11 brothers and sisters and so far has been the only one to leave the reservation to make a life, which he has been successful in the natural gas industry(ask anyone in the area and they will know his name),a decorated Veitnam War veteran(he volunteered rather than be shamefully drafted). He left behind tradition and family which makes him sad and that's his sacrifice to give me a decent life that he didn't have as a child. That is the problem that most Native Americans face today, do I stay at home in poverty but keeping my tradition, family, sacred land, and friends. Or, do I go into the world and leave that behind. The two cannot or very rarely co-exist, if you have money or objects of value you are the main person to ask for handouts which in Sioux tradition you are supposed to help friends and family, but when the amount borrowed grows and grows and no change happens what are you supposed to do then? Rarely do you ever hear of anything good happening on the reservation, government officials using funds for their own personal uses, deaths, alcoholism, and etc. Before you make any statements about the lively hood of the Sioux let alone any Native American population you should live amongst them on reservation, then tell me they got a good deal.

I saw Dances With Wolves for the first time sometime within the last several months. It wasn't as great or memorable as I hoped it would be, but it's pretty good nonetheless.As the story starts off, we are introduced to Lieutenant John Dunbar, who does something stupid during a Civil War battle and inadvertently leads the Union troops to a victory. As a reward, he is given a post at the western frontier. Upon arriving, he finds the post deserted. Soon however, he starts to befriend a curious local Indian tribe. Gradually, over time earns the trust and respect of these people, and eventually becomes one of them. Along the way, he also falls in love with Stands With A Fist, a white girl raised by the tribe. Also, along the way, he even receives a tribal name, "Dances With Wolves." It's a simple story. It's that old man-befriends-natives-and-turns-against-his-own-people type of story. There's no originality in it whatsoever, and it's almost completely predictable. However, it is very well-told, with soul and emotion. The movie follows Dunbar and allows the viewer to feel his emotions and experiences as he gradually falls in love with the tribe and the land. In terms of the script, and other aspects, the movie is pretty good. The dialogue is pretty good, and the story is well-paced. Performances by Costner and everyone else are good as well, and the actors really bring out their characters. John Barry also composed a great score for the film, which also helped bring out the emotion, mood, and tone of the film.I do have a few criticisms of the film. My first criticism concerns Mary McDonnel. She was effective as Stands With A Fist, and her performance was good, but there's something about her that took away slightly from my liking for her character. I didn't think she was quite right for her role. Also, I should have had more emotional attachment to her (not that I didn't, but I did feel that it lacked a bit). My second criticism concerns the length of the film. I can see what Costner was trying to do in terms of storytelling, emotion, length of scenes, and all that, but, in my opinion, the film was too long. I have to admit, I liked the film, but I did get bored in some areas. Also, while the character development is solid, I think the story should have gone more into character complexity. The story itself had more potential too. There's hardly any plot at all, but it's enjoyable, but nonetheless, if the movie did have more of a real plot it could have been a lot better. Next, I didn't really feel much tension/worry for the inevitable fight with the American military coming up at the end. I really did need to feel much more of that. Also, while the movie is pretty good, it only has a few memorable aspects about it. It needed more.Overall, I feel that Dances With Wolves is more of a moral message experience than entertainment. It's not something I'd want to watch more than once, but it's a good movie all the same, definitely worth watching. But it did have a lot more potential.My Rating: ***1/2 (out of ****)For more reviews, visit my website: http://robertsreliablereviews.blogspot.com
