The title infers a movie about dancing and a number of wolves (plural). However after enduring 3 hours of a somewhat western-style movie I saw absolutely no professional dancing and only 1 wolf (singular).

I first saw this movie in the theater when it was newly released. I believe it is the best movie ever made! True, it is quite long, but I wish the story would never end. I've seen the Dances With Wolves more than a hundred times...and look forward to seeing it again. It shows that a man can be tough, have dedication, love, and find his true self. If you've never seen it, sit down on a long winters night and watch it, you'll laugh, cry, get angry, and finish with a new feeling of hope...for yourself. That last thing may sound strange, but watch Dances With Wolves, and you'll see what I mean.I can't believe that it didn't rank on the Best 250 movies, and Pulp Fiction did. Honestly, when I read that fact, it made me angry! Pulp Fiction seemed to me as a "blood & guts" film with no real meaning. Dances With Wolves was more than just a movie... It's a description of real life in a real setting. Honestly, Dances With Wolves describes the life I wish I'd lived!

I do not remember all the details from this movie after several years after I saw it the last time. On the other hand, I am quite sure what I do remember: the impression from Dunbar (the main hero) meeting Kicking Bird remains strong even after years. How two enemies, both being very proud fighters, but also tired by live, become friends - these scenes of "Dances with wolves" have something archetypal about them. Their first "discussions" about bulls (how was the word for bull? Takanka?) etc. belong to my favourite moments in cinema at all. Beautifully done, it inspires to thinking about many aspects of their stories: is not the intelligent Kicking Bird also alone among his people as Dunbar among his? Isn't it the ridiculous shyness and helplessness of the Kicking Bird that make the viewer understand his real authority? Conclusion: very sentimental, but I cannot remember anything disturbing in this movie.

reviews.review_title: A flawed but very beautiful and moving gem
reviews.content: For it's time a really beautiful film in many ways, note that I watched the 4 hour long D. Cut which I highly recommend if you think this film is for you.DWW tells the story of a somewhat despondent Officer who ends up finding himself out in the great Frontier. This largely happens through his deep friendships made with the Lakota Indians and then him finally fully integrating himself in their tribe and their ways including marriage to one of their own.Its a magnificent tale told beautifully overall and many have gushed over all those details. I will focus a little more on the flaws which in the end (including the end...) still nagged at me and kept it from my personal top tier favs. Some of these are more Nit Picks for sure, and none of these really take too much away from the entire film in the big picture, which I do highly recommend.First Act - His Journey to the Frontier and his first month at his new post so about 40 mins of the film is just very slow. There is at least some intrigue present so I would not label it boring but others might.Emotional lost opportunities - This is one of the biggest ones for me if not the biggest, and its not a huge flaw by any means there are still some heart-string tugs but it bugged me none the less while watching. Several times in the film we see a very moving part take place, but very little emotion shown. One example is when several in the tribe risk their lives to rescue him and once successful, not even a thank you escapes his lips, at least 3 or 4 others like this.Wolf - I imagine there is a bit less of him in the 3 hour version. Here anyway, it kind of goes back to emotional lost opportunities again, I really wanted to see him take the wolf fully by his side, instead they just tease each other with friendship. This is a very minor point but the Wolf was important to him.The Ending - This was another big one for me. Again its part of emotional lost opportunity flaw, but moreover it left me unsettled. So we see him departing with his wife, and then right after, we see the Army arrive. They show the Army is "working with" the enemy of his tribe, this is already weird, as they don't show the Indians being prisoners but maybe we can assume it I guess. We see the enemy lead them to the tribes camp, but it is abandoned now, but freshly abandoned as they find smoldering fire. Then we see Dunbar and Wife riding off in final shot, and the Epilogue role, which makes no mention of Dunbar. I didn't like that loose end, we find out what happens to the Tribe down the road but not him, and the it was shown I felt like maybe the Army caught up to him (but apparently they didn't).More on the Nit pick side of things:Relationship - This might be personal preference but I would have rather of seen him fall in love with a Sioux Woman to really complete his full integration into the tribe, even though his choice was fully part of the tribe she was white like him.His promotion - After a display of sheer despondency a promotion just due to an unplanned distraction giving their side an edge seems off.Stands with Fists - Her family murdered by Indians when she is a Child, she flees into the Wilderness only to go and live and grow up amongst Indians? Yeah, not something most would have done....
This movie touches on all areas, and does it wonderfully. As much of a movie buff as I am, this is definitely one of those favorites that I can't find any part where they could of improved.

Costner can't act, way out of his depth here, even in this dreadful film which portrays the extermination of an entire race like a romantic Rock Hudson matinée. Its a good job the film is mostly set in the great plains instead of forests as the trees would have probably out-acted the leading man. The film follows the Hollywood formula for peaceful whiteman meets indians.... the love interest of course must be a white women and the leading man must then earn the respect of the natives by out performing them at almost every facet of their own lives (Tarzan?) Watch Black Robe. 1991. instead for an altogether more realistic depiction of a native people.

reviews.review_title: A Wonderful, Sensitive Look Into The Dark Past
reviews.content: What to say about this film in particular? I first saw this movie as a class project in grade 7 (1991). I enjoyed it then and I must say that I enjoy it 26 years later even more than ever. The depth and sensitivity with detail was beyond my juvenile understanding. While I recommend the uncut version, the theater version is more than an ample story of love, friendship, hate, and change in a strange time. Kevin Costner may have had career missteps, but this is his Magnum Opus. Graham Greene, Floyd "Red Crow" Westerman, and Mary McDonnell with a swell and superb supporting cast tells the story of change in North America. The maturity and sensitivity of indigenous folk is top notch. As a pre-pubescent 12 year old, I did not quite understand the entire story, but I did see this as a very important milestone in film making. Years of marinating and quite a large amount of thought has confirmed this as my favorite film of all time (Shawshank Redemption, a close number 2). The music, the scenery, the culture clash and ultimate mixing was superb. The white man's self appointed superiority without communication with the native Sioux (and Pawnee with many other tribes assuredly represented) here is the stuff of legends. I did not know this won awards as a kid. I only thought this was the coolest 3+ hour class I'd ever had. I passed the test from viewing this film. In Canada, relations still seem restrained between the First Nations people and the 'newcomers'. Truth be told, without plot details, this is a very good movie. I am reluctant to critique the age from which this film is depicting. Nothing can change what happened. I hope, as I think Mr. Kevin Costner does, that this is a very sensitive movie with action, some cultural difference, humour (who can deny the humour in the 'Good Trade' argument after the buffalo hunt?), and a great plot. If I had a picture or film to take with me to a desert island, or an abandoned camp on the frontier as described, this is the film. Although I am sentimental at heart, nothing has shaken my view of this film in 26 years. This hasn't aged and is timeless. Understandably, there are people who will disagree on varying levels. It made me appreciate the wars of the past and how ignorant previous societies were. It also showed me how far we still have to go in the way of understanding people who come from a different place or culture than what we grew up with. An eye-opening film and, in my opinion, the best film I have seen to date. The uncut version shows more detail and is recommended highly. In short, this is a lesson in how people are all fundamentally the same. We are conditioned within our own culture, more-so back in those 'Cowboy & Indian' ways/days. This film is an education piece. It also is the most entertaining education I have received (by film) to this date. 10/10

Growing you've probably always been told that the natives were people that went around scalping pilgrims and killing innocent people. Well, I'm not sure you were but I was. This movie shows that there was much more to the Sioux people than most thought. It also shows that the white man was even more savage and cruel then the supposed 'savage'. If you watch old movies with natives and the white man you see that all the natives were the enemy and uncivilized. THis movie breaks the genre stereotypes and shows intelligent caring people, now true its more or less just switched the traditional roles around, but I think that is the more historically accurate version of history All in all an excellent movie deserves to be on the top if not the top of the list of 250 much better than the Godfather

reviews.review_title: My friend went away because you were coming....
reviews.content: This is a tale of exploration and adventure of the most unusual kind – almost a fantasy. It is a fictional story about a soldier who 'turns Injun' in crude terms. It is not as if no one had ever lived with and become like the Indians. J.W. Schultz who wrote 'My Life As An Indian' is a classic example, well known because of the book, but there have been several, mostly unknown, because at that time no one was really interested to know about the life style and social, cultural values of the Indians. Some fictional tales can become more powerful by the excellence of their presentation, and Costner has been able to achieve this in Dances With Wolves. Lt. Dunbar is a desperate hero, who is given the choice of any station that he desires. He wants to go towards the frontier. Some mysterious force is pulling Lt. Dunbar towards the frontier (compare Schultz's account). The only reason he can give is that he wants to see the frontier before it is gone. The mood of the story builds up slowly and gracefully. Dunbar will gradually and surely discover why he wanted to come here, leaving behind the comfort and security of cities and forts...he will find who he really is inside. And to find all that he loves...the open, beautiful, unspoilt land, the wild but friendly wolf Two Socks, the tribe of Indians with whom he develops a social bond, and finally - Stands With A Fist. The good days can't last long....more troops have come to the frontier, and the frontier is shrinking. Dunbar sees that the tribe of which he is now a member is going to be decimated. He decides that he must go back to civilization to talk to those who would listen....that the existence of the frontier is actually the last chance for civilization to learn from. The frontier here is not just a physical boundary, but also a metaphysical one - a metaphor for the unknown, and if the frontier dies, so does the chance for civilization to learn from what lies beyond the frontier. He sets on his journey back....will anyone listen?

reviews.review_title: Kevin Costners Dances With Wolves, my favourite movie of all time.
reviews.content: Dances with Wolves. Hate to oversell things but forget it! It's an expertly directed movie with some truly beautiful shots, lots of gorgeous wides, the best shot of the movie IMO is at 1:34:46 of the directors cut. Kevin Costner gives his best performance of his career as do all the other actors, Graham Greene and Mary McDonnell give the best of the entire movie. It's also a movie with really good intentions portraying the Sioux with a great amount of respect. John Barry delivers his best soundtrack, Two Socks, Journey to Fort Sedgewick and the Love Theme are the best of the OST. It's also a movie that takes its time with nearly every aspect. All the characters, locations, themes (as in the emotional aspects) and scenes are all very well written, realised and developed perfectly, I guess since the movie is 4 hours long that was inevitable.I think what sets it apart from most other films is how peaceful and welcoming it is, it's a really optimistic and positive movie, a tone that is similar to the Shire scenes in the Middle Earth franchise. Also normally movies that deal with animals tend to end up feeling unconvincing. But this movie does a great job with the Wolves, the wolf trainer they got and the Costners directing merge really well to create some very believable scenes with the animals.The character of John Dunbar has an extremely optimistic view on the world he lives in. Dunbar is an every man, Costner usually portrays characters like that, a person who the audience can easily connect with and one that the audience feels comfortable going on an adventure with.The only real problem is that some people won't like hearing Kevin Costners voice for 4 hours straight and I guess it could be a bit longer.

I saw this movie on the big screen when it was first released, and just watched it again for perhaps the twentieth time. It is timeless work of art and a story that should be told and remembered. I'm always moved to tears by some scenes and my heart is always warmed by the richness of the relationships between John Dunbar and his Native American "family". The story may be fictional, but the facts are sickening with regard to the white man's treatment and subsequent annihilation of the beautiful Native American cultures. I will continue to watch this movie time and again.

reviews.review_title: Look at us, we're a sickness to this world
reviews.content: Today was my first time watching this film. I'm a wildlife photographer and I take great pride in the connection I have with nature and the photos I captured of wildlife, from tiny bugs to Wolves and Gazelles. With my own eyes I see what we're doing to nature, we are a sickness to this wonderful world. We dream of reaching heaven when we finally die and we miss out on everything life has to offer. Deep inside we know how horrible we are so we don't even feel we deserve to enjoy on this earth, so if it's not for us, let's destroy it, right?. This film represents what I've been thinking and feeling ever since the first step I took in nature. We take and take and take and only think about the next thing we're gonna get and about how much money we have and we're in a constant race that will never end, a chase to be better than our neighbors. We destroyed almost every part of this earth. Murdered each other, murdered animals and deforested almost every ancient tree that ever existed. When I look at you I feel sick. I have very few connection with people because of it. You all make me sick. Thinking about you and what you've done, and keep on doing, makes me want to throw up. Wake up. Wake. Up. Stop this madness. Think about your actions. Be aware of your thoughts and emotions. Stop being a goddamn robot. Live actively, you're all living on autopilot and thats no way to live. Find love, it exists deep inside you, when you finally find it, when you finally feel connected to this earth, to the trees, to the soil, to the wildlife, then you'll know you've finally woken from the long deep sleep you were in your entire life. If you feel more connected to asphalt, cinderblocks, concrete and the fast pace chase of this insane society.. know that you're simply repressing your true self and you will never find it as long as you keep living in that awfully sad way.

I know that not everyone likes Kevin Costner, but I really think he did a fine job with this movie. It's beautiful. It has, I think, just the right combination of quiet, contemplative scenes with climactic action scenes such as the buffalo hunt. Again, not everyone appreciates Costner's acting ability, but I think in this movie, he really rises to the occasion.

reviews.review_title: The only thing wrong with this film is Costner
reviews.content: It's ironic that this film should come up as the random title given that I just rewatched it the other day.  And, I could not believe how terribly outdated and self-serving it seemed now that time has gone by and it is not as current.  The indians and their customs and way of life were not what was outdated.  Both the indian characters and the actors portraying them stay true to life and timeless.  But Costner seems like a fish out of water. He makes the fatal flaw of being overly sentimental, both for himself in front of the camera and behind it.  Perhaps I felt this way because since then I've had the pleasure of watching another actor step behind the camera and direct his own epic:  Mel Gibson in Braveheart.  After having seen the way he portrayed the English-Scottish conflict and the amazing cinematography and script that he incorparated, Dances With Wolves comes across as a B movie.  With Gibson, I see no sympathy for self - he seems to trust in the work and the subject matter to carry his film along vibrantly and with truth.  Costner, in turn, seems to feel the need to constantly show his empathy and courage in order to make sure that you see him in the light which suits him best.  I wish I could vote higher, especially as Graham Greene gave the film such heart and truth, but Costner just blaringly stood in my way.Still, a good film to watch.  Enlightening and a bitter reminder of what America once was and the people that were it's true inhabitants only to be treated in a despicable fashion.  A good history lesson, but the lines are just a little too blurred for my taste.

reviews.review_title: Kostner unequaled in telling a love story
reviews.content: "Dances with Wolves" is about soldiers, Indians, and the frontier now gone. True.But it is about a frontier much greater than any pioneering could encounter: a frontier always present: the love between a man and a woman.The film peaks at the point where Mary McDonnell ("Stands with a fist") runs to embrace Kevin Kostner (John Dunbar/"Dances with Wolves") upon his return to the Souix camp after being rescued by his Souix friends. All the rest of the film serves that end: the enchantment and 'romantic' sentiment of a people tragically ended against their will, is encapsulated in the love that "Stands with a fist" and John Dunbar have for each other.Highly recommended. To be watched with the phone off the hook.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful Scenery, Interesting attempt at Inverting Western
reviews.content: This movie was one of the better Westerns made in the last couple decades but is by no means the great film that many people here are making it out to be. I will separate out into pluses and minuses:Pluses: Great scenery Very good cinematography Interesting effort to portray the Lakota Sioux view of the coming of the white man to the Great Plains Use of Lakota language Interesting use of wolf actors Efforts made to portray the Sioux as not quite "noble savages" in that they do some things that we find repulsive like revenge killing/killing white folk/stealing horses etc.Minuses: Kevin Costner's acting Kevin Costner's voice over The fact that Kevin Costner's hair always looks like a stylist just went over it The whites in the movie with the exception of Costner and Stands with Fists are pretty uniformly "savage".On the whole an epic that is worth watching but also not particularly deep or intelligent. If you are looking for a great recent Western..try "Unforgiven"..an amazing movie.

Kevin Costner took a great script and a potentially great movie and created an unwatchable piece of junk. I refuse to read subtitles to watch any movie. I did watch this movie twice. I hated it more the second time I watched it than the first. All of the dialog needs to be in English. I do not speak any other language. I watch movies for entertainment. I will not watch movies to have to try to read a bunch of subtitles. I did enjoy some parts of the movie when there were No subtitles. I hope this movie is remade by someone who will not use subtitles. I like Costner in some of his other movies and I think some of the other movies with Costner are great. I will never watch Dances With Wolves again. Not ever.

On my personal opinion, I really loved this film. It includes the exact amount of love, action and moral that any long movie should have. I really think the transformation of Lieutenant John J Dunbar in "Shoung Mani Tu Tonka Ob Waci" (sorry if I misspelled it) is very good. The performance of Kevin Costner is  believable, and all the performances, as well as the direction and photography are really good. The only problem with it is that after having seen it, no other film with Kevin Costner will convince me.

What top gun was for flying scenes, Dances with wolves is for western scenes Visually it's a master piece. Story wise I find it somewhat to long and tedious, and in some places you can clearly see that some of Kevin Costner actions don't make sense for someone who's living in a hostile territory. Like walking all the way across the river, to take a shave. And in the process leaving rifle and gun far behind in the cabin, even when he knew there were Indians around, and he could just as easily have done it 10 paces from he's sleeping quarters. But It got it's humorous moments too, and its not a bad film. It's nice that they have taken the time and effort to make all the Indians talk native instead of fluent English. Kevin somewhat overplay he's part a lot in a some places. But all in all I'll give it full house cause of the visual scenery

reviews.review_title: The best movie of all time.
reviews.content: This is without doubt my all time favourite movie - and I have seen literally thousands. I have also done a LOT of research and, whilst the Oglala Sioux in particular were a bloodthirsty lot, the same cannot be said for all the Sioux. Many US soldiers in those days WERE uneducated, lecherous, dishonest and plain dirty. And the way new settlers in the mid west recklessly and stupidly slaughtered thousands of buffalo is well documented. The storyline is believable, well laid out and entertaining.The cinematography, acting, directing, sound, editing and overall 'everything' of this movie in my opinion may never be equalled. It is a audio and visual masterpiece, and the haunting themes leave one with a wish that Costner would do another such film. No wonder it got seven Oscars - should have been at least two more.

reviews.review_title: Up there with the classic epics.
reviews.content: Initially I stayed away from this film as it swept the boards at the oscars, leaving the tremendous T2( I'm a big Arnie fan) to spit in the dust. However after several years, watching this film was a pure delight. For a first time director, Costner deals with the big canvas very professionally, extracting top performances from all involved. And the soundtrack - One of the best, if not the best available. At times it comes across as typical John Barry (shades of some Bond themes)  but it always remains emotionally stirring.I would advise anyone interested in this film to track down the extended (by 45mins) version.

reviews.review_title: Good Western but Rehash of Romantic Tradition
reviews.content: Dances With Wolves is a great epic Western with strong supporting roles. The message, that there are sympathetic Indians, is nothing new, however. But much of the story stems from the Romantic tradition in literature, with a white hero removed (and fed up with) civilization and the indigenous people the "children of nature." Jean-Jacques Rousseau wrote about it, and Dances With Wolves follows through with many of his themes.Speaking about writing, an excellent interview with screenwriter Michael Blake appears in "Making the White Man's Indian: Native Americans and Hollywood Movies." (Praeger, 2005) The book contains many behind-the-screen anecdotes about Indians in Hollywood.

This film was great and entertaining. There is so much action in this film. Between the fighting, the hunting and the learning of a new language.I love how this film portrays natives. They portray them as real people who want to learn about white people. The Natives and Dunbar establish a good, healthy relationship. They both help each other survive.I recommend this film to anyone wanting to know how the native and the white established a good relationship. Yes, this happened rarely but it did happen. The way the relationship was established is amazing. The way Dunbar and the Natives gradually gained each other's trust.

Dancing with wolves is such an amazing film, the only thing I didn't enjoy was that we didn't find the closed captions until 5 minutes were left in the movie. I think it would be better if closed captions automatically came on especially when the Natives were talking. The movie was very well acted showing many complications both sides had. I LOVE how it started as the main character Dunbar having to gain the Natives trust and had to learn to talk to them. I also enjoyed seeing how the Whites and Natives actually acted when both tribes ran into each other, which begins in a war every time. The movie never got boring and always had you on the edge of your seat. I would recommend this movie to anyone needing to learn about the Natives or enjoy history. This movie is also good to see how everyone acted.
A 3h movie of overratedness. I would say not to watch this film.

The film Dances with Wolves is directed by Kevin Costner who also stars in the movie as lieutenant Dunbar. The film does have a slow start but once John Dunbar has his first interaction with the Sioux tribe the story begins to move smoother. I liked the scene where John makes his first trade with one of the members of the tribe. I also loved the growing relationship that John had with the tribe, especially with kicking bird, from the Sioux coming to Dunbar's place then later on, Dunbar living with the Sioux and eventually learning their native tongue. I enjoyed the direction that the film went in when Dunbar requested to go fight alongside the Sioux. I believe that it showed that John was a loyal person and wanted to help those that he cared for. I also liked the way that the character John would describe Standing with fist at their wedding and showing how much he loved her. I was touched by the goodbye that the Sioux gave John and Standing fist when they left the tribe because the army was going after John and how John was willing to leave to protect the tribe and keep them safe from the military. :)

reviews.review_title: Why i dont like dances with wolves
reviews.content: Dances with wolves was not that good; there were too many strings left untied. It seemed more like a legend or fairytale where every single person is so happy throughout the entire film. When things did go wrong there was only two to three minutes of fighting then the battle was over it was not even a battle more like a fist fight between a seven year old and a grown man. Just one punch and there's no need for three more rounds of this cause the kid probably won't even wake up in time. The relationship that is formed throughout the movie has nothing to do with what the title suggests it's about. Most of the movie is in a language I cannot understand. The plot is nice but not how it turned out.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest films of all time...
reviews.content: Dances With Wolves is not only the highest grossing western of all time, but is considered by many to be one of the greatest films of all time. I couldn't agree more. I have a special place in my heart for this movie especially since I have taken a missions trip up to Pine Ridge, SD where the Lakota reservation now exists. It is deplorable, but that's a whole other subject. Back to the movie... Despite the fact that the movie is over 3 hours long, it never really drags because the story is so good. Costner's character, John Dunbar, is determined not to lose his leg, which was badly wounded in battle. It is an excruciating scene when he has to slip his leg back into his boot! John Dunbar wishes to see the frontier before it is gone and his request is granted. The journey that begins there changes him in a positive way when he befriends the Sioux (Lakota) Indians, finds a sort of companion in a lone wolf (which he names "Two Socks"), and falls in love with "Stands With A Fist", played by the wonderful Mary McDonnell. The experiences John Dunbar has with the Indians teaches him that not all the natives are hostile and savage. That they are a simple people who live off the land, waste nothing and only desire to be left alone to live in peace on the land they inherited from their ancestors. He particularly grows fond of "Kicking Bird" played by Graham Greene. There is plenty of excitement between the Buffalo (ttonka) Hunt, the fight with the Pawnee and the clash between the Cavalry Soldiers and the Sioux. The scenery is sometimes breathtaking and at least for me, makes me long for a more simple landscape than the one I see when I drive to work everyday. Truly, our country should always preserve whatever huge chunks of land can be preserved for future generations to be able to observe, walk, ride and breathe-in the wonder of God's creation. Add to the mix a sweeping and inspirational score by John Barry (his magnum opus IMHO) and you have one solid, beautiful film.

Dance with wolves is definitely an A-tier movie in my own opinion. It is the one of the best movies i have ever seen though i saw due to classwork it is classwork i will remember. The symbolism with the wolf can be seen as his loneliness with it being around only when he is by himself. I find this as not a complicated example of symbolism more as something you would have to think about to find out. The language gap at first when john first met with the sioux really puts in perspective of why many of the army attacked due the language difference. The actions you take can often be seen offensive towards other people. You would have no way to defend yourself verbally if you offended them. It's like someone walking in your house and pointing at your tv and they think they can take it. Though the white woman had a troubled background that was never addressed again it was so small that it did not affect the story.
This movie doesn't need a long drawn out review!! It's simply a masterpiece. There hasn't been a movie like it since. It's in my top 5 movies ever

This is an intelligent, deep, thoughtful film. It is full of life, isnt that what all great films have in common. If you are a thoughtful, empathetic person i know you will fall in love with this movie.

John Dunbar is a fantastic character. The moment where he goes "She's hurt" and then the Natives just look at him like he's crazy actually made me laugh out loud. But now for the serious part of this review. This movie is awesome, the way that the american settlers are portrayed at the final act of the movie was solid. The use of the Native's language was really good (too bad I didn't realize subtitles were an option so for most of the movie I was just left confused) The immersion in this film is great, you can really feel John's loneliness before he meets the Natives. The wolf's death by the soldiers really shocked me, didn't see that happening. Overall I really liked this movie, every actor did such an amazing job with their roles.

reviews.review_title: More like Dances with Oscars l o l
reviews.content: I thought the movie was actually excellent, it could be lengthy at times especially if you don't have captions on all the scenes with only Native speaking. I like the way that the Natives were representative, it seemed like they took their time to research what they would've actually worn and talked about at the time. I like the development of John Dunbar compared to how in the beginning he didn't have anything to live for and act on impulse then in the end he had a life and friends. The symbolism in the movie was great like between his horse and the wolf, it gave more context to the relationships that Dunbar had with the other characters in the movie. Good movie, had a fun time and all.

I really enjoyed watching this movie. It showed me how important it is to respect other people's way of living and their culture. Throughout the movie there were various parts that I found very interesting. The plot focuses on Lieutenant John Dunbar, a Civil war officer who befriends a band of Lakota Sioux and adopts their culture in the post-Civil War American West. This movie really shows the heart and pride of the Native Americans. I also really like how there were no captions at the time so you had to really focus on what they were talking about, especially when the natives were talking. So overall I really enjoyed this historic film.

The author has developed an interesting story which is probably more accurate than the vast majority of westerns we grew up with.  It shows the Indians as humans - different than the white man they battled, but unique in their own right.  It seems the author may have gone slightly overboard and ignored some of the Indians faults, but mostly did an excellant job. Costner could have accomplished more with less, four hours is too long especially when the story dragged along at times.

The movie with "Dances with Wolves" by Kevin Costner is a western
Drama movie about a character named John Dunbar who is a former civil war soldier who lives out on a post(house) by himself but later starts to develop a good relationship with the Native Americans and later learns how to communicate with them. I really liked the story and how it showed a more realistic look on the Natives and shows how they aren't really as deadly and vicious as they are made out to be, they are just trying to live free as anyone would want to. The ongoing meetings between Dunbar and the Native Americans was also something i really enjoyed, it was cool to see a white settler being nice to Natives and learning there traditions like bull hunting and even camp songs and dances. The only thing i really disliked was the Wolf, i didn't understand really why he was there and what his purpose was but it was also interesting to see the Wolf and Dunbar's relationship grow throughout the movie. Overall the movie is really enjoyable and i recommend it to anyone who enjoys Native history during that time period.

The portal of native american in this film was probably the only one that I feel didn't give native americans negative attributes of killing the american settlers, but it showed what the settlers did to them first and how they retaliated. Also you got to see more into the way they lived and communicated with each other and American settlers. So I would say that this movie was pretty good and I actually enjoyed certain parts of it. I don't usually watch shows like this but this is one that I probably could see myself watching on my own time. DWW is an excellent movie.  It has excellent performances, wonderful cinematography and moments of great power (Kevin Costner's character dancing around the fire, the final farewell from the clifftop, etc.)At the time it was released, I didn't see it.  My moviegoing companions weren't into film epics, and I assumed, and I had heard that it was basically a piece of propaganda to discuss the plight of the Native American.  However, when I saw it recently, I was pleasantly surprised. There is very little overt preaching.  The movie simply portrays the Native Americans as more than cartoonish villains or "noble savages".  Westerns with well-developed, three-dimensional Native American characters are rare in American cinema.The only weakness in the film is that in order to make its points, Costner chooses to portray the U.S. soldiers and other Whites in the film in broad negative strokes.  Except for Costner's character, they are all bigoted, violent, and ignorant.  Costner basically reverses the stereotypes of the traditional western, and the same way it was unfair and ineffective to portray the Native Americans as one-dimensional, it is unfair and ineffective to portray the Whites of that time period in the same way.
Overall, however, a rewarding film experience.

In the movie I like that it shows that Dunbar was part of the American Civil War. He had seen the war and wanted to stop being a part of that. Not that he didn't believe what he was fighting for, but it got to be too much for him that he wanted to take his own life. I do like how the Native Americans are portrayed in the movie. In most movies they are usually seen as dumb and savages. But in this movie they are seen as people that are trying to survive and trying to protect what little they have. When the Sioux are hunting for buffalo and they see what the white settlers are skinning the buffalo and just leaving the rest to rot that makes them sad because that is what they need to live. In old western movies they picture them as people that kill at random and have a vengeance for all the settlers, but the bigger picture is that they were doing that to protect themselves and their tribes. And they didn't kill all the white settlers. The thing that I didn't like about the movie is the ending. I wish there had been a better ending.

reviews.review_title: Connections with Natives and white settlers.
reviews.content: Dances with Wolves is a different type of historical movie. It's not like every other Native American/western film. There is a white Lieutenant named John Dunbar who started out as your typical white settler. However, throughout the movie he slowly converts into the Native culture. He is one of the only white settlers who takes the time to understand the Indians and develops a strong relationship with them. Based on the title of the movie, there is a wolf in the background of the movie. The wolf symbolizes the correlation between the white settlers and the Natives. The movie has some humor in it, which you wouldn't think a film like this would have. John Dunbar plays his role seriously, but at some moments he is comedical. Which brings a refreshing tone of the movie as a whole. Unfortunate as it is to say, there are some sad moments in the movie, but that's just how it works.

Dances with Wolves as I describe it, really shows the surrounding and setting taking place during the time of war and the Sioux tribe. From the characters to the dialogue being expressed into the story, everything seemed fit for this movie. It's no wonder the people who created this film won an award for this one of a kind film. The main character Lt. Dunbar really did a 180 turn as he was once just a boring and obedient lieutenant to becoming more open about himself with his mentality and spiritual self while spending time with the Sioux tribe and discovering even more freedom than he thought he would have. The language that the Native Americans used in this movie made me think of how realistically it was during their era in history and how much their language has changed throughout the year. In all honesty, I don't see anything wrong with this film other than the animal killing. The ending does get me confused at times with the thought of maybe a sequence could occur. I would have liked to see Dunbar's future with his wife and future family with their family customs and traditions they adopted while spending their time with their Sioux family.

Dances With Wolves was a great portrayal of Native American tribes. It's hard to find a movie with a positive representation of them in Hollywood. I feel like this movie is an authentic historical representation of the westward expansion and what it was like during that time. The only thing I didn't like was the ending I feel like just writing a short paragraph didn't do the realistic life of Natives during that time justice. The character development of Lieutenant Dunbar to Dances With Wolves was complex and showed how he went from serious and unsympathetic to compassionate and.softhearted. The portrayal of the cruel racist whites was nothing short of accurate. Not only did it show how bad the treatment was for the Native Americans but also the environment. The buffalo skinners were a very real example of this. Not only was it realistic it had a humor that was not really found in movies like this. This movie is like nothing like I've ever seen for historical period movies it brings a human side while also being historically accurate. It's hard not to be entertained and grow close to the characters in the movie. Dunbar, Kicking Bird, and Stand With a Fist are all interesting complex characters that have their own stories different from the plot. Overall this was a great movie.

reviews.review_title: A well made movie that is like a breath of fresh air
reviews.content: Very few movies are made with so much attention to detail. Kevin Costner deserves wholesome praise for this movie. It is one of those rare movies that takes a look at American Indians as human beings. Indians are also a fiercely proud and brave race. But in most of the movies they are revealed as savages and thieves. But it is different in Dances With Wolves. For his first movie, Costner impresses a lot. The camera work and direction are absolutely breathtaking. It is very difficult to understand that such an honestly and well made movie is not listed in IMDb Top 250. There are many stupid movies listed there but not this awesome and touching movie. This movie will always be among my favorites. A rare masterpiece that succeeds on more than one level.

I have seen this movie multiple times in my life and it gets better every time I watch it. I think it shows a great side of how Native Americans did or could have lived, and showed that relationships can always be built, regardless of barriers. John Dunbar was all alone and by himself, and he did something that no white man had done or thought about doing, he befriended and learned the ways of local Native American. He faced his fears and pushed the limits and learned many things about them and they learned about him. He learned their native language and a lot of their customs. This movie is an all time great in my opinion, one of my favorite films.

reviews.review_title: First Native American Movie with Cultural Appreciation
reviews.content: My first impression of Dances with Wolves was not too extraordinary, the protagonist seemed dull, with no motivation or personality. As the film progressed, though, I see that was the intention the whole time. The movie builds Dunbar's character in such a clear, successful way, showing how his previous way of life was so wrong, so full of hate and misinformation. I also appreciate how the Native American tribe Sioux is shown to the audience. The dedication to appreciation of language and culture that is now widely looked over in our society today is inspiring and also very progressive for the 1990's. I also noted how there was never a happy ending. Even at the very end, when the Sioux evaded the white settlers for the last time, the director made is known that they would not do that forever. They would meet the same fate as thousands of other tribes in the Great Plains. I think it is best to not put a sweet ending over such a tragic time for so many cultures at the time.When I am told movies are very good, I usually don't believe them. Either it's not my taste, or it is not an interesting topic to me- but this movie I believe can touch any person's heart. I truly recommend this movie to not only understand the tension at that period in history, but to appreciate and learn more about Native American culture. I give Dances with Wolves a 10/10, please give it a watch.

reviews.review_title: An appreciation for a fantasic flim
reviews.content: The movie, Dances with Wolves, was a very worthwhile watch. The portrayal of someone finding themselves through a different culture is very interesting and I feel like it can promote a healthy way of appreciating a culture instead of appropriating it. I love the characterization of John Dunbar. Yes, he did have the mindset that the Natives were bad but after interacting with them he learns that the stories that were spread around the states were just lies. I love the fact of John learning the language of his friends instead of him teaching them english. I feel like it was a nice change of the expectations of non white people needing to learn English in order to interact with the settlers and John himself was pretty funny although I feel like this was an unintentional move on the director's part). Dances with Wolves was a nice change in narrative with the interactions with Natives during the civil war and this is a must watch for everyone.

Dances with wolves was an awesome story of how native american portrayals can affect what people really will do just off of an assumption or what they have heard. And how one thing can totally skew your view of things. John dunbar is great example of how these internalized ideas of native americans can be shattered by taking a second to try and understand and accept them and their differences. And notice how once he does this they become closer and as they became closer more of the culture could be shared. Things like the wolf to signify his fate and his relationship with his native americans are excellent choices throughout the movie that allow for a better understanding of the movies themes to be found.

Costner played this part very well and did even better as the director. Watch this one you will love it.

reviews.review_title: Western but with a turn on natives
reviews.content: Dances with Wolves is a heartfelt western movie that is about an American soldier going off to live alone in the plains and befriend natives. The main character Dunbar is a lieutenant for the US army and is stationed at an abandoned post. The beginning of the movie is a little slow but as soon as he meets the local natives its action packed from there. The representation of the natives was different than most western's with some of the natives being a key part of the story line and had personalities. The movie showed much of their culture too such as celebrations and preparations for war. It shows how life was lived in the early beginnings of civilization of the United States and how many settlers saw the natives as savages and bad people. This is the reason most westerns have natives as bad guys but I really like how this one stands out and shows the other side.

The movie Dances with Wolves was a great movie to show the perspective of the Native Americans. The relationship between John and the Natives was very heartwarming and something most viewers would not usually see in a western type of movie. The beginning of the movie started off slow but it slowly got better and better. The end of the movie was quite sad in the fact that the army slowly moved them away from their original site but it showed how times really were back then. The connection between the title of the movie and the story to the movie is very interesting. The audience would have never guessed that that is what John's name would be to the indians. Every time you saw a wolf you would always see the Indians and John together or near each other and I found that really interesting. Overall this was a great movie and definitely worth watching.

I have issues with the movie as some others in how ALL white people, save Dunbar and Stands With a Fist, are portrayed. They are all portrayed as ignorant, aggressive, over-the-top evil characters. I am SURE some whites were like that but so could some native Americans be like that too. The movie also glosses over the real problem for plains Indians which was that even if US policy concerning them had been different, white people were going to expand westward anyhow and that the vast amounts of land that a small number of Indians "claimed" was going to cause a big problem anyhow. Indeed, the wars Indians had between each other were usually over tribal reach for hunting purposes to feed their particular tribe. Some of the movie was quite predictable too like Costner going to get the rifles he buried and saving the day against the Pawnee invaders. Basically, some of the movie was the Michael Moore view of the world that the Sioux were just kite flying peaceful people until the white man came which isn't accurate at all when you consider tribal warfare. That being said, having a movie from the Indian perspective is quite useful but this one wasn't it.

The whole movie gives you an insight on how Native Americans lived and salvaged their food and used every single part of their kill for something and nothing was ever wasted.

Of course as a teenager, this made the movie even easier to enjoy.The Indians lives were portrayed way differently than any other Western I've seen and I fully supported the way the writers chose to do it. Overall, this movie ended up being super great and I regret ever doubting it's potential.

Dances with Wolves depicts a non typical interaction between a white settler and a native american tribe. In many westerns, the stereotypical native american tribe is depicted as extremely aggressive, uncivilized and barbaric. However, in Dances with Wolves, these stereotypes are not portrayed. The tribe's culture is beautifully portrayed, the structures of their society are also clearly showcased as well as their humor, personalities, and sense of community. Dances with wolves help destroy these painful and destructive stereotypes of the native americans while painting them as real human beings. While also incorporating a white settler who came to the frontier, John Dunbar, and welcoming them into their culture and teaching him their ways, and vice versa. It also highlights the destructive nature of the white settlers and the problems they created for the native americans. In many cases the native americans basic survival, like hunting buffalo, was almost intangible for them because of the competition for resources with the white settlers. The script is flipped, now that the native americans are the protagonists and the white settlers are the antagonists. This point of view is nice to see in a western movie, along with the action, love, and family.

Now this epic western is a Kevin Costner picture based on a 1988 novel, Dances with Wolves by Michael Blake. Blake also penned the screenplay for the film. The movie delivers a very American Social Studies version of the US Civil War and the Sioux tribe. This is a very well made movie with a great cast, terrific story, and high-quality production. There are some alarming scenes for animal lovers. However, the Buffalo hunting scenes are breathtaking. It's no wonder that DwW took home so many awards at the 1991 Academy Awards. I'm not going to say that this is going to be for everyone. It's kind of a commitment since the run time is up to three and a half hours depending on the version you see. At least fifteen of those minutes feature Costner's butt. A trope in Costner pictures. But if you are checking out movies from 1990 then I think you've gotta check it out at least once.

After watching Kevin Costner in Yellow stone, I became a fan of him and started looking for his other cow boy type movies. Not too long and I came accross this movie. Apartfrom the amazing story and the direction this movie has, I can only say that I'm a more fan of Kevin now.

reviews.review_title: A reallistic picture of life itself
reviews.content: Besides the beautiful pictures of nature, which one can really miss in contemporary North America, this film is a real picture of life itself. Yes, there are things like good guys against the bad guys, barbarians and other things usually present in other westerns, but what I really saw in it is the human relations against the system, dignity against force, and friendship against indifference. And one thing about Kostner - he's by far not my favourite actor, but usually he's better when he's also the director.

For me it was amazing because it showed how some native Americans are bad people but is also shows how some are very nice people and how they could treat people who saves and respects them. For me it was exciting to see him at war with him fighting with the army to him helping the native Americans with the army and him going against them. It was also interesting how there was a girl that joined the native Americans and living with them even though they killed her parents and siblings. Even though they did that i think that that was the right thing to do because if they did not kill her parents then she would not have met john Dunbar and would never have been able to help Dunbar with translating what the natives would have said.

Love the story, music, and cinematography. Unfortunately, from the little I know of various Indigenous cultures, there is a lot of inaccuracies. I suppose one could forgive it as Indigenous already being corrupted by European culture.

I enjoyed this movie because of all of the different points of views it was seen from. Almost as if we were reading straight from John's journal. This movie also portrays native Americans differently. Instead of just showing us them trying to fight the Americans, it showed their lives too. It showed their humor and how they live. That's an aspect of the movie I really liked. As John lives among them he learns how they live and adapt. Rather than any other western with fighting and blood.I also thought it was interesting how the wolf symbolizes so many things. One thing the wolf was symbolizing was how you need a pack. Its easier to function and get things done when you're with a group of people. Everyone needs help with something in their life at some point. John is an american but found his pack with the native Americans.

I love this movie and the portrayal of the westward expansion. It doesn't step lightly around the fact that the Natives' homes were threatened and upended by the arrival of the settlers. The tensions and fights between the whites and the Natives is shown, yet there is a beautiful story of friendship that is formed by people of ridiculously different backgrounds. The bittersweet conclusion to the movie makes my imagination run wild. The gorgeous scenery and truly beautiful people in the cast take my breath away and always leave me wanting for more.

Wow. Everything about this movie is amazing. The acting, the scenery, the music... It's one of my mom's favorites, and I remember hearing the music when she and my dad watched it. (I was to little at the time) An appropriate word for it would be bittersweet. Near the beginning it's kind of boring and startling; John Dunbar tried to kill himself by riding in front of the enemy. In the process, the others named him a hero and awarded him a horse and a new rank (I think) The commanding officer which send him out with Timmons is perfectly revolting, and Timmons himself is disgusting but kind of funny. I find myself laughing at his morbid humor when he points to the skeleton and mentions the folks back east must be saying 'Why don't he write?' The first encounter with Kicking Bird is so funny! Dunbar's taking a bath, and chases after Kicking Bird (who is trying to steal the horse Cisco) naked. Mom says that in the book, Kicking Bird described the naked Dunbar as 'so white it hurt his eyes'. Another funny thing about this movie is the reaction of the Soux to the coffee and the sugar. After tasting some, Wind in His Hair likes the sugar so much he begins putting some in Kicking Bird's cup. This annoys Kicking Bird and he covers his cup so Wind In His hair will stop adding sugar. One of my favorite scenes in the movie is John Dunbar doing the fire dance back at the soldier fort. It always gives me goosebumps.The bitter part of the movie is bitter indeed. It's heartbreaking when the soldiers shoot both Cisco and Two Socks and treat Lt. Dunbar like an animal. When the Pawnee attack the Soux, it makes me feel sick to watch them pull the arrows from the dogs. The saddest part is the ending. As John Dunbar (now Dances with Wolves) rides away with Stands With a Fist and Wind In His Hair hollers at him from the clifftop. "Shumani Tutonka Obwa Chi!" "I am Wind in His Hair. Do you see that you are my friend?" I always tear up when I see that.With the gorgeous scenery, the flawless acting, the moving story, and the stirring music, I'd recommend this movie to anyone old enough to understand.

I absolutely love this movie, and watch it at least once per year. Costner did a great job, and so do the rest of the cast. It is incredibly sad how the Native Americans were treated across America during this time period. There is no excuse for the atrocities that occurred, yet it was also inevitable, given the circumstances. I would recommend this movie to anyone who would like to lose themselves in a story with a great ending. It's a great weekend movie where you just just kick back and relax, grab a bag of popcorn and enjoy!

Kevin Costner's "Dances With Wolves" involves a union soldier named John Dunbar (Costner), his leg wounded and ravaged, consciously chooses to die on the confederate line than suffer amputation. He purposely rides his horse along the enemies sideline trying to get shot. He survives and is awarded for his act of "bravery." With his leg fully healed, he relocates to a western fort in total solitude. Other soldiers unaware of his exact posting, he is left to fend for himself. As Dunbar rebuilds his new fort, he encounters nearby Sioux members. With no intentions of intimidation, Dunbar seeks out this indigenous tribe. He soon meets Stands With A Fist (Mary McDonnell), a white woman who was raised by this tribe. She mutilates herself while mourning for her lost husband. He returns her to the Sioux people and tries to communicate with them, after discovering the language barrier is too great Stands With A Fist translates between Dunbar and the Sioux. Thus beginning a relationship between white man and the Indians. Dunbar adapts to the culture and learns the language while romancing Stands With A Fist. Eventually Dunbar is given his nickname of "Dances With Wolves." After he helps the tribe defend themselves from a rival Pawnee attack, he marries Stands With A Fist and is fully integrated into the Sioux. Of course the tribe must relocate due to pressure of the white men, Dunbar of course says he will accompany them. When he returns to his fort, Dunbar is confronted by U.S army men and is arrested as a traitor. While he is transported, the Sioux track them down and kill the white soldiers and free Dunbar. Dunbar then makes the decision to leave the tribe with his new wife to prevent any further danger on the Sioux. The last shot of the film tells us that 13 years later, the last of the Sioux were subjugated to the American government.This was Costner's first film as director and for a debut, it is excellent. As far as strengths, the film has a soft, leisurely pace, which combined with a gorgeous score from John Barry, create a very lush canvas. Visually, "Dances" is strong, with compositions that are simple yet ethereal. The tone is also quite delectable. Almost poetic, as if Costner invites us to yearn for a more simpler time in American history to enjoy his tale.As far as it's flaws, the most obvious is probably the relationship between Dunbar and his wife (who is the "native" girl in the film). Although Costner handles their love scene very romantically, it's almost ridiculous the transfer of bodily fluids represents bringing two cultures together and all differences are virtually erased. This symbolism is rather stupid and has been used in several other films. More recently in James Cameron's "Avatar".8/10. For other westerns, see "Unforgiven", "Rio Bravo", or Sergio Leone's filmography. For a more unconventional western, see "McCabe and Mrs. Miller".

reviews.review_title: A magnificent tribute for a culture lost over time...
reviews.content: "Dances With Wolves" is another great period piece that I can watch at least once a year, never tiring of the western frontier against mesmerizing setting and John Barry's Oscar-winning stirring music... The motion picture is told through the words and experiences of a civil war soldier, Lieutenant John Dunbar, and Costner makes it an intensely spiritual journey which challenges the individual in so many ways... After his suicidal and successful ride on the battlefield, Lt. Dunbar accidentally leads Union troops to victory against the Confederates... He is allowed to select his own reassignment... John opts to retreat into the wilderness, to the furthest frontier, where both the Sioux and Pawnee Indians still rule... The film perfectly captures the finest kind of American audacity when Costner rides out alone in the Lakota plains, wearing full dress uniform and holding the large American flag to formally introduce himself to his Sioux neighbors... and the worst of America, the cruelty exercised by the army when it's found he's a Yankee soldier turned Indian and arrested as a traitor... But it's the gentle humor and intimate moments of the movie which give Costner's ambitious epic Western its special flavor: scenes with Dunbar and his wild wolf Two Socks not daring, at first, to eat from his hand; his funny first encounter with a peaceful man Kicking Bird (Graham Greene); his love story with a stolen white woman living with the tribe called Stands With a Fist (Mary McDonnell); his relationship with a fierce impulsive warrior Wind in His Hair (Rodney A. Grant); and many others as Black Shawl (Tantoo Cardinal) advising her husband on affairs of the heart... With its share of bow-and-arrow fights, joyous buffalo hunts, and unprecedented tender feelings for the American Indians, "Dances With Wolves" remains an amazing accomplishment and a magnificent tribute for a culture lost over time...

reviews.review_title: More like a spiritual experience than just a film!
reviews.content: I just saw "Dances With Wolves" again, the four hour extended version with an added overture, intermission and extra hour of footage. Wow I'm speechless. It's a lot more than just a movie. It's like a spiritual experience and a great epic as well. Every moment in it is meaningful and moving. And the masterpiece musical score makes every moment moving and soulful as well. I've never seen such a musical score complement a film so well.What's special and unique about this film is that when the protagonist character John Dunbar (Kevin Costner) slowly transforms into a Native American soul, you (the viewer) feel like you are going through the transformation process along with him. That's what makes it like an experience, rather than just a film.What's more, if you are a white American guy with a deep observant genuine soul and personality, you will relate to John Dunbar's character - his alienation from his white culture, as well as his connection with the Sioux tribe. (Thus this film has a Happier Abroad theme to it as well) Dunbar is the only deep observation genuine white character in the film, along with his lover, because the rest of the white characters in this epic seem so degenerate and hollow, or robotic, in comparison.I would try to see this on a big screen though, so you can appreciate the scenery, which most of this film focuses on, even more than the characters. Set aside four hours and dim the lights to see it. Then you will understand what I mean. I think it's one of the top ten best films of all time. And it's Costner's best role as well. On IMDb, almost everyone gave it a 10 out of 10. Also, on Amazon.com nearly every reviewer gave it 5 stars out of 5 as well.You can get the DVD version on Amazon.com for 5 dollars or download it from Amazon.com for a few dollars.I think it's a Happier Abroad film (referring to the movement I started at HappierAbroad.com) too because in the story, John Dunbar (Kevin Costner) experiences social connection, harmony and genuineness with the Sioux tribe, and then realizes how hollow and empty his white culture is. His soul slowly becomes Sioux, to the point where he doesn't fit in anymore with American life. The soldiers at the end who capture and persecute him look so degenerate, soulless and depraved compared to the Sioux tribe he joined. Only then do you realize the comparison.Anyway, this is a must see film. It reflects the spirit and feeling of our movement at HappierAbroad.com. Everyone should see it to understand our point of view better.

Mary McConnell puts in a great performance as Stands With a Fist, and Graham Green is his usual subtle self. I would highly recommend this movie as a good way to round out your viewing experience - this is Costner's masterpiece.

The first director's work of Kevin Costner - Dances With Wolves - is an epic Western movie that tells the story of Union army Lieutenant John Dunbar (played by the very same Costner), who travels to the frontier to serve at a military post and afterward encounters Native Americans, which inhabit that area. It's one of the very few movies that condemns the actions of the US government towards Native Americans and the violent settlement of the West. It does not justify the actions of Indigenous Americans (like killing and stealing) either and aims to narrate the story objectively.Guns, horses, fight scenes, and Indians - all these are Western movie attributes inherent in Dances With Wolves. Nonetheless, it still doesn't look like a typical representative of this genre. Its essence is somewhat different, at least to me. Growing up, I watched quite a few movies of this genre. At the back of my mind, they were all about a cowboy - a wanted cowboy, in most cases - who killed villains and fought for justice, but not the generally accepted justice, it also could be a justice of his own. Western movies definitely stood out to me among other movie genres and evoked certain emotions of fun and entertainment. However, it is pretty different in the case of Dances With Wolves. It was a rollercoaster of varied emotions and feelings, which I shared with John Dunbar as if I experienced what he did through the screen. Those were the emotions and feelings of confusion and perplexity at the beginning of the movie, namely in the scenes of a bloody field hospital, in the scenes of a mocking depiction of a Civil War battle, and subsequently John's encounter with a weirdly shocking officer (masterfully played by Maury Chaykin). Later, those were the feelings of calmness and peacefulness during John's stay at Fort Sedgewick with beautiful scenery of American Great Plains and the feelings of concern and interest in John's confrontations with Indians following his assimilation into their community. The strongest emotions of all were the emotions of rage and resentment for the gratuitous actions of the US army shown in the movie and all the injustice they provoked.What also distinguishes Dances With Wolves from a typical Western movie is the presence of a love story. While in the tribe, John Dunbar falls in love with a beautiful young white woman (played by Mary McDonnell), who was raised by the Sioux and named Stands With a Fist. Female characters were not central characters in this movie genre for a long time and became playing leading roles closer to the end of the twentieth century.A considerable part of the movie is devoted to Native Americans, namely to the Sioux tribe. Having made friends with Sioux, John Dunbar writes in his journal: "they have gentle humor I enjoy, it seems every day is a miracle. I have never known people so eager to laugh and so dedicated to family." Hence we discover their other, a better side, in contrast to what USa propaganda promulgated to its citizens. Sioux don't wish for a war; they simply want to live on their ancestors' land.Western movies are known for their action, crossfires, and horse racings. Dances With Wolves follows this trend but at the same time uses a slow narration pace. Considering that the movie is almost four hours long, it is neither boring nor slow. The musical score complements the movie wonderfully and helps to capture all the emotions of the story.Well-written and nicely filmed, Dances With Wolves is more than just a movie - it's a message to us to remember our past and learn from the mistakes we have made. I wish this movie were simply a work of fiction, but knowing that the historical facts underlie the basis of its plot, makes it even more engaging to watch.

reviews.review_title: An epic dedicated to the human civilization
reviews.content: I'm not an American. I have no right to judge this history and I'm not going to. The saddest thing about this movie is that we all know the end but we don't want it to come. We hope the harmony situation can last long, longer than the movie showed. But there's no way to expect that the tragedy of the Indian culture never come. Ancient civilization is bound to be replaced by modern one, though it may take blood, tears, darkness and sin to go through this. It's inevitable. As one saying (in China) goes, men are created to die. Though this analogy seems pretty sad, it's quite true. As soon as a man is born, he is moving to death every day, every hour and every second. So does human civilization. Human beings have gone through the original society, agriculture society, and now we are going through industrial society. It's impossible for us to foresee what the next society will be like after, say, 10000 years. So we can say that the industrial societies we build today are made to die, just like the original society and agriculture society. It's cruel to say this, but it does expose the cruelty that the world we live in and history we went through truly posses.This movie showed us this bloody and glory,miserable and honorable substitution process. So it's sure to be an epic. It's an epic dedicated to the human civilization.Also, being an epic requires magnificent scenes. This movie created a quite perfect one with the prairie, the sky, the buffalo and the wolf. Why do I count "wolf" in? Well, this movie spent a lot on that, didn't it? First, the name, "Dances with Wolves". Then the real wolf, there are lots of scenes about it. More importantly, this wolf, "two socks", is a symbol of Indian civilization. Outside the Indians look like cavemen, which is terrifying, this is similar to the wolf. But inside, they are kind, generous and warm-hearted, just like the development of the relationship between "two socks" and John Dunbar. So the denouement of the wolf marks the denouement of Indian culture.P.S. The music played in this movie is so wonderful and it contributed to the epic atmosphere. I think the only music which is better than this one is "My Heart Will Go On" in Titanic.

reviews.review_title: John Audabon would have been unhappy
reviews.content: Watching Dances With Wolves again after many years, I noted an historical error. In the scene out west when Dunbar arrives at his new station and looks through the old structure, a Dove lands on the sill. The Dove is supposed to be a Mourning Dove but is obviously a European Collared-Dove. European Collared-Doves did not arrive in the United States until the late 1900s, and probably did not get to South Dakota until nearly 1990 when the movie was filmed. The first were seen in the southeastern U. S. and did not get west or north for many years. Eurasian Collared-Doves originated from the Indian Sub-continent and arrived in Florida in the late 1970s. This bird is now common throughout the U. S.

Twenty years after winning 7 Academy Awards, this film is still one of the greatest American epics of our time. Now available on Blu-Ray, I can only hope that a new generation will discover - and the rest remember - what an enduring classic this is. Based on the 1988 novel by Michael Blake (the e-book of which was also just released this week), Dances With Wolves tells the story of Lieutenant John J. Dunbar as he retreats from the battlefields of the Civil War to the expanses of the American frontier. Left alone and forgotten at the abandoned Fort Sedgewick, the lieutenant's solitude is broken only by the strange visits of an old wolf and the constant companionship of his horse, Cisco. That is, until a nearby Indian tribe returns to their summer home a few miles away. Though initially fearful of one another, the Native American people introduce Dunbar to a new way of life - a life that gradually draws him away from his identity as an officer of the Union Army and into a new identity as "Dances With Wolves."

Seriously. And this is a kid talking.

Lieutenant John J. Dunbar became a hero accidentally because of that he wanted to suicide but led Union to winning. After that, he volunteered to go to frontier. On the way, he heard some bad things about Indians. When he got to the Fort Sedgwick, there isn't anything. He was there by his own, and met Kicking Bird who is medicine man of Sioux tribe and was attracted by Sioux's culture. They became more and more friendly to each others. Dunbar felt that they have a lot of difference, because Indians are optimistic and innocent. He was with them and help them to defend their children, women, and food. In addition, he felt he is a part them. They help him to be marry, even poor families did so. It's a little different to what I know in the movie. In other movies, cowboys are always very tough. In this movie, it is more emphasis the difference between Sioux and pioneers' concepts. Dunbar isn't very rugged, but he has higher technology than Sioux. There are lots of difference, but it doesn't comment which one is true, it even makes me feel Indians' concept is more important than modern concept. At that time, the bad conditions make people hard to live, pioneers only can rely on themselves, I think that's why Thanksgiving is so important to Americans. Dunbar has a hero ability which is can-do spirit, he can live in the Fort Sedgwick, but he go to Sioux tribe and help Sioux to find buffaloes and defend their village,We are always threatened by environment nowadays, I feel that Indians' concept is completely good for us. In this movie, Dunbar doesn't really want to fight to nature and native Americans. Primitive life style is sort of cruel. However, living in that style can be really sustainable development. Dunbar is a hero whose type is what I like, because he is sensitive, brave, and kindhearted.

I think the movie is trying to speak for Indians. It describes a white officer Dunbar in the United States who volunteers to go to the west front to station. At last make friends with Sioux warriors who even have a different language and culture. Later on, the white people regard him as a traitor, and treat him with violence. What's more, they even want to execute him with hanging punishment. After Dunbar seeing what white army did, he starts to feel shameful for the white army and he stands totally on the Sioux's side and insists that his name is "dances with wolves". Dunbar tries to persuade Indians to move the camp because he knows he cannot change what is going to happen, but in the end, the Indians' leader, Ten Bears only smiled and talked of simple pleasures. He reminded Dunbar that at his age, a good fire was better than anything. I think Ten Bears was an extraordinary man. Finally, the Indians were suffering from a massacre.The movie's title is "Dances with wolves", there really is a wolf that always stays around Dunbar in the movie, and I think the director is trying to express something; he wants people to meditate. When someone mentioned wolves, the first impression comes to my mind is "loneliness". The wolf in this movie metaphors a belief of grief and strength. When I watched over this movie last weekend, at that night, I thought much about that movie and I lied on bed and even cannot sleep as early as before. I am not sure that's because of the regards of the friendship built between Dunbar and the Indians or because I felt sad when I realized the harsh reality that the tragedy came from human's nature of desire and cruel.The white people think the Indians are ruthless and rude who cannot have a conversation with. Actually brutal and rude Indians are exceptional. Just like what Dunbar says when he knows more about the Sioux people:" nothing I have been told about these people is correct. They are not beggars or thieves. They are not the brutal men they have been made out to be. On the contrary, they are polite and have the familiar humor I enjoy. The communication is slow however. The "Quiet" is frustrated as I am. Most of our progresses were based on failure rather than success". I like these words in Dunbar's journal, so I wrote these words down when I saw the movie. I always thought that if I were him, what would I do?"Dances with Wolves" is the name of the movie, the name of a white lieutenant Dunbar, but it also give us a feeling of beauty and sadness. It shows the close contact between people, between people and animals, between man and nature. However, "wolf" is alone after all and is not comprehended by "the people", I like the howl of the wolf at the end of the movie, and I think we can feel its destiny as well as Dunbar's from this sad howl. I think the misunderstanding is one of the crucial reasons leads to the massacre to Indians other than exploring frontier. Besides, we should have lived in harmony with Indians together.
